('69', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 1
('69', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. A GREAT FRIEND GONE
('69', 0, 2, 3, 65) It is not usual in these columns to have obituary notices of all the great men who pass away.
('69', 0, 2, 4, 159) This is a journal devoted to a special cause.
('69', 0, 2, 5, 205) Such notices are taken generally only of those who had specially identified themselves with the Harijan cause.
('69', 0, 2, 6, 316) I had to use extraordinary self restraint to avoid noticing Kamala Nehru’s death.
('69', 0, 2, 7, 398) It almost become an oppression.
('69', 0, 2, 8, 430) But I need exercise no such restraint about Dr. Ansari’s death.
('69', 0, 2, 9, 494) For he was essentially a symbol of Hindu Muslim unity with Hakim Saheb Ajmal Khan.
('69', 0, 2, 10, 577) Dr. Ansari never wavered in his faith even when it was put to a severe test.
('69', 0, 2, 11, 654) He was an orthodox Mussalman proud of his descent from the helpers of the Prophet when the latter was most in need of help.
('69', 0, 2, 12, 778) His very staunchness and his intimate knowledge of Islam made Dr. Ansari a believer in Hindu Muslim unity.
('69', 0, 2, 13, 885) It is no exaggeration to say that he had at least as many Hindu as he had Mussalman friends.
('69', 0, 2, 14, 978) He was one of the ablest physicians in all India.
('69', 0, 2, 15, 1028) His advice was freely available to the poor of all races.
('69', 0, 2, 16, 1086) And what he earned from the princes and rich men, he spent with both hands among his many needy friends.
('69', 0, 2, 17, 1191) No beggar approached him without emptying whatever his pocket contained, and he never counted what he gave.
('69', 0, 2, 18, 1299) He was a tower of strength to hundreds of men and women who swore by him.
('69', 0, 2, 19, 1373) I have no doubt that he has left many literally weeping for the personal loss they have sustained.
('69', 0, 2, 20, 1472) He has left a wife who is a philosopher though invalid.
('69', 0, 2, 21, 1528) She is too brave and too much of a believer to shed a tear over her loss.
('69', 0, 2, 22, 1602) But the many whom I have in mind are no philosophers.
('69', 0, 2, 23, 1656) Their faith in God is vapoury; their fatih in Dr. Ansari was living.
('69', 0, 2, 24, 1725) It was no fault of theirs that their faith in God was weak as with most of us.
('69', 0, 2, 25, 1804) They had many proofs of the Doctor’s friendship when they thought God had forsaken them.
('69', 0, 2, 26, 1893) They little knew that even the great Doctor could only help them so long as his Maker allowed him.
('69', 0, 2, 27, 1992) Would that what he could not accomplish while he was alive would be accomplished by his death.
('69', 0, 3, 28, 2087) Harijan, 16 5 1936
('69', 1, 0, 1, 2106) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 1, 1, 2, 2146) 2. HINDI OR HINDUSTANI−II
('69', 1, 2, 3, 2172) In the previous article 1 I have already showed how and why I regard Hindi and Hindustani as synonymous terms and why it is necessary to retain the use of the word ‘Hindi’.
('69', 1, 2, 4, 2345) An objection to the use of the word ‘Hindi’ has been thus stated in the letter 2 reproduced in the last issue:
('69', 1, 3, 5, 2456) It has been studied by Mussalmans in the past and they have done as much if not more than their Hindu brethren to raise it to the status of a literary language.
('69', 1, 3, 6, 2617) But it has also religious and cultural associations with which Mussalmans as a whole cannot identify themselves.
('69', 1, 3, 7, 2730) Besides, it is now evolving a vocabulary that is exclusively its own and is generally unintelligible to those who know only Urdu.
('69', 1, 3, 8, 2860) If the Mussalmans of old studied and enriched Hindi in the past, why should they of the present generation avoid it?
('69', 1, 3, 9, 2977) Surely the Hindi of old had greater religious and cultural associations than modern Hindi has today.
('69', 1, 3, 10, 3078) And should one avoid the use of a language because of its religious and cultural associations?
('69', 1, 3, 11, 3173) Must I avoid Arabic and Persian for their religious and cultural associations?
('69', 1, 3, 12, 3252) I may not be affected by the latter, if I do not want to be or if I have antipathy towards them.
('69', 1, 3, 13, 3349) Surely if we are to live together as blood brothers that we are, we may not fight shy of each other’s culture.
('69', 1, 3, 14, 3460) And why quarrel with the use of Sanskrit words, in Hindi to the point of rebelling against the language itself?
('69', 1, 3, 15, 3572) The unnatural process of using Sanskrit words in the place of simpler current words or giving the derived words their original Sanskrit form is undoubtedly a reprehensible practice and robs a language of its music.
('69', 1, 3, 16, 3787) But a certain use of Sanskrit words, as the nation expands, is inevitable in the hands of Hindus who know only Sanskrit, as the use of Arabic is inevitable in the hands of Mussalmans who know only Arabic, though both write the same language and have no special likes or dislikes.
('69', 1, 3, 17, 4067) Educated Hindus and Mussalmans will have to acquaint themselves with both the forms.
('69', 1, 3, 18, 4152) Is this not true of all growing languages?
('69', 1, 3, 19, 4195) Educated Englishmen know both ‘sympathy’ and ‘fellow feeling’or ‘fatherly’ and ‘paternal’ or
('69', 1, 4, 20, 4288) 1 Vide “Hindi or Hindustani”, 9 5 1936 2 For extracts from the letter, vide Appendix, “For Hindustan only”, 9 5 1936.
('69', 2, 0, 1, 4406) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 3
('69', 2, 1, 2, 4448) yearly’ and ‘annual’.
('69', 2, 1, 3, 4470) The difficulty with us is that just now our hearts are not one and the best of us are affected by the virus of mutual suspicion.
('69', 2, 1, 4, 4599) Hindi, Hindustani and Urdu are different names for the same speech just as the dialects of Cornwall, Lancashire and Middlesex are different names for the same speech.
('69', 2, 1, 5, 4766) What is being aimed at today is not to evolve a new language but to adopt the language known under the three names as the inter provincial language.
('69', 2, 1, 6, 4915) I believe Shri Munshi was right when he defended the form of the language used in Hans.
('69', 2, 1, 7, 5003) For rendering, say, a Tamil or Telugu piece into Hindi or Hindustani, the use of Sanskrit words is almost inevitable, even as the use of Arabic words would be inevitable if one was translating an Arabic piece into Hindi or Hindustani.
('69', 2, 1, 8, 5238) Rabindranath’s Gitanjali in Hindi would read much less musical than it does, if its Hindi or Hindustani translation studiously avoided the Sanskrit words with which Bengali is replete.
('69', 2, 1, 9, 5423) Literary Musssalmans like Moulvi Abdul Haq Sahib or Aquil Sahib have but to make thier own contribution to the common speech to avoid its degenerating into a language only spoken by the Hindus.
('69', 2, 1, 10, 5617) I would if I could wean them from treating the Urdu form as the exclusive speech of Mussalmans, as I would wean literary Hindus from treating Hindi as the exclusive speech of Hindus.
('69', 2, 1, 11, 5800) If none of them is weaned, there will be no common speech for Hindus and Mussalmans of the North, no matter by what name it is known.
('69', 2, 1, 12, 5934) Here at least, therefore, we do not need to quarrel about the name.
('69', 2, 1, 13, 6002) Call it by what name you like, if only you mean the same thing in all sincerity.
('69', 2, 1, 14, 6083) There remains the question of script.
('69', 2, 1, 15, 6121) At the present moment insistence on Devanagari by Mussalmans is not to be thought of.
('69', 2, 1, 16, 6207) Insistence on the adoption of Arabic script by the vast mass of Hindus is still less thinkable.
('69', 2, 1, 17, 6303) What therefore I have suggested as the definition of Hindi or Hindustani is ‘that language which is generally spoken by Hindus and Mussalmans of the North, whether written in Devanagari or Urdu’.
('69', 2, 1, 18, 6499) I abide by that definition, in spite of protests to the contrary.
('69', 2, 1, 19, 6565) But there is undoubtedly a Devanagari movement with which I have allied myself whole heartedly and that is to have it as the common script of all the languages spoken in the different provinces, especially those which have a large Sanskrit vocabulary.
('69', 2, 1, 20, 6817) Anyway, an attempt is being made to transcribe in Devanagari script the most precious treasures of all the languages of India .
('69', 2, 2, 21, 6945) Harijan, 16 5 1936
('69', 3, 0, 1, 6964) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 3, 1, 2, 7004) 3. LETTER TO PURUSHOTTAM GANDHI
('69', 3, 2, 3, 7036) NANDI DURG, May 16, 1936
('69', 3, 3, 4, 7061) PURUSHOTTAM,
('69', 3, 4, 5, 7074) You must have received an unexpected letter 1 from me even before I got yours.
('69', 3, 4, 6, 7153) The noble hopes expressed in it could be entertained only of one like you brought up in the Ashram from childhood.
('69', 3, 4, 7, 7268) Vijaya alone would know the state of her mind but you have to be a teacher to her.
('69', 3, 4, 8, 7351) The circumstance is common in the Hindu family.
('69', 3, 4, 9, 7399) If you wish to follow the duties of married life as I have suggested, I have also outlined its restriction in my article.
('69', 3, 4, 10, 7521) If you find these difficult, it only means that you have not really understood the one purpose of sexual intercourse.
('69', 3, 4, 11, 7639) Even to the husband the wife is a mother.
('69', 3, 4, 12, 7681) It has been said in a book that the woman giving birth to a child gives birth to a portion of the husband himself, and that therefore after she has conceived she deserves to be daily honoured with a namaskara much as his own mother.
('69', 3, 4, 13, 7914) Such things are looked upon as intellectual indulgence.
('69', 3, 4, 14, 7970) The conviction that such things need to be put into practice has not gone down people’s throat.
('69', 3, 4, 15, 8066) Hence they turn a deaf ear to any talk of acting according to it.
('69', 3, 4, 16, 8132) “The path of God is for the brave alone.” Read this to Vijaya if you think it fit.
('69', 3, 5, 17, 8215) Blessings from
('69', 3, 7, 18, 8230) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II
('69', 3, 8, 19, 8274) 4. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('69', 3, 9, 20, 8303) May 16, 1936
('69', 3, 10, 21, 8316) NARANDAS,
('69', 3, 11, 22, 8326) Herewith a letter 2 for Purushottam and Marybehn’s letter to you.
('69', 3, 11, 23, 8392) Yesterday I had a telegram telling me of the death at Rishikesh of a very benevolent lady, Tarabehn Chesley, whom you do not know.
('69', 3, 12, 24, 8523) 1 Vide “Letter to Purushottam and Vijaya Gandhi”, 14 5 1936 2 Vide the preceding item.
('69', 4, 0, 1, 8610) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 5
('69', 4, 1, 2, 8652) She was on her way to Badri Kedar with two other women.
('69', 4, 1, 3, 8708) She was a learned person, living an exceedingly simple life.
('69', 4, 1, 4, 8769) Kusum is having a nice time.
('69', 4, 1, 5, 8798) She comes out daily for a walk with me.
('69', 4, 1, 6, 8838) I do hope this place will help her recover her health.
('69', 4, 1, 7, 8893) Kanu moves about, absorbed in his work.
('69', 4, 1, 8, 8933) He has been trying to train his hand on the dilruba 1, and his instrument accompanies the Ramayana recitation every day.
('69', 4, 1, 9, 9054) All the three brothers 2 sing the verses in unison, and now Kusum has joined them.
('69', 4, 1, 10, 9137) Sardar walks for four hours every day, and Mahadev and Mani accompany him.
('69', 4, 1, 11, 9212) It is beyond my capacity to take such long walks.
('69', 4, 1, 12, 9262) Kumarappa and Shantabehn are of course here.
('69', 4, 1, 13, 9307) Both are good company to each other and spend their time working.
('69', 4, 1, 14, 9373) Ba keeps fairly good health.
('69', 4, 1, 15, 9402) This is how our little world here goes on.
('69', 4, 1, 16, 9445) I learn from Kusum’s talks that the Bal Mandir has been running at a loss.
('69', 4, 1, 17, 9520) In my opinion, we should send an account of income and expenditure to the parents and notify to them that the Bal Mandir would be closed if they did not help to meet this expenditure.
('69', 4, 1, 18, 9704) You may also mention that the house rent, etc., is not included in the accounts .
('69', 4, 1, 19, 9786) You should, however, include Kusum’s salary of Rs. 35 or 40 as also those of the other teachers, if any, whatever they are paid.
('69', 4, 1, 20, 9915) We might go about begging to run the school if the children belonged to the Harijan or some other so called lower communities, but certainly not for the others; and emphatically not a Bal Mandir.
('69', 4, 1, 21, 10111) The very poor cannot afford to send their children there; nor is there any great need that they should.
('69', 4, 1, 22, 10215) Please think over this and, if you are convinced about it, you should consult the Committee and give the parents notice of one or two months.
('69', 4, 1, 23, 10357) Kusum says that you have increased the fee already, in which case the increase should be only to the extent of meeting the increased cost.
('69', 4, 1, 24, 10496) You must be aware that there are several schools in the country, which bring profits to the owners after defraying all expenses.
('69', 4, 1, 25, 10625) Many schools, for example, the Bharda High School, are a source of income.
('69', 4, 1, 26, 10700) Only the Proprietary High School of Ahmedabad and some others regarded as national schools and some experimental schools are run with the help of contributions
('69', 4, 2, 27, 10860) 1 A stringed musical instrument 2 Kanti Gandhi, Kanu Gandhi and Navin Gandhi; in fact, cousins
('69', 5, 0, 1, 10955) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 5, 1, 2, 10995) raised from the public.
('69', 5, 1, 3, 11019) I think we should get away from this kind of work and give our time to work among Harijans and in the villages.

('69', 5, 3, 7, 11238) 5. LETTER TO AMRITLAL T. NANAVATI
('69', 5, 4, 8, 11272) May 16, 1936
('69', 5, 5, 9, 11285) AMRITLAL, I read the two lines you added to Nimu's letter to me.
('69', 5, 5, 10, 11350) See that you preserve your health.
('69', 5, 5, 11, 11385) Give the body as much milk, curds and ghee as it might need.
('69', 5, 5, 12, 11446) It is only if you preserve your health that I shall be able to take from you all the work I want.
('69', 5, 5, 13, 11544) Tell Bhanubapa that an obstacle has again cropped up.
('69', 5, 5, 14, 11598) A fresh estimate is contemplated for the place where the building is to be put up.
('69', 5, 5, 15, 11681) This is a complicated affair.
('69', 5, 5, 16, 11711) Perhaps Mahadev will have to be sent to Nasik.
('69', 5, 5, 17, 11758) Did you hear anything further as regards the summons?
('69', 5, 5, 18, 11812) Let Nimu have her studies to her fill.
('69', 5, 5, 19, 11851) All are well and happy here.
('69', 5, 5, 20, 11880) The coolness here and the hot winds there—what a contrast!
('69', 5, 5, 21, 11939) Yet one may not say that here I am in better health than there.
('69', 5, 5, 22, 12003) The fact is that heat does not affect me.
('69', 5, 5, 23, 12045) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 10714

('69', 6, 1, 2, 12516) 7. LETTER TO AMTUSSALAAM
('69', 6, 2, 3, 12541) NANDI DURG, May 17, 1936
('69', 6, 3, 4, 12566) DEAR DAUGHTER,
('69', 6, 4, 5, 12581) All that you write about Doctor Saheb is perfectly true.
('69', 6, 4, 6, 12638) We have no one to take his place.
('69', 6, 4, 7, 12672) But we do not know if his death was for the good or otherwise.
('69', 6, 4, 8, 12735) God alone is the best judge.
('69', 6, 4, 9, 12764) He gives and He takes away.
('69', 6, 4, 10, 12792) We should only learn a lesson from Doctor Saheb's death.
('69', 6, 4, 11, 12849) We should carry on from where he left.
('69', 6, 4, 12, 12888) Mourning and fasting serve no purpose.
('69', 6, 4, 13, 12927) Those who believe in God have no reason to fear death.
('69', 6, 4, 14, 12982) Those who are born are bound to die.
('69', 6, 4, 15, 13019) You do not want any more clarification on your earlier letters, do you?
('69', 6, 4, 16, 13091) Now you do not have to go to Patiala or Chitrakoot or even to join me.
('69', 6, 4, 17, 13162) To me you can come whenever you feel like it.
('69', 6, 4, 18, 13208) Otherwise the Harijan Ashram is all you should devote yourself to.
('69', 6, 4, 19, 13275) This is not my own suggestion but deduced from the last letter from Doctor Saheb.
('69', 6, 4, 20, 13357) You are taking, I hope, the medicine prescribed by him.
('69', 6, 4, 21, 13413) We are all well.
('69', 6, 4, 22, 13430) I do not write separately to Tyagiji.
('69', 6, 4, 23, 13468) Rajkishori is happy, I suppose.
('69', 6, 5, 24, 13500) Blessings from

('69', 7, 7, 28, 15897) If death is not a prelude to another life, the

('69', 18, 6, 22, 33023) 1 Vide “Letter to Zakir Husain”, 11 5 1936 2 Lala Lajpat Rai 3 The first cutting read: Bombay, May 18—Mr. Jawaharlal Nehru, addressing a ladies' meeting this evening, said that he was asked in several places why he had not included women in the Congress Working Committee.
('69', 18, 6, 23, 33296) He was surprised that no such question was forthcoming from women.
('69', 18, 6, 24, 33363) He continued, “The responsibility of choosing the Working Committee members rests with the President, and you all know what the situation was at Lucknow.
('69', 18, 6, 25, 33517) You know the price I had to pay for my views and I will have to continue to pay such price.

('69', 23, 0, 1, 40942) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 23, 1, 2, 40983) Africa they occurred at intervals of several years.
('69', 23, 1, 3, 41035) I do not remember exactly.
('69', 23, 1, 4, 41062) Here in India they have been of months.
('69', 23, 1, 5, 41102) I have mentioned the fact of my getting discharges in a few articles of mine.
('69', 23, 1, 6, 41180) If my brahmacharya had been completely free from discharges, I would have been able to place before the world very much more than I have succeeded in doing.
('69', 23, 1, 7, 41337) But it seems practically impossible that a person who has indulged in sex gratification from the age of 15 to 30, maybe with his own wife only, can, on taking a vow of brahmacharya, control the discharge of his vital fluid completely.
('69', 23, 1, 8, 41572) One whose capacity for retention has progressively weakened from day to day for fifteen years cannot recover it fully all at once.
('69', 23, 1, 9, 41703) Both his body and mind will have become too weak for that.
('69', 23, 1, 10, 41762) I, therefore, consider myself a very imperfect brahmachari.
('69', 23, 1, 11, 41822) But my position is like that of the castor oil plant which looks big on a heath where there are no trees.
('69', 23, 1, 12, 41928) People know this shortcoming of mine.
('69', 23, 1, 13, 41966) The experience which tormented me in Bombay was a strange and painful one.
('69', 23, 1, 14, 42041) All my discharges so far had occurred in dreams and they never troubled me.
('69', 23, 1, 15, 42117) I could forget them.
('69', 23, 1, 16, 42138) But the experience in Bombay occurred while I was fully awake and had a sudden desire for intercourse.
('69', 23, 1, 17, 42241) I felt of course no urge to gratify the craving, there was no self forgetfulness whatever.
('69', 23, 1, 18, 42332) I was completely master of my body.
('69', 23, 1, 19, 42368) But despite my best efforts the organ remained aroused.
('69', 23, 1, 20, 42424) This was an altogether strange and shameful experience.
('69', 23, 1, 21, 42480) I have already explained the cause.
('69', 23, 1, 22, 42516) 1 As soon as that cause was removed the state of remaining aroused came to a stop, that is, waking state.
('69', 23, 1, 23, 42622) Despite my imperfection, one thing has always come easily to me, viz., that thousands of women have remained safe in my company.
('69', 23, 1, 24, 42751) There have been occasions in my life when certain women, though aroused, were saved by God, or say, I was saved.
('69', 23, 1, 25, 42864) I am a hundred per cent certain that it was God who saved us and, therefore, take no pride in the fact.
('69', 23, 1, 26, 42968) It is my unceasing prayer to God that I might remain in the same condition till the very end of my life.
('69', 23, 1, 27, 43073) I have been striving to attain to Shukadeva's 2 condition.

('69', 23, 1, 29, 43166) If I succeed, I would become a eunuch 3

('69', 28, 1, 2, 49725) 38. IN MEMORIAM
('69', 28, 2, 3, 49741) Miss Mary Chesley, an Englishwoman, came to India in 1934 when the Congress was in session 1 in Bombay.
('69', 28, 2, 4, 49845) As soon as she landed she came to my hut in the Congress camp and told me she knew Mirabehn and had expected to come with her but somehow or other she had preceded her by a week or there about.
('69', 28, 2, 5, 50039) Her desire was to serve India through her villages.
('69', 28, 2, 6, 50091) She did not prepossess me by her talk and I thought she would not stay in India many months.
('69', 28, 2, 7, 50184) But I was wholly mistaken.
('69', 28, 2, 8, 50211) She had come to know of Miss Mary Barr who had already commenced village work in Khedi, a village a few miles from Betul (C.P.).
('69', 28, 2, 9, 50340) Miss Chesley found her way to Mary Barr.

('69', 28, 2, 13, 50675) She would dig, carry baskets full of earth on her head.
('69', 28, 2, 14, 50731) She simplified her food as much as to put her health in danger.
('69', 28, 2, 15, 50795) She had her own handsome income from Canada from which she kept only a paltry sum of about Rs. 10 for herself and gave the rest to the A.I.V.I.A., or to Indians with whom she came in contact and who seemed to her to give promise of being good village workers and who needed some pecuniary help.

('69', 29, 3, 13, 52706) 39. BRIBERY
('69', 29, 4, 14, 52718) Bribery in the name of mamul 1 and the like to railway officials and the others is not an unusual occurrence in Indian life.
('69', 29, 4, 15, 52843) Any official with whom the public has anything to do is generally said to be open to receive bribes even for the performance of his duty, not to speak of committing breach thereof.
('69', 29, 4, 16, 53024) I have had to suffer in my time for refusing to pay a paltry anna at the third class ticket windows for getting my ticket in my turn which would never come because favourites had to be served first.
('69', 29, 4, 17, 53223) I have had to wait for hours sometimes before I could get a chance of buying my ticket.
('69', 29, 4, 18, 53311) The customs and the railways are the two departments with which the general public have to come in frequent touch.
('69', 29, 4, 19, 53426) And it is there that the public suffer most.
('69', 29, 4, 20, 53471) A correspondent draws my attention to the woes of public workers who want to despatch goods or receive consignments.
('69', 29, 4, 21, 53588) At either end unless you are prepared to bribe officials, you are made to wait exasperatingly long.
('69', 29, 4, 22, 53688) He wants to know how this evil can be remedied.
('69', 29, 4, 23, 53736) There is desire among spirited workers to resist this immoral blackmail.
('69', 29, 4, 24, 53809) It is difficult to advise in this matter.
('69', 29, 4, 25, 53851) Obviously no bribe 2 may possibly be given.
('69', 29, 4, 26, 53895) Equally obviously public work must not be allowed to suffer.
('69', 29, 4, 27, 53956) There is no quick remedy against a petty official who misuses his brief authority.
('69', 29, 4, 28, 54039) Threat to lodge a complaint produces no effect on hardened officials.
('69', 29, 4, 29, 54109) They know their strength and use it mercilessly, for it is a matter of pecuniary gain for them.
('69', 29, 4, 30, 54205) They have come to think these perquisites are a part of their pay.
('69', 29, 4, 31, 54272) And he who

('69', 30, 1, 2, 54363) questions their right to demand them needs to be taught a lesson.
('69', 30, 1, 3, 54429) Lesson or no lesson, someone has to have the courage to bring to book those who will not recognize the new spirit that is seizing so many workers.
('69', 30, 1, 4, 54576) Despatch or clearance work may suffer for the time being.
('69', 30, 1, 5, 54634) It is worth while taking the risk, if thereby officals will learn the elementary morality of not taking bribes.

('69', 30, 2, 9, 55015) 40. MARRIAGE BY PURCHASE
('69', 30, 3, 10, 55040) Some months ago The Statesman opened its columns to a discussion of the dowry system prevalent among many castes almost all over India, and dealt with it editorially.
('69', 30, 3, 11, 55207) I used to write on the cruel custom 1 often enough in the columns of Young India.
('69', 30, 3, 12, 55289) The cuttings from The Statesman revive the cruel memories of what I used to know then.
('69', 30, 3, 13, 55376) My remarks were aimed at deti leti as the custom is known in Sind.
('69', 30, 3, 14, 55443) Enough educated Sindhis were found who exacted large sums of money from parents who were anxious to see their daughters well married.
('69', 30, 3, 15, 55577) The Statesman has carried on a crusade against the custom in general.
('69', 30, 3, 16, 55647) There is no doubt that the custom is heartless.
('69', 30, 3, 17, 55695) But so far as I am aware it does not touch the millions.
('69', 30, 3, 18, 55752) The custom is confined to the middle class who are but a drop in the ocean of Indian humanity.
('69', 30, 3, 19, 55847) Whenever we talk of evil customs, we usually think of the middle class.
('69', 30, 3, 20, 55919) The millions living in the villages have their customs and woes of which we have as yet but little knowledge.
('69', 30, 3, 21, 56029) This however does not mean that one may ignore the dowry evil because it is confined to a comparatively small number of the people of this country.
('69', 30, 3, 22, 56177) The system has to go.
('69', 30, 3, 23, 56199) Marriage must cease to be a matter of arrangement made by parents for money.
('69', 30, 3, 24, 56276) The system is intimately connected with caste.
('69', 30, 3, 25, 56323) So long as the choice is restricted to a few hundred young men or young women of a particular caste, the system will persist no matteer what is said against it.
('69', 30, 3, 26, 56484) The girls or boys or their parents will have to break the bonds of caste if the evil is to be eradicated.
('69', 30, 3, 27, 56590) Then the age for marrying has also to be raised and the
('69', 30, 4, 28, 56646) 1 The source has “customs.”
('69', 31, 0, 1, 56674) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 31, 1, 2, 56715) girls have to dare to remain spinsters, if need be, i.e., if they do not get a suitable match.
('69', 31, 1, 3, 56810) All this means education of a character that will revolutionize the mentality of the youth of the nation.
('69', 31, 1, 4, 56916) Unfortunately the system of education has no connection with our surroundings which therefore remain practically untouched by the education received by a microscopic minority of the boys and girls of the nation.
('69', 31, 1, 5, 57128) Whilst, therefore, whatever can be done to abate the evil must be done, it is clear to me that this evil and many others which can be named can only be tackled if there is education which responds to the rapidly changing conditions of the country.
('69', 31, 1, 6, 57376) How is it that so many boys and girls who have even passed through colleges are found unable or unwilling to resist the manifestly evil custom which affects their future so intimately as marriage does?
('69', 31, 1, 7, 57578) Why should educated girls be found to commit suicide because they are not suited?
('69', 31, 1, 8, 57660) Of what value is their education if it does not enable them to dare to defy a custom which is wholly indefensible and repugnant to one's moral sense?
('69', 31, 1, 9, 57810) The answer is clear.
('69', 31, 1, 10, 57831) There is something radically wrong in the system of education that fails to arm girls and boys to fight against social or other evils.
('69', 31, 1, 11, 57966) That education alone is of value which draws out the faculties of a student so as to enable him or her to solve correctly the problems of life in every department.
('69', 31, 2, 12, 58130) Harijan, 23 5 1936

('69', 46, 1, 2, 81574) 61. LETTER TO VITHAL V. DASTANE
('69', 46, 2, 3, 81606) NANDI DURG, May 27, 1936
('69', 46, 3, 4, 81631) BHAI DASTANE,
('69', 46, 4, 5, 81645) It appears you are expecting too much from me.
('69', 46, 4, 6, 81692) You know my present limitations in placing the thing before the country.
('69', 46, 4, 7, 81765) Publicity, however, is inherent in diligence in your own work.
('69', 46, 4, 8, 81828) In response to his letter I have asked Dev to let me know the location, plan and other facts.
('69', 46, 4, 9, 81922) In the mean while here are my answers to your questions: (1) In the rainy season you should grow there the requisite vegetables as also a few flowering plants.
('69', 46, 4, 10, 82082) You should also grow such food grain as could be harvested by December.
('69', 46, 4, 11, 82154) All this should be utilized at the time of the Congress session.
('69', 46, 4, 12, 82219) Measurements of the land should be obtained right now.
('69', 46, 4, 13, 82274) Make notes of places which are waterlogged during the rainy season.
('69', 46, 4, 14, 82342) If there is any tank which gets filled up, this water too should be conserved.
('69', 46, 4, 15, 82421) For this job you should immediately obtain the services of an expert agriculturist and an expert engineer.
('69', 46, 4, 16, 82528) I take it that you will get their help gratis.
('69', 46, 4, 17, 82575) Do see Shankerlal right now.
('69', 46, 4, 18, 82604) He knows about this more than anyone else.
('69', 46, 4, 19, 82647) Mhatre the architect has worked for two sessions; so please take him there right now.
('69', 46, 4, 20, 82733) Again ask Shankerlal about Nandalal Bose and the material from the Santiniketan exhibition.
('69', 46, 4, 21, 82825) Contact Lakshmidas, as also Jajuji and Kumarappa.
('69', 46, 4, 22, 82875) Mhatre will help you with the calculations regarding the time and space for the pandal, barracks, etc.
('69', 46, 4, 23, 82978) Assume that the minimum time required would be three months, so that the construction work should start soon after the monsoon is over.

('69', 54, 5, 9, 95968) 71. SELF CONTROL AGAIN
('69', 54, 6, 10, 95991) Your recent articles 1 on self control have created quite a stir.
('69', 54, 6, 11, 96057) Persons who are in sympathy with your views find it difficult to exercise self control for any length of time.
('69', 54, 6, 12, 96168) They argue that you are applying your own experience and practice to the whole mankind.
('69', 54, 6, 13, 96256) And even you have admitted that you do not fulfil the definition of a complete brahmachari.
('69', 54, 6, 14, 96348) For you yourself are not
('69', 54, 7, 15, 96373) free from animal passion.
('69', 54, 7, 16, 96399) And since you admit the necessity of limiting the number of children a married couple may have, the use of contraceptives is the only practical method open to the vast majority of mankind.
('69', 54, 7, 17, 96588) Thus writes a correspondent.
('69', 54, 7, 18, 96617) I have admitted my own limitations.
('69', 54, 7, 19, 96653) In this matter of self control v.
('69', 54, 7, 20, 96687) contraceptives, they constitute my qualifications.
('69', 54, 7, 21, 96738) For my limitations show quite clearly that I am like the majority of earth earthy and can have no pretensions to any extraordinary gifts The motive for my self control was also quite ordinary, viz., the desire to limit the progeny for the purpose of serving the country or humanity.
('69', 54, 7, 22, 97021) Inability to support a large family should be a greater incentive than the very distant one of serving one’s country or humanity.
('69', 54, 7, 23, 97151) That in spite of thirty five years of successful (from the present standpoint) self control, the animal in me still needs watching shows in an eminent degree that I am very much an ordinary mortal.
('69', 54, 7, 24, 97349) I, therefore, do suggest that what has been possible for me is possible for any human being who would make the required effort.
('69', 54, 7, 25, 97477) My quarrel with the advocates of contraceptives lies in their taking it for granted that ordinary mortals cannot exercise self control.
('69', 54, 7, 26, 97613) Some of them even go so far as to say that even if they can,
('69', 54, 8, 27, 97674) 1 Vide “For Contraceptives”, 4 4 1936; “For Women Reformers”, 2 5 1936; also “Birth Control [ I], “Birth Control II” and “For the Young”, 28 3 1936
('69', 55, 0, 1, 97822) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 55, 1, 2, 97863) they ought not to do so .
('69', 55, 1, 3, 97889) To them, no matter how eminent they may be in their own spheres, I say, in all humility but with utmost confidence, they are talking without experience of the possibilities of self control.
('69', 55, 1, 4, 98079) They have no right to limit the capacity of the human soul.
('69', 55, 1, 5, 98139) In such instances the positive evidence of one person like me, if it is reliable, is not only of greater value but decisive.
('69', 55, 1, 6, 98264) To dismiss my evidence as useless because I am popularly regarded as a ‘mahatma’ is not proper in a serious inquiry.
('69', 55, 1, 7, 98381) Far more weighty is the argument of a sister who says in effect:
('69', 55, 2, 8, 98446) We, the advocates of contraceptives, have come on the scene only recently.
('69', 55, 2, 9, 98521) You self controllers had the field all to yourselves all these long generations, maybe thousands of years.
('69', 55, 2, 10, 98628) What have you to show to your credit?
('69', 55, 2, 11, 98666) Has the world learnt the lesson of self control?
('69', 55, 2, 12, 98715) What have you done to stop the misery of over burdened families?
('69', 55, 2, 13, 98780) Have you heard the cry of wounded motherhood?
('69', 55, 2, 14, 98826) Come, the field is even now open to you.
('69', 55, 2, 15, 98867) We do not mind your advocacy of self control.
('69', 55, 2, 16, 98913) We may even wish you success, if perchance you save wives from the unwanted approaches of their husbands.
('69', 55, 2, 17, 99019) But why should you seek to decry the methods which we employ and which take note of and make every allowance for common human weaknesses or habits and which when properly employed almost never fail to accomplish their purpose?
('69', 55, 3, 18, 99246) The taunt is dictated by the anguish of a sister filled with compassion for the families that are always in want because of the ever increasing number of children.
('69', 55, 3, 19, 99410) The appeal of human misery has been known to melt hearts of stone.
('69', 55, 3, 20, 99477) How can it fail to affect high souled sisters?
('69', 55, 3, 21, 99524) But such appeals may easily lead one astray, if one is lifted off one’s feet and, like a drowning man, catches [at] any floating straw.
('69', 55, 3, 22, 99660) We are living in times when values are undergoing quick changes.
('69', 55, 3, 23, 99725) We are not satisfied with slow results.
('69', 55, 3, 24, 99765) We are not satisfied with the welfare merely of our own caste fellows, not even of our own country.
('69', 55, 3, 25, 99865) We feel or want to feel for the whole of humanity.
('69', 55, 3, 26, 99916) All this is a tremendous gain in humanity’s march towards its goal.
('69', 55, 3, 27, 99984) But we won’t find the remedy for human ills by losing patience and by rejecting everything that is old because it is old.
('69', 55, 3, 28, 100106) Our ancestors also dreamt, perhaps vaguely, the same dreams that fire us with zeal.
('69', 55, 3, 29, 100190) The remedies they applied for similar ills, it is possible, are applicable even to the horizon that appears to have widened beyondexpectations.
('69', 55, 3, 30, 100334) And my plea based on positive experience is that even as truth and ahimsa are not merely for the chosen few but for the whole of
('69', 56, 0, 1, 100463) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 57
('69', 56, 1, 2, 100506) humanity to be practised in daily life, so exactly is self control not merely for a few ‘mahatmas’ but for the whole of humanity.
('69', 56, 1, 3, 100636) And even as because many people will be untruthful and violent, humanity may not lower its standard, so also though many, even the majority, may not respond to the message of self control, we may not lower our standard.
('69', 56, 1, 4, 100856) A wise judge will not give a wrong decision in the face of a hard case.
('69', 56, 1, 5, 100928) He will allow himself to appear to have hardened his heart because he knows that truest mercy lies in not making bad law.
('69', 56, 1, 6, 101050) We may not attribute the weaknesses of the perishable body or the flesh to the imperishable soul that resides in it.
('69', 56, 1, 7, 101167) We have to regulate the body in the light of the laws that govern the soul.
('69', 56, 1, 8, 101243) In my humble opinion, these laws are few and unchangeable, capable of being understood and followed by the whole of the human family.
('69', 56, 1, 9, 101377) There would be differences of degree but not of kind in their application.
('69', 56, 1, 10, 101452) If we have faith, we won’t lose it because it may take a million years before humanity realizes or makes the nearest or visible approach to its goal.
('69', 56, 1, 11, 101602) In Jawaharlal’s language, let us have the correct ideology.
('69', 56, 1, 12, 101662) The sister’s challenge, however, remains to be answered.
('69', 56, 1, 13, 101719) The “self controllers” are not idle.
('69', 56, 1, 14, 101756) They are carrying on their propaganda.
('69', 56, 1, 15, 101795) If their method is different in kind from the method of contraceptives, so is and must be their propaganda.
('69', 56, 1, 16, 101903) “Self controllers” do not need clinics, they cannot advertise their cure for the simple reason that it is not an article to be sold or given.
('69', 56, 1, 17, 102045) But their criticism of contraceptives and warning to the people against their use is part of their propaganda.
('69', 56, 1, 18, 102156) The constructive side has always been there, but naturally in an unfelt and unseen manner.
('69', 56, 1, 19, 102247) Advocacy of self control has never been suspended.
('69', 56, 1, 20, 102298) The most effective is that of example.
('69', 56, 1, 21, 102337) The larger the number of honest persons who practise successful self control, the more effective becomes the propaganda.
('69', 56, 2, 22, 102458) Harijan, 30 5 1936

('69', 57, 1, 2, 102684) drawing near.
('69', 57, 1, 3, 102698) I reproduce below the notice 1 that appeared in Harijan dated August 31, 1935.
('69', 57, 2, 4, 102777) CERTIFIED DEALERS, NOT CERTIFIED KHADI
('69', 57, 3, 5, 102816) The manager of the Burma Branch of the A. I. S. A. writes to the Secretary: 2
('69', 57, 4, 6, 102894) With reference to the article of Gandhiji under the caption “Uncertified Khadi” in Harijan of 11 4 1936, I beg to bring to your notice the fact that
('69', 57, 5, 7, 103043) here in Burma also, spurious khadi is sold in large quantities and it is a common practice amongst the uncertified dealers to demonstrate to the buyers that they are stocking and selling khadi certified by A.I.S.A., by showing to them the words “Certified by A.I.S.A.” stamped on (some) cloth or the label bearing these words affixed on (some) cloth ....
('69', 57, 6, 8, 103398) We have therefore often and often to bring to the notice of the public and the credulous buyers the fact that khadi or cloth is never certified by A. I. S. A. but it is only the dealer or the party that is certified, (and the public are advised to buy only from A.I.S.A. or A. I. S. A. certified dealers or depots.) You will thus see that it is wrong for us to use the words “certified khadi” or “uncertified khadi” because it only strengthens the hands of uncertified dealers.
('69', 57, 7, 9, 103876) Now that the use of these words is made even by Gandhiji.
('69', 57, 7, 10, 103934) I have not been able to check myself from bringing to your notice the mistake that we unconsciously commit by using the words “certified khadi” or “uncertified khadi”.
('69', 57, 7, 11, 104102) I gladly make amends.
('69', 57, 7, 12, 104124) It is undoubtedly an error to speak of certified khadi.
('69', 57, 7, 13, 104180) It will be difficult to certify pieces and it is futile to expect buyers to make sure of every article they purchase, whether it is genuine or not.
('69', 57, 7, 14, 104328) The A.I.S.A. has always therefore followed the practice of certifying stores and dealers selling only genuine khadi in the cloth line.
('69', 57, 7, 15, 104463) I hope that, whether in Burma or elsewhere, lovers of khadi will make themselves sure that they buy only from stores or dealers certified by the A.I.S.A.
('69', 57, 8, 16, 104617) Harijan, 30 5 1936

('69', 57, 10, 18, 104706) 2 Only excerpts of the letter are reproduced here.

('69', 65, 1, 6, 118571) Miss Barr has, I think, struck the true balance.

('69', 65, 3, 8, 118718) “Yes,” said Dr. Rosenthal but energetically added, “but not with the desire to convert the people.
('69', 65, 3, 9, 118817) The religious motive is what spoils most of their work I hate conversion.” No doubt you would, being the daughter of your father.
('69', 65, 4, 10, 118947) And yet, you will be rather surprised that I have come up against a sentence in my father's writings which I cannot understand.
('69', 65, 4, 11, 119075) He says, in effect, that he could not understand why people were unable to accept a religion because of the outside temptations that were offered them.
('69', 65, 4, 12, 119227) It must be just the contrary.
('69', 65, 4, 13, 119257) I should like to see that text.
('69', 65, 4, 14, 119289) It cannot be as you say.
('69', 65, 5, 15, 119314) I shall send you the text.
('69', 65, 5, 16, 119341) Yes, do.
('69', 65, 5, 17, 119350) And then if I am right and you are wrong you will have to admit that I am a better son of your father than you are his daughter.
('69', 65, 6, 18, 119479) I think, Mahatmaji, we have to contend against religion being mixed up too much with the daily life of our people.
('69', 65, 6, 19, 119594) No, if it is true religion we want more of it.
('69', 65, 7, 20, 119641) I do not want to exclude true religion.
('69', 65, 7, 21, 119681) I shall give you an example.
('69', 65, 7, 22, 119710) We have in one of our centres a very good Harijan nurse.
('69', 65, 7, 23, 119767) One day a Brahmin came there wih his son who was suffering from sores.
('69', 65, 7, 24, 119838) The doctor with the help of the nurse washed the sores and dressed them and bandaged them.
('69', 65, 7, 25, 119929) But lo and behold the consternation of the Brahmin when he found that it was a Harijan nurse who had dressed his boy's sores.
('69', 65, 7, 26, 120055) He took him to the nearest river, bathed him and washed away the whole dressing and bandage!
('69', 65, 7, 27, 120148) That is no religion.
('69', 65, 7, 28, 120169) It is rank superstition.
('69', 65, 7, 29, 120194) You will come across instances of that kind, but they are getting fewer every day.
('69', 65, 8, 30, 120277) Harijan, 6 6 1936
('69', 66, 0, 1, 120295) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 67
('69', 66, 1, 2, 120337) 81. LETTER TO CHIMANLAL N. SHAH
('69', 66, 2, 3, 120369) BANGALORE CITY, May 31, 1936
('69', 66, 3, 4, 120398) CHIMANLAL,
('69', 66, 4, 5, 120409) I have your postcard.
('69', 66, 4, 6, 120431) It is surprising that you never are quite free from illness.
('69', 66, 4, 7, 120492) However, watch the result of the serum injection.
('69', 66, 4, 8, 120542) Why should Babu 1 write to me, now that she is a learned lady?
('69', 66, 4, 9, 120605) However, I would not complain if she never wrote to me, so long as she does not fall ill or grow weak.
('69', 66, 4, 10, 120708) I know complaining will not avail but I would not complain even to myself, if Babu made her body like copper.
('69', 66, 4, 11, 120818) How very seriously you take the Narandas episode!
('69', 66, 4, 12, 120868) It is contrary to non violence.
('69', 66, 4, 13, 120900) Not to mind the pain inflicted whether by a friend or by a foe is one more form of non violence.
('69', 66, 4, 14, 120997) Such conduct is part and parcel of non violence.
('69', 66, 4, 15, 121046) Moreover, we must also think of the friend's point of view.
('69', 66, 4, 16, 121106) Why should we be pained if he said or did something without ill will even though his words or act were improper?
('69', 66, 4, 17, 121219) You could point out his error, if any, to Narandas in case you are convinced that he is not a man to take any step out of ill will.
('69', 66, 4, 18, 121351) Be patient if he is unable to see his error, but never take offence.
('69', 66, 4, 19, 121420) Even if you think that he had an evil motive, your heart should feel no shock because a malicious person deserves to be pitied.
('69', 66, 4, 20, 121548) Should we take offence at the act of one who deserves pity?
('69', 66, 4, 21, 121608) My purpose in writing this is that you may analyse the state of your mind, apply to it the touchstone of non violence and, if you detect your error, rectify it, cleanse your heart and calm down.
('69', 66, 5, 22, 121803) Blessings to you all from
('69', 66, 6, 23, 121829) BAPU [PS.] We shall be here till the 12th.

('69', 69, 1, 2, 127026) 85. SPEECH AT LABOURERS’ MEETING
('69', 69, 2, 3, 127059) KOLAR GOLD FIELDS, May 31, 1936
('69', 69, 3, 4, 127091) Gandhiji, speaking to a mass meeting of mine labourers for a few minutes, said he had paid a hurried visit to the labour huts which seemed to him too small, too ill lighted and too low roofed to be fit for human habitation.
('69', 69, 3, 5, 127315) If the workers only knew what they could do for themselves by combining their training and intelligence they would realize that they were no less proprietors of the mines than the managers and shareholders.
('69', 69, 3, 6, 127522) Their labour was better gold than the metal they extracted with their labour from the bowels of the earth.
('69', 69, 4, 7, 127629) Gandhiji made an earnest appeal to the mining authorities to see to the betterment of the lot of coolies working in the mines, through whom the mining authorities derived their maximum benefit.
('69', 69, 4, 8, 127823) Mahatmaji wanted that the mining officials should give the same facilities to the coolies working underground as they did to the highly paid officials.
('69', 69, 5, 9, 127975) Mahatmaji said that he could not congratulate the management on their efforts to house the poor.
('69', 69, 5, 10, 128072) He understood that the labourers were charged about twelve annas to one rupee per hut.
('69', 69, 5, 11, 128159) The rent should be much less.
('69', 69, 6, 12, 128189) He reminded the mine owners that unless they voluntarily recognized the due status of labour and treated it as they treated themselves, time was not far distant when labour would dictate its own terms.
('69', 69, 6, 13, 128391) He mentioned his theory of trust which he had propounded before the Ahmedabad mill owners.
('69', 69, 6, 14, 128482) He told the workers that whilst it was right and proper to assert their rights they ought to do their tasks as if the mines were their personal property.
('69', 69, 6, 15, 128636) He also asked them to shun drink, gambling and other vices.
('69', 69, 7, 16, 128696) Mahatmaji observed that considering the cause for which the money was collected, this sum of Rs. 619 from the Kolar Gold Fields area was not much.
('69', 69, 8, 17, 128843) Harijan, 13 6 1936, and The Hindu, 1 6 1936

('69', 69, 9, 19, 128938) 2 This sentence is from The Hindu.

('69', 71, 1, 2, 130214) 87. SPEECH AT MUNICIPAL COLONY, BANGALORE 1
('69', 71, 2, 3, 130258) [After May 31, 1936] 2
('69', 71, 3, 4, 130281) I was taken to the huts of the workers in the Kolar Gold fields the other day.
('69', 71, 3, 5, 130360) I could not help remarking that the huts were not fit for human habitation.
('69', 71, 3, 6, 130436) With the mining Company declaring fat dividends of 30 to 40 per cent it seemed to be cruel to me that those who earned the profits for them were housed in those dismal hovels.
('69', 71, 3, 7, 130612) The huts you have built here are certainly better, they are well ventilated and well situated.
('69', 71, 3, 8, 130707) But there ought to be something like a minimum standard of a hut for unmarried people and of a hut for married couples and couples with children.
('69', 71, 3, 9, 130853) We ought to realize that husband and wife must not share the same room with grown up children.
('69', 71, 3, 10, 130948) These cabins provide for no privacy.
('69', 71, 3, 11, 130985) I cannot understand municipalities measuring out land for their poor employees by so many feet.
('69', 71, 3, 12, 131081) One more room for each of these huts and a verandah is an absolute necessity.
('69', 71, 3, 13, 131159) I am glad you propose to provide the same facilities for the Harijan employees, but pray bear this suggestion in mind when you build houses for them.
('69', 71, 3, 14, 131309) There are, I am pained to say, still numerous municipalities which provide no housing facilities for their lowest paid employees.
('69', 71, 3, 15, 131439) I do not know when we shall realize our duty to the most essential of our servants.
('69', 71, 3, 16, 131523) If we do not do so ere long, the doom will soon settle on our society, as it must, if the society does not correct itself.
('69', 71, 4, 17, 131646) Harijan, 11 7 1936
('69', 71, 5, 18, 131665) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('69', 71, 5, 19, 131715) The colony, consisted of 250 huts, built by the Municipality for its employees.
('69', 71, 5, 20, 131795) 2 From the reference to Kolar Gold fields in the speech it is evident that this visit took place after May 31, 1936.

('69', 75, 6, 10, 136775) 94. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('69', 75, 7, 11, 136804) BANGALORE, June 2, 1936
('69', 75, 8, 12, 136828) The newspapers report that about a fortnight ago my eldest son Harilal, now nearing fifty years, accepted Islam and that on Friday last 29th May in the midst of a large congregation in the Jumma Musjid at Bombay, he was permitted to announce his acceptance amid great acclamation and that, after his speech was finished, he was besieged by his admirers who vied with one another to shake hands with him.
('69', 75, 8, 13, 137232) If his acceptance was from the heart and free from any worldly considerations, I should have no quarrel.
('69', 75, 8, 14, 137337) For I believe Islam to be as true a religion as my own.
('69', 75, 8, 15, 137393) But I have the gravest doubt about this acceptance being from the heart or free from selfish considerations.
('69', 75, 8, 16, 137502) Everyone who knows my son Harilal, knows that he has been for years addicted to the drink evil and has been in the habit of visiting houses of ill fame.
('69', 75, 8, 17, 137655) For some years he has been living on the charity of friends who have helped him unstintingly.
('69', 75, 8, 18, 137749) He is indebted to some Pathans from whom he had borrowed on heavy interest.
('69', 75, 8, 19, 137825) Up to only recently he was in dread of his life from his Pathan creditors in Bombay.
('69', 75, 8, 20, 137910) Now he is the hero of the hour in that city.
('69', 75, 8, 21, 137955) He had a most devoted wife who always forgave his
('69', 75, 9, 22, 138005) 1 The Statement, published in Harijan under the title “To My Numerous Muslim Friends”, was issued to the Press on June 2, 1936.
('69', 76, 0, 1, 138133) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 77
('69', 76, 1, 2, 138175) many sins including his unfaithfulness.
('69', 76, 1, 3, 138215) He has three grown up children, two daughters and one son, whom he ceased to support long ago.
('69', 76, 1, 4, 138310) Not many weeks ago he wrote to the Press complaining against Hindus—not Hinduism—and threatening to go over to Christianity or Islam.
('69', 76, 1, 5, 138444) The language of the letter showed quite clearly that he would go over to the highest bidder.
('69', 76, 1, 6, 138537) That letter had the desired effect.
('69', 76, 1, 7, 138573) Through the good offices of a Hindu councillor he got a job in Nagpur Municipality.
('69', 76, 1, 8, 138657) And he came out with another letter 1 to the Press recalling the first and declaring emphatic adherence to his ancestral faith.
('69', 76, 1, 9, 138785) But, as events have proved, his pecuniary ambition was not satisfied and in order to satisfy that ambition, he has embraced Islam.
('69', 76, 1, 10, 138916) There are other facts which are known to me and which strengthen my inference.
('69', 76, 1, 11, 138995) When I was in Nagpur, in April last, he had come to see me and his mother and he told me how he was amused by the attentions that were being paid to him by the missionaries of rival faiths.
('69', 76, 1, 12, 139185) God can work wonders.
('69', 76, 1, 13, 139207) He has been known to have changed the stoniest hearts and turned sinners into saints, as it were, in a moment.
('69', 76, 1, 14, 139318) Nothing will please me better than to find that during the Nagpur meeting and the Friday announcement he had repented of the past and had suddenly become a changed man having shed the drink habit and sexual lust.
('69', 76, 1, 15, 139531) But the Press reports give no such evidence.
('69', 76, 1, 16, 139576) He still delights in sensation and in good living.
('69', 76, 1, 17, 139627) If he had changed, he would have written to me to gladden my heart.
('69', 76, 1, 18, 139695) All my children have had the greatest freedom of thought and action.
('69', 76, 1, 19, 139764) They have been taught to regard all religions with the same respect that they paid to their own.
('69', 76, 1, 20, 139861) Harilal knew that if he had told me that he had found the key to a right life and peace in Islam, I would have put no obstacle in his path.
('69', 76, 1, 21, 140001) But no one of us, including his son now twenty four years old and who is with me, knew anything about the event till we saw the announcement in the Press.
('69', 76, 1, 22, 140156) My views on Islam are well known to the Mussalmans who are reported to have enthused over my son’s profession.
('69', 76, 1, 23, 140267) A brotherhood of Islam has telegraphed to me thus:
('69', 76, 2, 24, 140318) Expect like your son you truth seeker to embrace Islam truest religion
('69', 76, 3, 25, 140389) 1 For Gandhiji’s comment on it, vide “Letter to P. M. Naidu”, 3 3 1936
('69', 77, 0, 1, 140460) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 77, 1, 2, 140501) of world.
('69', 77, 1, 3, 140511) I must confess that all this has hurt me.
('69', 77, 1, 4, 140553) I sense no religious spirit behind this demonstration.
('69', 77, 1, 5, 140608) I feel that those who are responsible for Harilal’s acceptance of Islam did not take the most ordinary preca utions they ought to have in a case of this kind.
('69', 77, 1, 6, 140767) Harilal’s apostasy is no loss to Hinduism and his admission to Islam is a source of weakness to it if, as I apprehend, he remains the same wreck that he was before.
('69', 77, 1, 7, 140932) Surely conversion is a matter between man and his Maker who alone knows His creatures’ hearts.
('69', 77, 1, 8, 141027) And conversion without a clean heart is, in my opinion, a denial of God and religion.
('69', 77, 1, 9, 141113) Conversion without cleanness of heart can only be a matter for sorrow, not joy, to a godly person.
('69', 77, 1, 10, 141212) My object in addressing these lines to my numerous Muslim friends is to ask them to examine Harilal in the light of his immediate past and, if they find that his conversion is a soulless matter, to tell him so plainly and disown him and if they discover sincerity in him to see that he is protected against temptations so that his sincerity results in his becoming a godfearing member of society.
('69', 77, 1, 11, 141609) Let them know that excessive indulgence has softened his brain and undermined his sense of right and wrong, truth and falsehood.
('69', 77, 1, 12, 141738) I do not mind whether he is known as Abdulla or Harilal if, by adopting one name for the other, he becomes a true devotee of God which both the names mean.
('69', 77, 2, 13, 141894) Harijan, 6 6 1936

('69', 81, 1, 2, 146892) 101. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('69', 81, 2, 3, 146923) June 5, 1936
('69', 81, 3, 4, 146936) NARANDAS,
('69', 81, 4, 5, 146946) I was silent over your letter because I wanted to have a talk with Kanu, which I had at length yesterday.
('69', 81, 4, 6, 147052) He does not wish to be away for the present at any rate.
('69', 81, 4, 7, 147109) He particularly wishes to acquire from me whatever he can just by remaining by my side although he no doubt wants to learn a good deal of music from Panditji 1. Hence, I have assured him that he may rely without fear on my promise that I would gladly let him go any time he thinks he has had enough of me or wants to go to Panditji or anywhere else and obtain some special knowledge.
('69', 81, 4, 8, 147493) I think this is enough for the present.
('69', 81, 4, 9, 147533) Of course I shall be watching him.
('69', 81, 4, 10, 147568) He has a clean mind, but after all he is only an adolescent.
('69', 81, 4, 11, 147629) Some times he suffers from melancholy but it is momentary and there is no particular reason for it.
('69', 81, 4, 12, 147729) Didn’t we all at his age have a similar experience more or less?
('69', 81, 4, 13, 147794) As for the school, I am getting convinced more and more that we should start thinking in terms of closing it unless it becomes self supporting.
('69', 81, 4, 14, 147938) For, if it does not stand on its own it could be looked upon as being run to serve our needs.
('69', 81, 4, 15, 148032) We however believe that knowledge should be imparted only to the seeker.
('69', 81, 4, 16, 148105) Yes, of course we would go begging money for such students if we have any as might thirst for knowledge and yet be unable to pay their way.
('69', 81, 4, 17, 148245) If we had such seekers, they would cheerfully carry out our word and within a year fully bear their financial burden.
('69', 81, 4, 18, 148363) There are many institutions of the kind in America where immediately on admission the student begins to earn his board side by side with his studies.
('69', 81, 4, 19, 148513) You may continue this discussion in your letter if you wish.
('69', 81, 4, 20, 148574) Kanu has gone through this letter and says that I am not correct in saying that he has a great desire to learn music under Panditji.
('69', 81, 4, 21, 148707) If he is ordered to go to Ahmedabad, he would rather learn it at the Gandharva Vidyalaya under Shankarrao 2 Vyas although it cannot be said that this is what he wishes.
('69', 81, 4, 22, 148876) According to his present state of mind,
('69', 81, 5, 23, 148916) 1 Narayan Moreshwar Khare 2 ‘Shankarlal’in the source, which is obviously a slip.

('69', 84, 10, 20, 152480) 106. THE LEPROSY PROBLEM
('69', 84, 11, 21, 152505) Wardha is a Tahsil having a fair share of lepers.
('69', 84, 11, 22, 152555) Village workers often come in contact with them.
('69', 84, 11, 23, 152604) What are the workers to do?
('69', 84, 11, 24, 152632) May they freely mix with the lepers?
('69', 84, 11, 25, 152669) How may they help these unfortunate people?
('69', 84, 11, 26, 152713) Is there any cure?
('69', 84, 11, 27, 152732) These are daily questions for serious village workers.
('69', 84, 11, 28, 152787) I, therefore, approached Rev.
('69', 84, 11, 29, 152817) Donald Miller, whom I have had the pleasure of knowing for years as a great worker among lepers in the Purulia Leper Asylum and otherwise, for simple
('69', 84, 12, 30, 152967) 1 A Swiss pacifist, President of the International Voluntary Service, who had come to India for helping in the relief work in Bihar
('69', 85, 0, 1, 153099) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 85, 1, 2, 153140) directions for village workers.
('69', 85, 1, 3, 153172) He readily agreed and a series of letters to an imaginary village worker was the result.
('69', 85, 1, 4, 153261) The first letter is given below.
('69', 85, 2, 5, 153294) Harijan, 6 6 1936
('69', 85, 3, 6, 153312) 107. A FALSE ALARM
('69', 85, 4, 7, 153331) When I saw a newspaper report purporting to be a summary of what Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru had said on khadi during his recent visit to the Khadi Bhandar at Bombay, I refused to believe it.
('69', 85, 4, 8, 153519) It seemed to me to be so thoroughly contrary to what I had understood to be his considered view about khadi.
('69', 85, 4, 9, 153628) I, therefore, sent the cutting to the Pandit, 2 and the following is the reply he promptly sent me.
('69', 85, 5, 10, 153728) I attended and spoke at several dozen meetings in Bombay__I have lost count of them—and had no time to see reports.
('69', 85, 5, 11, 153844) I spoke in Hindustani of course, and reporting was no easy matter—and then condensed reports are apt to be misleading.
('69', 85, 5, 12, 153963) The report of what I said on khadi, however, was pointed out to me and was corrected the same day or the next day.
('69', 85, 5, 13, 154078) What I had said was that for many reasons—economic, political, social—khadi was an important item in our present programme and must be encouraged, but that I did not think that it could finally solve our poverty problem, especially if the present social system continued.
('69', 85, 5, 14, 154350) This system transferred the improvements and additional earnings of the peasant to the landlord.
('69', 85, 5, 15, 154447) But I pointed out that this theoretical argument did not apply today.
('69', 85, 5, 16, 154517) For this I said that although I was in favour of big industry, I believed that even with the increase of industrialization there would be considerable room for the development of cottage industries in India.
('69', 85, 5, 17, 154725) At present, of course, they were even more important from various points of view.
('69', 85, 6, 18, 154807) This position may not satisfy the ‘whole hoggers’.
('69', 85, 6, 19, 154858) But it is vastly different from the misleading report.
('69', 85, 6, 20, 154913) Such misreporting is the lot of public men, especially in India, where they have to speak in an Indian language which reporters do not always understand and which has invariably to be translated into English for the purpose of transm ission by wire.
('69', 85, 6, 21, 155163) The moral is, the public should wait for authentic
('69', 85, 7, 22, 155214) 1 Not reproduced here.
('69', 85, 7, 23, 155237) This and the other four articles of the series first appeared in Harijan and later in the form of a booklet, The Leprosy Problem.
('69', 85, 7, 24, 155367) 2 Vide, “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 21 5 1936
('69', 86, 0, 1, 155415) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 87
('69', 86, 1, 2, 155457) information before believing the so called pronouncements of leaders in important matters.
('69', 86, 1, 3, 155548) Form the letters I have received I see that the report created great uneasiness among some khadi workers.
('69', 86, 1, 4, 155654) To them I should like to give a warning.
('69', 86, 1, 5, 155695) It is fortunate that, for all practical purposes, what Pandit Jawaharlal actually says is satisfactory.
('69', 86, 1, 6, 155799) He is too noble to say anything to please anybody if he does not believe in it.
('69', 86, 1, 7, 155879) The quotation from his letter, therefore, derives added weight from the fact that the helmsman of the Congress holds views favourable to khadi, But khadi workers should know that there are many important public men outside the Congress who decry khadi and would never touch it.
('69', 86, 1, 8, 156157) They should know too that even in the Congress ranks there are some who do not believe in khadi, who are never tired of ridiculing it, and use it merely as a measure of discipline till they succeed in banishing it from the Congress programme.
('69', 86, 1, 9, 156400) Khadi has progressed in spite of these obstacles.
('69', 86, 1, 10, 156450) No doubt it would have made greater progress if we had not such opposition to contend against.
('69', 86, 1, 11, 156545) It is a matter of very great conso lation that Pandit Jawaharlal believes in khadi as he does.
('69', 86, 1, 12, 156640) But what should khadi workers do if he, on further study, finds it necessary to declare himself against it?
('69', 86, 1, 13, 156748) I hope that after sixteen years of experience of khadi and its possibilities, we have a sufficient number of confirmed believers whose faith in it is based on thier own knowledge of its working.
('69', 86, 1, 14, 156943) If it is still a derived faith, the prophecy of a great journalist will undoubtedly come true that on my death khadi will also die and that the wheels that would be broken after the natural event would be sufficient for full cremation of the body.
('69', 86, 1, 15, 157191) This nervousness over the false alarm is a portent if it is a token of weak faith of khadi workers.
('69', 86, 1, 16, 157291) I suggest to them that they examine their own position and if they have doubts about the great economic importance of khadi, let them revise their attitude.
('69', 86, 1, 17, 157448) In order to help them to carry on the examination, I propose, if at all possible, in the next issue, 1 to put my view of the importance of khadi for India from several points of view.
('69', 86, 2, 18, 157632) Harijan, 6 6 1936
('69', 86, 3, 19, 157650) 1 Vide “Is Khadi Economically Sound?”, 20 6 1936.
('69', 87, 0, 1, 157700) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 87, 1, 2, 157741) 108. INDIA IN A VILLAGE
('69', 87, 2, 3, 157765) I tender my congratulations to the Maharashtra Provincial Congress Committee on their decision to hold the next Congress Session at Khirdi, a village near Faizpur—another village in East Khandesh.
('69', 87, 2, 4, 157962) If the plans are properly laid and preparations undertaken in advance, the Reception Committee will be able to put up a brave show at a comparatively less cost than is usually incurred at these annual national gatherings.
('69', 87, 2, 5, 158184) The conditions are obvious.
('69', 87, 2, 6, 158212) The Comm ittee must not aim at reproducing a city in the village.
('69', 87, 2, 7, 158278) That would be doing violence to the whole conception.
('69', 87, 2, 8, 158332) They should aim at giving the city people who, let us hope, will gather in their thousands, such hospitality as a model village should be able to supply.
('69', 87, 2, 9, 158486) In other words, we should see in December a miniature edition of village India in Khirdi.
('69', 87, 2, 10, 158576) By wise planning the organizers will find that there is practically nothing that a model village cannot supply in the way of hygienic comforts, proper food, proper sanitation, and in case of sickness proper medical aid.
('69', 87, 2, 11, 158796) These are not to be had today in the generality of villages.
('69', 87, 2, 12, 158857) Therefore, I have used the expression ‘model village’.
('69', 87, 2, 13, 158912) A model village should lack nothing that is required for healthy living.
('69', 87, 2, 14, 158985) But everything in a village has to conform to the village scale which need never be shoddy and [has to] be, at the same time, subdued.
('69', 87, 2, 15, 159120) For lighting, I would suggest electric light, though it may be a long time before our villages are able to have electricity.
('69', 87, 2, 16, 159245) The whole show should be an object lesson both for villagers and townsfolk.
('69', 87, 2, 17, 159321) The chief attraction of the Congress will necessarily be the exhibition.
('69', 87, 2, 18, 159394) The Lucknow Exhibition was undoubtedly a success when one realizes that it was the first effort of its kind.
('69', 87, 2, 19, 159503) The coming exhibition should be a much greater success and yet, so far as I can see, need not cost as much as the Lucknow Exhibition did.
('69', 87, 2, 20, 159641) In order that it may become a success, artists, engineers and like professional men will have to volunteer their services free of charge on a larger scale than heretofore.
('69', 87, 2, 21, 159813) And they will have to approach what to me is a sacred task with the village mentality.
('69', 87, 3, 22, 159900) Harijan, 6 6 1936
('69', 88, 0, 1, 159918) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 89
('69', 88, 1, 2, 159960) 109. FOR UNCERTIFIED KHADI DEALERS
('69', 88, 2, 3, 159995) Unfortunately it has been found that owing to the increased scale of wages that are being offered to hand spinners on behalf of the A.I.S.A. and a consequent slight rise in the price of a certain style of khadi, several uncertified dealers are selling khadi as if it was certified by the A. I. S. A. and some of them do not even hesitate to defend their unpatriotic and unhumanitarian action on the ground that the A. I. S. A. is not a registered body.
('69', 88, 2, 4, 160448) 1 In order to ascertain the true legal position instead of relying on his own ancient knowledge of law, Shri Rajagopalachari referred to an eminent lawyer for opinion and this is his decisive opinion: I have no doubt that the Tirupur merchant has been wrongly advised as to the law.
('69', 88, 2, 5, 160731) The law protects unregistered bodies as much as registered bodies in this respect.
('69', 88, 2, 6, 160814) To use an unregistered name pretending to be somebody that he is not is as much a deceit of the public as it would be if the name had been registered.
('69', 88, 2, 7, 160965) Registration under a statute may have statutory consequences and protections; but in the protection of the public from deceit there is no distinction between registered and unregistered names.
('69', 88, 2, 8, 161158) It is absurd prima facie that because a name is not registered, he can assume the same name and pass off goods as certified by A. I. S. A. An action will lie for injunction and damages.
('69', 88, 2, 9, 161344) Injunction you will have.
('69', 88, 2, 10, 161370) Damages will depend on proof that persons purchased believing the stuff had been made or certified by the A. I. S. A. If formal opinion with authorities is required I shall get it drawn for you at an early date.
('69', 88, 2, 11, 161582) (Sd.) T. R. V. SASTRI Ooty, 23rd May, ‘36 The eminent lawyer is no other than the ex Advocate General of Madras, Shri T. R. Venkatarama Sastriar.
('69', 88, 2, 12, 161728) I hope that in view of this opinion those dealers who are carrying on unauthorized sales of khadi as if they were authorized by the A. I. S. A. will desist from the practice which has been described as fraudulent.
('69', 88, 2, 13, 161942) If it becomes necessary, opposed though I am to resort to law courts, I would not hesitate in the interest of poor dumb spinners to advise legal steps being taken against those who knowingly injure their poor sisters.
('69', 88, 3, 14, 162160) Harijan, 6 6 1936
('69', 88, 4, 15, 162178) 1 Vide “Uncertified Khadi”, 11 4 1936
