('69', 100, 1, 2, 178238) 129. INTERVIEW TO ADI KARNATAKA SANGH
('69', 100, 2, 3, 178276) June 10, 1936
('69', 100, 3, 4, 178290) Mahatma Gandhi stated that he was in full agreement with the view that no work for the uplift of Harijans could be carried on satisfactorily unless it had their co operation.
('69', 100, 3, 5, 178465) No one had emphasized more than he the fact that in the service that they had undertaken, to remove all social and other disabilities in the case of Harijans, they were only discharging a debt of obligation, as they had committed the sin which had doomed the persons to social and other hardships.
('69', 100, 4, 6, 178763) He pointed out that the Kengeri Gurukul did not belong to the Harijan Sevak Sangh; and that far from the Kengeri Gurukul excluding Harijans, it expressly served Harijans and took in Harijans whenever they were forthcoming.
('69', 100, 5, 7, 178986) The next important thing was that the Conference was one of savarna Hindu workers who were going to assemble in order to compare notes, discuss their difficulties, find out their own weaknesses and to organize their work better.
('69', 100, 5, 8, 179215) The Conference was one of hereditary sinners who wanted to find out ways and means of repaying the debt they owed to Harijans.
('69', 100, 5, 9, 179342) How were the Harijans going to help in this Conference?
('69', 100, 5, 10, 179398) They were certainly welcome to attend it, but how would they help in the deliberations?
('69', 100, 6, 11, 179486) D’souza: You may call yourselves debtors but the Harijans cannot help suspecting a superiority complex in all that you do, and you will lend yourselves to the suspicion that instead of devising means to help them you are devising new means to keep them down.
('69', 100, 7, 12, 179745) GANDHIJI: If there is suspicion for which there is no ground, I do not mind the suspicion.
('69', 100, 7, 13, 179836) The savarnas’action if it is honest will dispel it.
('69', 100, 7, 14, 179888) I do not blame the Harijans because they have known nothing better.
('69', 100, 8, 15, 179956) A HARIJAN: There is no suspicion.
('69', 100, 8, 16, 179990) We simply wanted to narrate our hardships.
('69', 100, 9, 17, 180033) GANDHIJI: Need you narrate them to me?
('69', 100, 9, 18, 180072) Don’t I know them?
('69', 100, 10, 19, 180091) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('69', 100, 10, 20, 180141) P.G. D’Souza, leader of the deputation, among other things pointed out that the Harijan Sevak Sangh took no account of work being done by Harijans who wanted H.S.S. Funds to be made available to them, that if Hindu opposition persisted the Missionaries were bound to accentuate their antagonism, that the Harijans were not being admitted in the Gurukul Ashram at Kengeri, that the Harijan Workers’Conference about to be held was going to be a purely non Harijan affair and that it was no use concentrating on temple entry when Harijans’economic and social conditions badly needed improvement.
('69', 101, 0, 1, 180734) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 101, 1, 2, 180776) Don’t I proclaim from the house tops that you have to rise all along the line?
('69', 101, 1, 3, 180855) No; I want you to understand that it is a conference of sincere sinners.
('69', 101, 1, 4, 180928) You are all welcome of course, but you will find that the complexion of the meeting is different from what you expect it to be.
('69', 101, 1, 5, 181056) We are all debtors; we know that we can pay nothing more than small instalments, and that our creditors may be so enraged as to fling those instalments in our faces and kick us out.
('69', 101, 1, 6, 181238) But we have to tolerate even this if such is to be our lot.
('69', 101, 1, 7, 181298) For our goal is to pay the principal with interest.
('69', 101, 1, 8, 181350) When Dr. Ambedkar abuses us, I say that it serves us right.
('69', 101, 1, 9, 181410) Then sometimes the creditor becomes so great that he does not care for the debt of the debtors.
('69', 101, 1, 10, 181506) We, however, have to forget everything else and concentrate on repaying the debt.
('69', 101, 1, 11, 181588) The Shastras say that when the cup of a people’s iniquity is full, they perish.
('69', 101, 1, 12, 181668) Hinduism is a dying cult if it will not purge itself of untouchability and will perish, Ambedkar or no Ambedkar.
('69', 101, 1, 13, 181781) If our attempt is sincere, I assume you will see no superiority complex among the reformers.
('69', 101, 1, 14, 181874) I admit that as I see Hinduism, darkness envelops many savarnas.
('69', 101, 1, 15, 181939) They call irreligion religion.
('69', 101, 1, 16, 181970) Now it is out of this darkness that a very imperfect class of sinners are trying to come out.
('69', 101, 1, 17, 182064) As regards the condition of some Harijans, I am reminding the savarnas day in and day out that it is they the savarnas who are responsible for the filthy habits of some of the Harijans.
('69', 101, 1, 18, 182250) I tell them it is wrong of them to insist on Harijans getting clean before they receive the same status as other Hindus.
('69', 101, 1, 19, 182371) We have to admit them first and then make them clean.
('69', 101, 1, 20, 182425) As regards your disabilities, housing conditions, etc., I am pleading with the State.
('69', 101, 1, 21, 182511) Pray be patient.
('69', 101, 1, 22, 182528) We may not be able to deliver the goods as quickly as you want us to, but do not question our motives.
('69', 101, 2, 23, 182631) D’SOUZA: We thank you for having given us the assurance you have given.
('69', 101, 2, 24, 182703) We want you to extend to the Harijans the hand of fellowship.
('69', 101, 2, 25, 182765) A sinner should not behave as though in expressing penitence he was doing some service to God.
('69', 101, 2, 26, 182860) I want you to get the Harijans direct representation in the Mysore Assembly in proportion to their population.
('69', 101, 2, 27, 182971) They should be recognized as having attained manhood.
('69', 101, 3, 28, 183025) GANDHIJI: For that I must make a suggestion to you.
('69', 101, 3, 29, 183077) You must displace the present Maharajah and have me as such for a week !
('69', 101, 4, 30, 183150) Harijan, 27 6 1936, and The Hindu, 11 6 1936
('69', 102, 0, 1, 183195) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 103
('69', 102, 1, 2, 183238) 130. SPEECH AT HARIJAN WORKERS’ CONFERENCE, KENGERI 1
('69', 102, 2, 3, 183292) June 10, 1936 2
('69', 102, 3, 4, 183308) Whoever conceived the idea of this Conference gave vent to a happy idea and we should be able to make good use of this meeting.
('69', 102, 3, 5, 183436) Though there are at this Conference representatives invited from all parts of South India, there are others here, too, and instead of confining myself only to the actual work of the delegates, I will make some general observations.
('69', 102, 3, 6, 183668) These general observations I shall make for the benefit of the savarna Hindus.
('69', 102, 3, 7, 183747) Let them understand that this movement for the removal of untouchability is different from other current movements in India.
('69', 102, 3, 8, 183872) So far as I am concerned, and so far as the Harijan Sevak Sangh is concerned, the anti untouchability movement is not a political movement.
('69', 102, 3, 9, 184012) Nor is it intended purely for the economic amelioration of the Harijans nor yet for their social regeneration.
('69', 102, 3, 10, 184123) But this does not mean that we do not aim at the Harijans’ social, economic or political advancement.
('69', 102, 3, 11, 184225) We want all these improvements.
('69', 102, 3, 12, 184257) If we are honest about our work, progress in these directions is bound to follow from our efforts.
('69', 102, 3, 13, 184356) But our goal is quite different from the things I have mentioned just now.
('69', 102, 3, 14, 184431) It is this: that untouchability is a blot upon Hinduism and must be removed at any cost.
('69', 102, 3, 15, 184520) Untouchability is a poison which, if we do not get rid of it in time, will destroy Hinduism.
('69', 102, 3, 16, 184613) I know that those of you who are outside the ranks of workers and delegates—nay, even some of the workers and delegates—do not realize the real significance of what I am saying.
('69', 102, 3, 17, 184791) But whether you realize the significance or not, I must continue to express the views which I hold and hold very strongly.
('69', 102, 3, 18, 184914) I can see in the continuance of untouchability slow destruction overtaking Hinduism now, and I promise that if you study the thing itself as I am doing, you will observe that the slow disintegration which Hinduism is going through, may become so rapid as to make it impossible for the workers to overcome it.
('69', 102, 4, 19, 185223) 1 This was published in Harijan under the title “The Inwardness of Harijan Movement.”
('69', 102, 5, 20, 185309) 2 From The Hindu
('69', 103, 0, 1, 185326) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 103, 1, 2, 185368) And why do I say that untouchability is a curse, a blot and a powerful poison that will destroy Hinduism?
('69', 103, 1, 3, 185474) It is repugnant to our sense of humanity to consider a single human being as untouchable by birth.
('69', 103, 1, 4, 185573) If you were to examine the scriptures of the world and the conduct of peoples other than Hindus, you would not find any parallel to the untouchability I have brought to your attention just now.
('69', 103, 1, 5, 185767) I can well understand a person being untouchable whilst he is performing a task which he himself would feel makes him untouch able.
('69', 103, 1, 6, 185899) For instance, a nurse, who is nursing a patient who is helpless and bleeding and soiling his clothes and suffering from a disease giving out from his body a foul smell, such a nurse whilst she is nursing such a patient is untouchable.
('69', 103, 1, 7, 186134) But when she has washed herself, she becomes as touchable as ourselves.
('69', 103, 1, 8, 186206) Not only that.
('69', 103, 1, 9, 186221) She is not only just as fit to move in society as any of us, but she is also adorable for the profession which she follows.
('69', 103, 1, 10, 186345) She is worthy of our respect and, so long as we have ranks in our society, she must occupy a very high place amongst us.
('69', 103, 1, 11, 186466) Now look at the other side of the picture.
('69', 103, 1, 12, 186509) Take, for instance, Dr. Ambedkar.
('69', 103, 1, 13, 186543) He is pronounced as belonging to the Depressed Classes and as being untouchable.
('69', 103, 1, 14, 186624) Intellectually he is superior to thousands of intelligent and educated caste Hindus.
('69', 103, 1, 15, 186709) His personal cleanliness is as high as that of any of us.
('69', 103, 1, 16, 186767) Today he is an eminent lecturer in Law.
('69', 103, 1, 17, 186807) Tomorrow you may find him a Judge of the High Court.
('69', 103, 1, 18, 186860) In other words, there is no position in the Government of this country to which he may not aspire and rise, and to which an orthodox Brahmin can rise.
('69', 103, 1, 19, 187011) But that orthodox Brahmin will be defiled by the touch of Dr. Ambedkar and that because of his unpardonable sin that he was born a Mahar (Untouchable)!
('69', 103, 1, 20, 187163) If we had not been habituated to think that untouchability by birth is an integral part of Hinduism, we would not conduct ourselves towards our fellow human beings as many of us conduct ourselves even today.
('69', 103, 1, 21, 187371) I know that I have told you nothing new in this my talk to you today.
('69', 103, 1, 22, 187441) I know I have said this same thing in a much more burning language than I have done today.
('69', 103, 1, 23, 187532) Yet what I say is not, and will not be, superfluous so long as this simple fact of the need for the removal of untouchability does not affect your understanding or conduct.
('69', 103, 1, 24, 187705) Untouchability is a phenomenon which is peculiar to Hinduism only and it has got no warrant either in reason or in the Shastras, and
('69', 104, 0, 1, 187838) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 105
('69', 104, 1, 2, 187881) what little I have studied of the Shastras and what I have been told by people who have made a deeper study of them shows that there is no warrant for untouchability by birth in Hinduism.
('69', 104, 1, 3, 188069) I have not the time now to go into the Shastric precepts.
('69', 104, 1, 4, 188127) Nor is it necessary at this time of the day to give you Shastric proofs for my statement.
('69', 104, 1, 5, 188217) But what is necessary is that if you are satisfied that untouchability is a blot on Hinduism and that there is a danger of its destroying Hinduism, you must set about removing it.
('69', 104, 1, 6, 188397) What will you do to remove it?
('69', 104, 1, 7, 188428) If all of you will say that you have done your duty by declaring that untouchability is a blot on Hinduism, it will be a mockery.
('69', 104, 1, 8, 188558) It will not be enough even if you in a flush of enthusiasm go to a Harijan and touch him and embrace him, and then forget all about him.
('69', 104, 1, 9, 188695) It will not do even if you go to the Harijan quarters every day and make it a point to touch a number of Harijans as a token of your conviction.
('69', 104, 1, 10, 188840) What is required of you is that you should regulate your day to day conduct in such a manner that you make it absolutely evident to the Harijans whom you come across that a better day has dawned for them all.

('69', 111, 1, 4, 203803) I therefore say we must not visit the temples that forbid the entry of Harijans, and after we have finished with the members of our families we should go out with the same advice to others.
('69', 111, 2, 5, 203993) Q. Is the Harijan Sevak Sangh entitled to fight caste as we know it, since untouchability cannot go without the present caste going?
('69', 111, 3, 6, 204126) A. Untouchability has to go in its entirety, but so far as the Sangh as a body is concerned we have confined its work to the removal of the extreme form of untouchability.
('69', 111, 3, 7, 204298) Therefore we do not begin with an attack on caste, though most of the members individually do not believe in and have discarded from their lives all caste restrictions about food and marriage.
('69', 111, 4, 8, 204491) Q. Shall we ever at some stage have to attack caste?
('69', 111, 5, 9, 204544) A. Why not?
('69', 111, 5, 10, 204556) We recognize our limits and have thus restricted the rate of our progress.

('69', 111, 5, 14, 204881) Both of them are individual matters.

('69', 111, 6, 19, 205438) In some places these had incurred the wrath of the savarna Hindus who had declared a boycott against them and stopped all social amenities.

('69', 113, 1, 3, 208667) Dr. Ambedkar who is economically much better off than most of us is still regarded as an untouchable.
('69', 113, 2, 4, 208769) Q. A worker, apparently an iconoclast, seemed to be impatient of some of the forms of worship among Harijans including even their worship of Rama and Krishna— and naively said: “I know that they worship sticks and stones, even when they say they worship Rama and Krishna.

('69', 113, 4, 8, 209252) A. There is this difficulty staring me in the face: I am, you must know, an idol of mud, and those who seem to you to be revolting as ideals are my revered ideals.

('69', 122, 1, 9, 229991) I say this from my experience of different provinces.

('69', 122, 1, 11, 230082) Even when I was in South Africa, I thought that all the languages derived from Sanskrit should have Devanagari script, and I am sure that even the Dravidian languages could be easily learnt through the Devanagari script.
('69', 122, 1, 12, 230303) I have tried to learn Tamil and Telugu through the Tamil and Telugu scripts, as also Kannada and Malayalam, for a few days, through their respective scripts.
('69', 122, 1, 13, 230461) I tell you I was frightfully upset over having to learn four scripts when I could see that if the four languages had a common script—Devanagari—I should learn them in no time.
('69', 122, 1, 14, 230637) What a terrible strain it is on those like me who are anxious to learn the four languages?
('69', 122, 1, 15, 230728) As between the speakers of the four South Indian vernaculars, does it need any argument to show that Devanagari would be the most convenient script for the speaker of one to learn the other three?
('69', 122, 1, 16, 230925) The question of Hindi as lingua franca need not be mixed up with the question of script, but I have referred to this simply in order to point out the difficulty of those who want to know all the Indian languages.
('69', 122, 2, 17, 231138) Hirijan, 27 6 1936

('69', 123, 2, 5, 232093) 142. A WITNESS FROM AMERICA
('69', 123, 3, 6, 232121) Miss Mabel E. Simpson of Montana (U. S. A.) writes to the Editor:
('69', 123, 4, 7, 232187) I wish to express my appreciation of your publication.
('69', 123, 4, 8, 232242) What it lacks in size it more than makes up in quality.
('69', 123, 4, 9, 232298) I greatly enjoyed Mr. Gandhi’s article on birth control displaying his usual clear insight into the heart of things.
('69', 123, 4, 10, 232415) If he had visited America twenty years ago when birth control was disapproved and now when it is in full swing, he would know that it brings moral deterioration.
('69', 123, 4, 11, 232577) But he would not be able to convince anybody of it, for it also brings a blindness to both moral and spiritual perception that makes it impossible for its followers to discern with sensitivity along high moral and spiritual lines.
('69', 123, 4, 12, 232808) If India follows the West in this it will surely lose two of its most.
('69', 123, 4, 13, 232879) priceless and beautiful jewels: affection for little children and reverence for parenthood.
('69', 123, 4, 14, 232971) America has lost both—and does not know it.
('69', 123, 4, 15, 233015) Could you print a statement of the meaning of brahmacharya?
('69', 123, 4, 16, 233075) I have been asked about it and while I have an idea I am not sure enough to attempt to explain it to others.
('69', 123, 4, 17, 233184) Thank you.
('69', 123, 4, 18, 233195) The reader may place what value he or she chooses on this piece of evidence.
('69', 123, 4, 19, 233272) I suggest however that such evidence against the use of contraceptives is worth far more than that of those who claim to derive benefit from their use.
('69', 123, 4, 20, 233424) The reason is obvious.
('69', 123, 4, 21, 233447) The benefit in the sense that advent of children is often checked is not denied.
('69', 123, 4, 22, 233528) What is contended is that the moral harm the use does is incalculable.
('69', 123, 4, 23, 233599) Miss Simpson has given us a measure of such harm.
('69', 123, 4, 24, 233649) Now for the definition—the meaning—of brahmacharya.
('69', 123, 4, 25, 233701) Its root meaning may be given thus: that conduct which puts one in touch with God.
('69', 123, 4, 26, 233784) The conduct consists in the fullest control over all the senses.
('69', 123, 4, 27, 233849) This is the true and relevant meaning of the word.
('69', 124, 0, 1, 233900) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 125
('69', 124, 1, 2, 233944) Popularly it has come to mean mere physical control over the organ of generation.
('69', 124, 1, 3, 234026) This narrow meaning has debased brahmach arya and made its practice all but impossible.
('69', 124, 1, 4, 234114) Control over the organ of generation is impossible without proper control over all the senses.
('69', 124, 1, 5, 234209) They are all interdependent.
('69', 124, 1, 6, 234238) Mind on the lower plane is included in the senses.
('69', 124, 1, 7, 234289) Without control over the mind mere physical control, even if it can be attained for a time, is of little or no use.
('69', 124, 2, 8, 234405) Harijan, 13 6 1936
('69', 124, 3, 9, 234424) 143.WHERE IS THE LIVING GOD?
('69', 124, 4, 10, 234453) The following is taken from a letter form Bengal.
('69', 124, 5, 11, 234503) I had the privilege to go through your article 2 on birth control with the heading ‘A Youth’s Difficulty’.
('69', 124, 6, 12, 234610) With the original theme of your article, I am in full agreement.
('69', 124, 6, 13, 234675) But, in that article, you have expressed in a line your sentiment on God.
('69', 124, 6, 14, 234749) You have said that it is the fashion nowadays for young men to discard the idea of God and they have no living faith in a living God.
('69', 124, 7, 15, 234883) But, may I ask what proof (which must be positive and undisputed) can you put forth regarding the existence of a God?
('69', 124, 7, 16, 235001) Hindu philosophers or ancient rishis 3, it seems to me, in their attempt to describs the swarupa or reality of Ishwara have at last come to the conclusion that He is indescribable and veiled in maya and so on....
('69', 124, 7, 17, 235214) I do not dare to deny that a true Mahatma like you or Sri Aurobindo, or the Buddha and Sankaracharyas of the past, may well conceive and realize the existence of such a God, who is far beyond the reach of ordinary human intellect.
('69', 124, 8, 18, 235445) But, what have we (the general mass), whose coarse intellect can never penetrate into the unfathomable deep, to do with such a God if we do not feel His presence in our midst?...
('69', 124, 9, 19, 235624) So, it is not at all surprising that young men of the present day do not believe in a God, because they do not want to make a supposition of God— they want a real living God.
('69', 124, 9, 20, 235799) You have mentioned in your article of a living faith in a living God.
('69', 124, 9, 21, 235869) I shall feel highly gratified and I think you will be rendering a great benefit to the young world, if you put forth some positive, undeniable proofs of the existence of God.
('69', 124, 9, 22, 236044) I have the confidence that you will
('69', 124, 10, 23, 236080) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('69', 124, 10, 24, 236117) 2 Vide “A Youth’s Difficulty”, 25 4 1936 3 Seers
('69', 125, 0, 1, 236166) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 125, 1, 2, 236208) not more mystify the already mystified problem, and will throw some definite light on the matter.
('69', 125, 1, 3, 236306) I very much fear that what I am about to write will not remove the mist to which the correspondent alludes.
('69', 125, 1, 4, 236414) The writer supposes that I might have realized the existence of a living God.
('69', 125, 1, 5, 236492) I can lay no such claim.
('69', 125, 1, 6, 236517) But I do have a living faith in a living God even as I have a living faith in many things that scientists tell me.
('69', 125, 1, 7, 236632) It may be retorted that what the scientists say can be verified if one followed the prescription given for realizing the facts which are taken for granted.
('69', 125, 1, 8, 236788) Precisely in that manner speak the rishis and the prophets.
('69', 125, 1, 9, 236848) They say, anybody following the path they have trodden can realize God.
('69', 125, 1, 10, 236920) The fact is we do not want to follow the path leading to realization and we won’t take the testimony of eye witnesses about the one thing that really matters.
('69', 125, 1, 11, 237079) Not all the achievements of physical sciences put together can compare with that which gives us a living faith in God.
('69', 125, 1, 12, 237198) Those who do not want to believe in the existence of God do not believe in the existence of anything apart from the body.
('69', 125, 1, 13, 237320) Such a belief is held to be unnecessary for the progress of humanity.
('69', 125, 1, 14, 237390) For such persons the weightiest argument in proof of the existence of soul or God is of no avail.
('69', 125, 1, 15, 237488) You cannot make a person who has stuffed his ears, listen to, much less appreciate, the finest music.
('69', 125, 1, 16, 237590) Even so can you not convince those about the existence of a living God who do not want the conviction.
('69', 125, 1, 17, 237693) Fortunately the vast majority of people do have a living faith in a living God.
('69', 125, 1, 18, 237773) They cannot, will not, argue about it.
('69', 125, 1, 19, 237812) For them “it is”.
('69', 125, 1, 20, 237830) Are all the scriptures of the world old women’s tales of superstition?
('69', 125, 1, 21, 237901) Is the testimony of the rishis, the prophets, to be rejected?
('69', 125, 1, 22, 237963) Is the testimony of Chaitanya, Ramakrishna Paramahamsa, Tukaram, Dnyandeva, Ramdas, Nanak, Kabir, Tulsidas of no value?
('69', 125, 1, 23, 238083) What about Ramamohan Roy, Devendranath Tagore, Vivekananda— all modern men as well educated as the tallest among the living ones?
('69', 125, 1, 24, 238213) I omit the living witnesses whose evidence would be considered unimpeachable.
('69', 125, 1, 25, 238291) This belief in God has to be based on faith which transcends reason.
('69', 125, 1, 26, 238360) Indeed even the so called realization has at bottom an element of faith without which it cannot be sustained.
('69', 125, 1, 27, 238470) In the very nature of things it must be so.
('69', 125, 1, 28, 238514) Who can transgress the limitations of his being?
('69', 125, 1, 29, 238563) I hold that complete realization is impossible in this embodied life.
('69', 125, 1, 30, 238633) Nor is it necessary.
('69', 125, 1, 31, 238654) A living immovable faith is all that is required for reaching the full spiritual height attainable by human
('69', 126, 0, 1, 238762) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 127
('69', 126, 1, 2, 238806) beings.
('69', 126, 1, 3, 238814) God is not outside this earthly case of ours.
('69', 126, 1, 4, 238860) Therefore exterior proof is not of much avail, if any at all.
('69', 126, 1, 5, 238922) We must ever fail to perceive.
('69', 126, 1, 6, 238953) Him through the senses, because He is beyond them.
('69', 126, 1, 7, 239004) We can feel Him, if we will but withdraw ourselves from the senses.
('69', 126, 1, 8, 239072) The divine music is incessantly going on within ourselves, but the loud senses drown the delicate music which is unlike and infinitely superior to anything we can perceive or hear with our senses.
('69', 126, 1, 9, 239269) The writer wants to know why, if God is a ‘God of mercy and justice, He allows all the miseries and sorrows we see around us.
('69', 126, 1, 10, 239395) I can give no satisfactory explanation.
('69', 126, 1, 11, 239435) He imputes to me a sense of defeat and humiliation.
('69', 126, 1, 12, 239487) I have no such sense of defeat, humiliation or despair.
('69', 126, 1, 13, 239543) My retirement, such as it is, has nothing to do with any defeat.
('69', 126, 1, 14, 239608) It is no more and no less than a course of self purification and self preparation.
('69', 126, 1, 15, 239691) I state this to show that things are often not what they seem.
('69', 126, 1, 16, 239754) It may be that what we mistake as sorrows, injustices and the like are not such in truth.
('69', 126, 1, 17, 239844) If we could solve all the mysteries of the universe, we would be co equals with God.
('69', 126, 1, 18, 239929) Every drop of the ocean shares its glory but is not the ocean.
('69', 126, 1, 19, 239992) Realizing our littleness during this tiny span of life, we close every morning prayer with the recitation of a verse which means: “Misery so called is no misery nor riches so called riches.
('69', 126, 1, 20, 240182) Forgetting (or denying) God is the true misery, remembering (or faith in) God is true riches.”
('69', 126, 2, 21, 240277) Harijan, 13 6 1936

('69', 131, 6, 24, 248004) 152. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('69', 131, 7, 25, 248035) June 15, 1936
('69', 131, 8, 26, 248049) NARANDAS, Here are some of my thoughts.
('69', 131, 8, 27, 248089) We should not run the school from a rich man’s viewpoint, but have as teachers only those whose motto is service.
('69', 131, 8, 28, 248203) They should be satisfied with a maximum salary of Rs. 15 a month and devote their whole time to it.
('69', 131, 8, 29, 248303) To start with, there should be one teacher for just one pupil of whatever age.
('69', 131, 8, 30, 248382) The teacher should prepare his own textbook and impart knowledge through the use of the eyes and the ears and teach the pupil to use his hands for wielding implements to make things.
('69', 131, 8, 31, 248565) He should himself do what he teaches.
('69', 131, 8, 32, 248603) It would be better to have such a school in some village.
('69', 132, 0, 1, 248661) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 133
('69', 132, 1, 2, 248705) for you, you have to make the beginning at the place where you are.
('69', 132, 1, 3, 248773) You can start with yourself.
('69', 132, 1, 4, 248802) Accept pupils from middleclass families if they agree to your terms.
('69', 132, 1, 5, 248871) They must pay fees, but one should not depend on this income while undertaking the work.
('69', 132, 1, 6, 248960) You may start the experiment only if you accept the idea whole heartedly.
('69', 132, 1, 7, 249034) You should swallow only what you can digest.
('69', 132, 1, 8, 249079) If you understand this, this is what you should do for the present.
('69', 132, 1, 9, 249147) Put the thoughts before your associates.
('69', 132, 1, 10, 249188) It is our dharma to run the existing school if it pays its way but those parents who can should pay the full fees.
('69', 132, 1, 11, 249303) I have put all these ideas before Nanabhai 1. He likes them but he is himself so deeply involved that the changes suggested by me are beyond his power.
('69', 132, 1, 12, 249455) The help I used to get for Dakshinamurti has now stopped.
('69', 132, 1, 13, 249513) You may ask me time and again whatever you want to.
('69', 132, 1, 14, 249565) Kanu is my responsibility.
('69', 132, 1, 15, 249592) He will be under my supervision whether at Segaon or at Maganwadi.
('69', 132, 1, 16, 249659) He has my permission to live at Segaon.
('69', 132, 1, 17, 249699) Hence if he continues to stay at Maganwadi, it will have been his own decision.
('69', 132, 1, 18, 249779) Now that Kanti has gone to stay with Kaka to attend on him, Mahadev will be left alone.
('69', 132, 1, 19, 249867) If, on that account, Kanu is required to be with Mahadev, that too will be left to his choice.

('69', 141, 3, 5, 262206) 168. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('69', 141, 4, 6, 262238) June 19, 1936
('69', 141, 5, 7, 262252) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, I was about to send you the enclosed 1 for your information when I got your letter yesterday.
('69', 141, 5, 8, 262366) I am glad Ranjit is better.
('69', 141, 5, 9, 262394) He must take care of himself.
('69', 141, 5, 10, 262424) I do not want you to issue any special statement about the omission of [a] woman from your cabinet.
('69', 141, 5, 11, 262524) 2 I think that this omission does not stand on the same footing as the inclusion or exclusion of others.
('69', 141, 5, 12, 262629) None of us had either the courage or the wish to exclude [a] woman altogether from the W. C. If this is the correct interpretation of your attitude, it should be made clear if the occassion offers itself.
('69', 141, 5, 13, 262834) As to the others I am sorry you feel still sore about what happe ned.
('69', 141, 5, 14, 262904) You swallowed the Bhulabhai pill in the interest of the cause.
('69', 141, 5, 15, 262967) And surely at the very first discussion I had said before you had mentioned the thing that there must be Socialists in the cabinet.
('69', 141, 5, 16, 263099) I mentioned also the names.
('69', 141, 5, 17, 263127) What however I want to emphasize is not who mentioned whom but that all were actuated by no other motive than that of serving the common cause.

('69', 144, 4, 14, 267375) 173. G. O. M. OF GUJARAT
('69', 144, 5, 15, 267400) It was in 1915 I first met Shri Abbas Tyabji.
('69', 144, 5, 16, 267446) Wherever I have gone and there has been a Tyabji, he or she has made it a point to come to me as if I was a member of that great and numerous family.
('69', 144, 5, 17, 267596) I do not know what the binding tie specially was, except perhaps that the distinguished judge to whom the family owe their fame had befriended me in 1890 1 when I had come to India from South Africa as an utterly unknown man, possibly an adventurer as some had thought.
('69', 144, 5, 18, 267866) Not so however thought Badruddin Tyabji and several others I can name.
('69', 144, 5, 19, 267937) But I must come back to Abbas Mian of Baroda.
('69', 144, 5, 20, 267983) As we embraced each other and I looked into his face, it reminded me of the late Justice Badruddin.
('69', 144, 5, 21, 268083) That meeting laid the foundation of a life long friendship.
('69', 144, 5, 22, 268143) I found in him not merely a friend of Harijans, he was himself one.
('69', 144, 5, 23, 268211) When at Godhra 2 long ago I had, to the surprise of my audience, invited them to have an anti untouchability conference in the evening at the untouchable quarters, Abbas Mian was there taking as lively an interest in the Harijans as any staunch Hindu.
('69', 144, 5, 24, 268463) Yet he was no ordinary Mussalman.
('69', 144, 5, 25, 268497) He had given lavishly to the cause of Islam and was supporting several Islamic institutions.
('69', 144, 5, 26, 268590) And yet he had never any designs upon Harijans.
('69', 144, 5, 27, 268638) His Islam had room for all the great religions of the earth.
('69', 144, 5, 28, 268699) Hence he looked at the anti untouchability campaign with the fervour of a Hindu.
('69', 144, 5, 29, 268780) And I know that he retained
('69', 144, 6, 30, 268808) 1 Actually 1896; vide “Letter to Jamnalal Bajaj”, 5 5 1936 2 In November 1917.
('69', 145, 0, 1, 268887) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 145, 1, 2, 268929) that fervour to the end of his time on this earth.
('69', 145, 1, 3, 268980) The fact is he never took up anything half heartedly.
('69', 145, 1, 4, 269034) There were no mental reservations about Abbas Tyabji.
('69', 145, 1, 5, 269088) At a moment’s notice he answered the call of the Punjab.
('69', 145, 1, 6, 269145) 1 At his age and for one who had never known hardships of life it was no joke to suffer imprisonments.
('69', 145, 1, 7, 269248) But his faith conquered every obstacle.
('69', 145, 1, 8, 269288) He put to shame many a young man by his ability to live with an infectious smile the simple life of the Kheda peasant, to share their simple food, travel in all seasons in their rude carts.
('69', 145, 1, 9, 269478) I have never known him complain about inconveniences which could have been avoided.
('69', 145, 1, 10, 269562) “His was not to reason why, his was to do and die.” He who had once the power as Chief Judge of imposing the death penalty and exacting obedience showed an amazing capacity for submitting unquestion ingly to discipline.
('69', 145, 1, 11, 269782) He was a rare servant of humanity.
('69', 145, 1, 12, 269817) He was a servant of India because he was a servant of humanity.
('69', 145, 1, 13, 269881) He believed in God as Daridranarayana.
('69', 145, 1, 14, 269920) He believed that God was to be found in the humblest cottages and among the despised of the earth.
('69', 145, 1, 15, 270019) Abbas Mian is not dead, though his body rests in the grave.
('69', 145, 1, 16, 270079) His life is an inspiration for us all.

('69', 145, 3, 18, 270137) 174. IS KHADI ECONOMICALLY SOUND?
('69', 145, 4, 19, 270171) If by the question is meant whether khadi can compete with Japanese ‘fent’or even with the cloth manufactured by the Indian Mills in price, the answer must be emphatically ‘no’.
('69', 145, 4, 20, 270349) But the negative answer would have to be given about almost everything turned out by man power as against labour saving power.
('69', 145, 4, 21, 270476) It would have to be so even with regard to goods manufactured in Indian factories.
('69', 145, 4, 22, 270559) Cloth, iron, sugar made in factories require State aid in some form or other to withstand foreign competition.
('69', 145, 4, 23, 270670) It is wrong to put the question in that way at all.
('69', 145, 4, 24, 270722) In the open market a more organized industry will always be able to drive out a less organized one, much more so when the former is assisted by bounties and can command unlimited capital and can therefore afford to sell its manufactures at a temporary loss.
('69', 145, 5, 25, 270980) 1 Abbas Tyabji was one of the five Commissioners appointed by the Congress Sub committee to study the evidence and prepare a report on the Punjab disorders in April 1919.
('69', 146, 0, 1, 271151) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 147
('69', 146, 1, 2, 271195) Such has been the tragic fate of many enterprises in this country.
('69', 146, 1, 3, 271262) Any country that exposes itself to unlimited foreign competition can be reduced to starvation and therefore subjection if the foreigners desire it.
('69', 146, 1, 4, 271410) This is known as peaceful penetration.
('69', 146, 1, 5, 271449) One has to go only a step further to understand that the result would be the same as between hand made goods and those made by power driven machinery.
('69', 146, 1, 6, 271600) We are seeing the process going on before our eyes.
('69', 146, 1, 7, 271652) Little flour mills are ousting the chakkis, oil mills the village ghani, rice mills the village dhenki, sugar mills the village gur pans, etc.
('69', 146, 1, 8, 271795) This displacement of village labour is impoverishing the villagers and enriching the monied men.
('69', 146, 1, 9, 271892) If the process continues sufficiently long the villages will be destroyed without any further effort.
('69', 146, 1, 10, 271994) No Chengis Khan could devise a more ingenious or more profitable method of destroying these villages.
('69', 146, 1, 11, 272096) And the tragedy of it all is that the villagers are uncons ciously but none the less surely contributing to their own destruction.
('69', 146, 1, 12, 272227) To complete the tale of their woe let the reader know that even cultivation has ceased to be profitable.
('69', 146, 1, 13, 272332) For some crops the villager does not cover even the cost of seed.
('69', 146, 1, 14, 272398) With all these deadly admissions, what do I mean by saying that khadi is the only true economic proposition?
('69', 146, 1, 15, 272507) Let me then state the proposition fully: “Khadi is the only true economic proposition in terms of the millions of villagers until such time, if ever, when a better system of supplying work and adequate wages for every able bodied person above the age of sixteen, male or female, is found for his field, cottage or even factory in every one of the villages of India; or till sufficient cities are built up to displace the villages so as to give the villagers the necessary comforts and amenities that a well regulated life demands and is entitled to.” I have only to state the proposition thus fully to show that khadi must hold the field for any length of time that we can think of.
('69', 146, 1, 16, 273190) The present pressing problem is how to find work and wages for the millions of villagers who are becoming increasingly pauperized, as anyone who will take the trouble of going to the villages can testify for himself and as is amply proved by contemporary expert evidence that people are becoming poorer economically, mentally and morally.
('69', 146, 1, 17, 273529) They are fast losing the will to work, to think and even to live.
('69', 146, 1, 18, 273595) It is a living death that they are living.
('69', 147, 0, 1, 273638) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 147, 1, 2, 273680) Khadi supplies them with work, tools and a ready market for their manufactures.
('69', 147, 1, 3, 273760) It gives them hope where but yesterday there was blank despair.
('69', 147, 1, 4, 273824) “Then why has khadi made so little progress if it is such a hopeful proposition?”—the sceptic asks.
('69', 147, 1, 5, 273924) The answer is the progress khadi has made in terms of the millions, though little in itself, is comparatively the largest of all the other single industries.
('69', 147, 1, 6, 274082) It distributes yearly the largest amount as wages among the largest number of wage earners in the villages with the minimum of over head charges and every pice practically circulates among the people.
('69', 147, 1, 7, 274283) This can be verified by anyone who would study the figures published by the A.I.S.A. Khadi has to work against almost settled prejudices among the villagers, against unscrupulous competition without State protection, and against the prevalent opinion of so called experts in the science of economics, against even the demand of khadi wearers for progressively cheaper khadi.
('69', 147, 1, 8, 274658) It is thus largely a question of the education of the villagers and the city dwellers in the true economics for this land of tears.
('69', 147, 1, 9, 274790) These transcend all religions.
('69', 147, 1, 10, 274821) Hindus, Mussal mans and Christians who live in the villages suffer from the same disease of poverty and want.
('69', 147, 1, 11, 274931) If there is a difference it is only one of degree.
('69', 147, 1, 12, 274982) I therefore maintain that though yard per yard khadi may be dearer than mill made cloth, in its totality and in terms of the villagers it is the most economic, practical proposition without a rival.
('69', 147, 1, 13, 275181) Khadi may be interpreted to include other village industries for the purposes of a thorough examination of the proposition.
('69', 147, 2, 14, 275305) Harijan, 20 6 1936

('69', 158, 9, 16, 289586) 195. DISCUSSION WITH PIERRE CERESOLE AND CHRISTIAN MISSIONARIES 1
('69', 158, 10, 17, 289652) [ About June 23, 1936] 2
('69', 158, 11, 18, 289677) [PIERRE CERESOLE]: Religion which should bind us divides us.
('69', 158, 11, 19, 289738) Is it not a sorry spectacle that whilst people of various denominations find no diffculty in working together all day in hearty co operation, they must disband when the time for prayer comes?
('69', 158, 11, 20, 289930) Is religion then meant to divide us?
('69', 158, 12, 21, 289967) Must it be allowed to become an expression of conceit rather than of a desire to be of service?
('69', 158, 12, 22, 290063) I want some sort of religious communion between men of different faiths.
('69', 158, 12, 23, 290136) [GANDHI]: Quite possible, if there is no mental reservation.
('69', 158, 13, 24, 290197) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekely Letter”.
('69', 158, 13, 25, 290248) Pierre Ceresole, founder of Service Civil International—a moral equivalent for war—met.
('69', 158, 13, 26, 290336) Gandhiji at Segaon with two other missionary women.
('69', 158, 13, 27, 290388) 2 Ceresole arrived in Wardha presumably on 23 6 1936; vide the preceding item.
('69', 159, 0, 1, 290467) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 159, 1, 2, 290509) [P.C.] But a friend of mine, a great humanitarian worker, believes that but for evangelism he should not have taken up his mission work.
('69', 159, 1, 3, 290646) He gets the driving power from communion with Jesus, he says, because Jesus was always in communion with God.
('69', 159, 1, 4, 290756) [G.] The greatest trouble with us is not that a Christian missionary should rely on his own experience, but that he should dispute the evidence of a Hindu devotee’s life.
('69', 159, 1, 5, 290927) Just as he has his spiritual experience and the joy of communion, even so has a Hindu.
('69', 159, 2, 6, 291014) Dr. Ceresole seemed to have no doubt about this, and he said that the broadest view of Christianity seemed to him to have been presented by Frank Lenwood; whose book Jesus—Lord or Leader, deserved to be better known than it is.
('69', 159, 2, 7, 291242) “He says he has the greatest respect for the personality of Jesus, but he thought he might respectfully criticize him.”
('69', 159, 3, 8, 291362) [MISSIONARY LADY]: I have not had the time or desire to evangelize.
('69', 159, 3, 9, 291430) The Church at home would be happy if through our hospital more people would be led to Christian lives.
('69', 159, 3, 10, 291533) [G.] But whilst you give the medical help you expect the reward in the shape of your patients becoming Christians.
('69', 159, 4, 11, 291648) [M.L.] Yes, the reward is expected.
('69', 159, 4, 12, 291684) Otherwise there are many other places in the world which need our service.
('69', 159, 4, 13, 291759) But instead of going there, we come here.
('69', 159, 4, 14, 291801) [G.] There is the kink.
('69', 159, 4, 15, 291825) At the back of your mind there is not pure service for its sake, but the result of service in this shape of many people coming to the Christian fold.
('69', 159, 5, 16, 291975) [M.L.] In my own work there is no ulterior motive.
('69', 159, 5, 17, 292026) I care for people, I alleviate pain, because I cannot do otherwise, The source of this is my loyalty to Jesus who ministered to suffering humanity.
('69', 159, 5, 18, 292174) At the back of my mind there is, I admit, the desire that people may find the same joy in Jesus that I find.
('69', 159, 5, 19, 292283) Where is the kink?
('69', 159, 5, 20, 292302) [G.] The kink is in the Church thinking that there are people in whom certain things are lacking and that you must supply them whether they want them or not.
('69', 159, 5, 21, 292460) If you simply say to your patients, ‘You have taken the medicine I gave you.
('69', 159, 5, 22, 292537) Thank God, He has healed you.
('69', 159, 5, 23, 292567) Don’t come again,’ you have done your duty: But if you also say, ‘How nice it would be if you had the same faith in Christianity as I have,’ you do not make of your medicine a free gift.
('69', 159, 6, 24, 292754) [M.L.] But if I feel that I have something medically and spiritually which I can give, how can I keep it?
('69', 159, 6, 25, 292860) [G.] There is a way out of the difficulty.
('69', 159, 6, 26, 292903) You must feel that what you possess your patient also can possess but through a different
('69', 160, 0, 1, 292993) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 161
('69', 160, 1, 2, 293037) You will say to yourself, ‘I have come through this route, you may come through a different route.’ Why should you want him to pass through your university and no other?
('69', 160, 2, 3, 293207) [M.L.] Because I have my partiality for my Alma Mater.
('69', 160, 2, 4, 293262) [G.] There is my difficulty.
('69', 160, 2, 5, 293291) Becuase you adore your mother, you cannot wish that all the rest were your mother’s children.
('69', 160, 3, 6, 293385) [M.L.] That is a physical impossibility.
('69', 160, 3, 7, 293426) [G.] Then this one is a spiritual impossibility.
('69', 160, 3, 8, 293475) God has the whole humanity as His children.
('69', 160, 3, 9, 293519) How can I limit God’s grace by my little mind and say this is the only way?
('69', 160, 4, 10, 293595) [M.L.] I do not say it is the only way.
('69', 160, 4, 11, 293635) There might be a better way.
('69', 160, 4, 12, 293664) [G.] If you concede that there might be a better way, you have surrendered your point.
('69', 160, 5, 13, 293751) [M.L.] Well, if you say that you have found your way, I am not so terrifically concerned with you.
('69', 160, 5, 14, 293850) I will deal with one who is floundering in mud.
('69', 160, 5, 15, 293898) [G.] Will you judge him?
('69', 160, 5, 16, 293923) Have you people not floundered?
('69', 160, 5, 17, 293955) Why will you present your particular brand of truth to all?
('69', 160, 6, 18, 294015) [M.L.] I must present to them the medicine I know.
('69', 160, 6, 19, 294066) [G.] Then you will say to him, ‘Have you seen your own doctor?
('69', 160, 6, 20, 294129) You will send him to his doctor, ask the doctor to take charge of him.
('69', 160, 6, 21, 294200) You will perhaps consult that doctor, you will discuss with him the diagnosis, and will convince him or allow yourself to be convinced by him.
('69', 160, 6, 22, 294343) But there you are dealing with a wretched physical thing.
('69', 160, 6, 23, 294401) Here we are dealing with a spiritual thing where you cannot go through all these necessary investigations.
('69', 160, 6, 24, 294508) What I plead for is humanity.
('69', 160, 6, 25, 294538) You do not claim freedom from hypocrisy for the Christian Church?
('69', 160, 7, 26, 294604) CERESOLE: Most of us believe our religion to be the best and they have not the slightest idea of what other religions have revealed to their adherents, Dr.....
('69', 160, 7, 27, 294764) 1 has made a careful study of the Hindu scriptures, and he has observed what Hinduism gives to the Hindus.
('69', 160, 7, 28, 294871) [G.] I say it is not enough for him to read the Song Celestial or the Koran.
('69', 160, 7, 29, 294948) It is necessary for him to read the Koran with Islamic spectacles and the Gita with Hindu spectacles, just as he would expect me to read the Bible with Christian spectacles.
('69', 160, 7, 30, 295122) I would ask him: ‘Have you read the Gita as reverently as I have or even as reverently as I have read the Bible?’I tell you I have not read as many books on
('69', 160, 8, 31, 295279) 1 Omission as in the source.
('69', 161, 0, 1, 295308) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 161, 1, 2, 295350) Hinduism as I have about Christianity.
('69', 161, 1, 3, 295389) And yet I did not come to the conclusion that Christianity or Hinduism was the ONLY way.
('69', 161, 2, 4, 295478) Gandhiji discussed the instance of Mr. Stokes—now Shri Satyanand—who was, in his early years in India, nearly killed for preaching Christianity to the Pathans, but who in a truly Christian spirit secured his assailant’s reprieve, and who in the later years said to himself, ‘My faith in Jesus is as bright as ever, but I cannot deliver the message of Jesus to the Hindus unless I become a Hindu.
('69', 161, 2, 5, 295874) Unless I make the Hindus better Hindus I shall not,’ he said, ‘be true to my Lord.’ 1
('69', 161, 3, 6, 295960) But then, wondered the missionary friends, what exactly should be missionaries’attitude?
('69', 161, 4, 7, 296049) [G.] I think I have made it clear.
('69', 161, 4, 8, 296084) But I shall say it again in other words: Just to forget that you have come to a country of heathens, and to think that they are as much in search of God as you are; just to feel that you are not going there to give your spiritual goods to them, but that you will share your worldly goods of which you have a good stock.
('69', 161, 4, 9, 296404) You will then do your work without a mental reservation and thereby you will share your spiritual treasures .2. The knowledge that you have this reservation creates a barrier between you and me.
('69', 161, 5, 10, 296599) [P.C.] Do you think that because of what you call that mental reservation the work that one could accomplish would suffer?
('69', 161, 6, 11, 296722) [G.] I am sure.
('69', 161, 6, 12, 296738) You would not be half as useful as you would be without the reservation.
('69', 161, 6, 13, 296811) The reservation means that you belong to a different and a higher species, and you make, yourself inaccessible to others.
('69', 161, 7, 14, 296933) [P.C.] A barrier would be certainly my Western way of living.
('69', 161, 7, 15, 296995) [G.] No, that can be immediately broken.
('69', 161, 8, 16, 297036) [P.C.] Would you be really happy if we stayed at home?
('69', 161, 9, 17, 297091) [G.] I cannot say that.
('69', 161, 9, 18, 297115) But I will certainly say that I have never been able to understand your going out of America.
('69', 161, 9, 19, 297209) Is there nothing to do there?
('69', 161, 10, 20, 297239) [P.C.] Even in America there is enough scope for educational work.
('69', 161, 10, 21, 297306) [G.] That is fatal confession.
('69', 161, 10, 22, 297337) You are not a superfluity there.
('69', 161, 10, 23, 297370) But for the curious position that your Church has taken, you would not be
('69', 161, 11, 24, 297444) 1 Satyanand Stokes’s letter clarifying his position was published in “Weekly Letter” in Harijan, 15 8 1936. 2 Italics in the source.
('69', 162, 0, 1, 297577) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 163
('69', 162, 2, 2, 297621) [P.C.] I have come because the Indian women need medical care to a greater extent than American women do.
('69', 162, 2, 3, 297727) But coupled with that I have desire to share my Christian heritage.
('69', 162, 2, 4, 297795) [G.] That is exactly the position I have been trying to counter.
('69', 162, 2, 5, 297860) You have already said that there may be a better way.
('69', 162, 3, 6, 297914) [P.C.] No, I meant to say that there may be a better way fifty years hence.
('69', 162, 3, 7, 297990) [G.] Well we were talking of the present, and you said there might be a better way.
('69', 162, 4, 8, 298074) [P.C.] No, there is no better way today than the one I am following.
('69', 162, 4, 9, 298143) That is what I say is assuming too much.
('69', 162, 4, 10, 298184) You have not examined all religious beliefs.
('69', 162, 4, 11, 298229) But even if you had, you may not claim infallibility.
('69', 162, 4, 12, 298283) You assume knowledge of all people, which you can do only if you were God.
('69', 162, 4, 13, 298358) I want you to understand that you are labouring under a double fallacy: That what you think is best for you is really so; and that what you regard as the best for you is the best for the whole world.
('69', 162, 4, 14, 298558) It is an assumption of omniscience and infallibility.
('69', 162, 4, 15, 298612) I plead for a little humility.
('69', 162, 5, 16, 298643) Harijan, 18 7 1936

('69', 165, 9, 18, 303351) If a course of injections does it, well and good.
('69', 165, 9, 19, 303401) You must find out why your well knit frame broke down.
('69', 165, 9, 20, 303456) Believe me it is impossible that the observance of these niyamas 2 can affect health; but dangerous consequences do follow from a lapse in the observance of yamas, 3 etc.
('69', 165, 9, 21, 303627) For example, the greatest lapses are to be found in the observance of brahmacharya.
('69', 165, 9, 22, 303711) It being a bodily penance, the consequences of its faulty observance must adversely affect the body.
('69', 165, 9, 23, 303812) The same is true of aswada 4. I mention these only as illustrations.
('69', 165, 9, 24, 303881) It is difficult to say where you might have committed a slip.
('69', 165, 9, 25, 303943) The detection of your fault, if possible, can now benefit only to the extent of proving helpful in your treatment.

('69', 166, 6, 9, 304783) SHARDA,
('69', 166, 7, 10, 304791) It is a lame excuse that you had nothing to write about.Many boys and girls engaged in work which is not to my liking keep on writing to me.
('69', 166, 7, 11, 304932) Your argument is not worthy of your intelligence.
('69', 166, 7, 12, 304982) You say that your body being delicate you would like to develop your intellectual faculties to make a living.
('69', 166, 7, 13, 305092) But you do not see that mental work can have an adverse effect on health.
('69', 166, 7, 14, 305166) It is a lowly idea to acquire knowledge for the sake of earning money.
('69', 166, 7, 15, 305237) It is a also a mistaken notion that you will be a burden.
('69', 166, 7, 16, 305295) Why don’t you realize that you are going to be a burden if, in spite of acquiring the highest knowledge, you have to remain bed ridden?
('69', 166, 7, 17, 305431) I would certainly be happy if you acquired knowledge.
('69', 166, 7, 18, 305485) I would not grudge it if, like Bal, you studied in a college and acquired a high degree.
('69', 166, 7, 19, 305574) But certainly not at the cost of your health.
('69', 166, 7, 20, 305620) Your primary duty is to improve your health.
('69', 166, 7, 21, 305665) This is of course my view.
('69', 166, 7, 22, 305692) What matters is your own bent.
('69', 166, 7, 23, 305723) Now that you have started, continue writing to me.

('69', 172, 4, 8, 312988) Blessings from BAPU

('69', 172, 7, 12, 313091) 211. BARBAROUS IF TRUE
('69', 172, 8, 13, 313114) A correspondent sends me the following paragraph 1 from The Hindu’s own correspondent dated 8th June at Ramnad:
('69', 172, 9, 14, 313226) At a meeting of the Devacottah Panchayat Board held on Saturday at the Board’s office,...
('69', 172, 9, 15, 313316) the usual procedure was adopted, viz., the Harijan member entered the meeting hall, signed his signature in the attendance register, receded to the exit door of the meeting hall, and stood all the while till the close of the meeting...
('69', 172, 9, 16, 313552) I take the following 2 from his letter enclosing the cutting from The Hindu:
('69', 172, 10, 17, 313629) I am sending herewith a cutting from The Hindu....
('69', 172, 11, 18, 313680) The Panchayat Board referred to is in the heart of Chettinad and is supposed to be composed of Congressmen or men who had been elected quite recently on the Congress ticket to advance through local boards and panchayats the aims and objects for which the great Indian National Congress stands.
('69', 172, 12, 19, 313974) It is shocking to read that a body like this should in this twentieth century has the audacity to compel a Harijan member to stand out of the meeting hall in spite of the fact that he is himself a member of that body duly
('69', 172, 13, 20, 314196) 1 Of which only excerpts are reproduced here.
('69', 173, 0, 1, 314242) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 173, 1, 2, 314284) elected and representing a section of the community and thereby enjoying all the privileges to which such a membership entitles him...
('69', 173, 1, 3, 314419) I do not know whether my correspondent is correct in saying that the Devacottah Panchayat is composed of Congressmen.
('69', 173, 1, 4, 314537) If it is, so much the worse for the Congressmen concerned, for apart from the manifest injustice of the conduct adopted by the Panchayat towards its Harijan members, Congressmen are pledged opponents of untouchability.
('69', 173, 1, 5, 314756) But whether the Panchayat is composed of Congress men or not, the conduct of the Board can only be characterized as barbarous, even as it would be of the Legislative Assembly if it made its member Rao Bahadur Rajah stand in a corner whilst its proceedings were going on.
('69', 173, 1, 6, 315027) But The Hindu correspondent lets the public know that the procedure is usual for the Devacottah Panchayat.
('69', 173, 1, 7, 315134) It is to be presumed that the occasion for noticing the usual event has been supplied by the fact that untouchability just now looms large especially in the South.
('69', 173, 1, 8, 315298) Even if the practice of making Harijan members stand in a corner by certain panchayats is usual, public opinion should make it impossible of repetition.
('69', 173, 1, 9, 315451) Evidently, however, the paragraph does not appear to have caused any public stir.
('69', 173, 1, 10, 315533) The editorial columns of the Southern Press seem, too, to have taken no notice of the incident which is ugly enough to demand strong condemnation.
('69', 173, 1, 11, 315680) Thanks are therefore due to my correspondent for lifting The Hindu paragraph from oblivion.
('69', 173, 1, 12, 315772) Not only is the practice barbarous, I think it is also illegal.
('69', 173, 1, 13, 315836) The Harijan member has a legal right to demand a seat side by side with his fellow members.
('69', 173, 1, 14, 315928) It would be no answer to the charge that the Harijan member was party to his own insult.
('69', 173, 1, 15, 316017) I can well understand poor Harijans in remote parts of India being too timid to assert their rights.
('69', 173, 1, 16, 316118) And for Harijans, Devacottah is unfortunately remote enough.
('69', 173, 1, 17, 316179) Anyway, it is the duty of the Provincial and the local Harijan Sevak Sanghs to investigate the matter and take such steps as may be proper to avoid a repetition of the insult offered not merely to the Harijan member but the whole society, if it is jealous of the rights of the least among its members equally with the greatest.
('69', 173, 2, 18, 316507) Harijan, 27 6 1936
('69', 174, 0, 1, 316526) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 175
('69', 174, 1, 2, 316569) 212. HARIJANS AND ELECTIONS
('69', 174, 2, 3, 316597) The talk I had on my return journey from Bangalore, with Shri.
('69', 174, 2, 4, 316660) A. Kaleswara Rao and Shri V. Kurmiah, a Harijan lawyer, has been published in The Hindu.
('69', 174, 2, 5, 316749) Friends have written to inquire whether the correspondent of The Hindu has correctly reported the conversation.
('69', 174, 2, 6, 316861) They also ask me to give my opinion in my own language.
('69', 174, 2, 7, 316917) The Hindu correspondent’s version is substantially correct so far as it goes.
('69', 174, 2, 8, 316995) It omits the preliminary part of the talk.
('69', 174, 2, 9, 317038) In answer to Shri Kurmiah’s question I said I adhered to the written advice I had sent to Shri Gavai of Nagpur, M.L.C. “But what are we to do if we are not one undivided party, and if individuals or groups are not strong enough to act unaided?” asked Shri Kurmiah.
('69', 174, 2, 10, 317303) “Then,” I said, “naturally you will ally yourselves to that party which gives you the greatest advantage.
('69', 174, 2, 11, 317409) “In my opinion such a party is undoubtedly the Congress.
('69', 174, 2, 12, 317466) It is pledged to the removal of untouchability root and branch; the largest number of Congressmen are to be found among workers engaged in doing anti untouchability work.
('69', 174, 2, 13, 317637) But you will do well not to participate in any council boycott or civil resistance campaign, if the Congress is driven to any such thing in the pursuit of its clearly defined goal of complete independence.
('69', 174, 2, 14, 317843) And this I say, if only because the vast majority of Harijans are hardly equipped for such a fight.
('69', 174, 2, 15, 317943) Your immediate goal is to vindicate your status of absolute equality which is denied to you in the sacred name of religion by the so called sanatani Hindus.
('69', 174, 2, 16, 318100) You ask as if you were only an isolated individual.
('69', 174, 2, 17, 318152) But all Harijans are not like you.
('69', 174, 2, 18, 318187) An ocean separates you from the fellow Harijans in education and understanding.
('69', 174, 2, 19, 318267) If I am true to you, I must speak only in terms of the vast mass of illiterate Harijans in whose name Harijan members of councils will speak.” This is the purport of the conversation and it represents my considered opinion.
('69', 174, 2, 20, 318491) The reader will be interested to know that this was the advice I tendered Harijans even when I launched on the first civil resistance campaign and prevented Ashram Harijans from either joining the campaign or the exodus from the Ashram.
('69', 174, 3, 21, 318728) Harijan, 27 6 1936
('69', 175, 0, 1, 318747) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('69', 176, 5, 9, 320490) 216. TALK WITH A FRIEND 1
('69', 176, 6, 10, 320516) [About June 27, 1936] 2
('69', 176, 7, 11, 320540) We all know that conditions of life in a village are particularly hard in the monsoon.
('69', 176, 7, 12, 320627) Why then should I not begin with that rich experience and wait until conditions were better?
('69', 176, 7, 13, 320720) I had been nursing the thought of going to live in a village ever since I had heard of the experiences of Timappa Naik and his friends, and I tell you that now that I am there, I grudge having to come here even for a single day.
('69', 176, 7, 14, 320949) I came this week because it would have been too much to expect all the members of the Working Committee and other friends to tramp to Segaon in this weather.
('69', 176, 7, 15, 321107) But I may tell you that though I am here, my mind is there.
('69', 176, 8, 16, 321167) Harijan, 11 7 1936

('69', 182, 7, 14, 328932) 229. MESSAGE TO “INDIAN OPINION”
('69', 182, 8, 15, 328965) July 2, 1936
('69', 182, 9, 16, 328978) The Editor of Indian Opinion asks me to send a message for the Diwali number of the paper.
('69', 182, 9, 17, 329069) How can there be any Diwali—festival of lamps—for one who has a Holi—an all consuming fire—burning in his heart?
('69', 182, 9, 18, 329182) How can one celebrate Diwali when one’s ears are filled with the sighs of the millions of the living dead in this country?
('69', 182, 9, 19, 329305) All I can think of saying to the readers of Indian Opinion is this: Celebrate Diwali by all means, but don’t forget the skeletons in India.
('69', 182, 9, 20, 329445) Set apart a share for them first.
('69', 182, 10, 21, 329479) M. K. GANDHI

('69', 185, 6, 16, 333028) 235. FOR KHADI WEARERS
('69', 185, 7, 17, 333051) Here are two extracts 1 from a longish letter from a Bihar correspondent:
('69', 185, 8, 18, 333125) I have a complaint against you.
('69', 185, 8, 19, 333157) I am a habitual khadi wearer.
('69', 185, 8, 20, 333187) I have been using khadi since its first appearance....
('69', 185, 8, 21, 333242) If I ever be obliged to give up khadi due to my poor circumstances, I shall be much pained.
('69', 185, 8, 22, 333334) And the present unexpected increase in its prices without proportion will, I fear, drag me to that verge....
('69', 185, 8, 23, 333443) This will, I think, bring about the total collapse of the khadi movement.
('69', 185, 9, 24, 333517) I am told that you desire to pay more to the poor spinners...
('69', 185, 9, 25, 333579) But from whose pockets?...
('69', 185, 9, 26, 333606) It will certainly be death to poor khadi wearers if they are
('69', 185, 10, 27, 333667) obliged to give up an ideal for which they stood and bravely fought...
('69', 185, 10, 28, 333738) Your present decision is a great blunder.
('69', 185, 10, 29, 333780) I fear by this you mean to give the movement a decent burial.
('69', 185, 10, 30, 333842) The following 2 is taken from a U.P. correspondent:
('69', 185, 11, 31, 333894) ...Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru has so much minimized the importance, necessity and utility of khadi that many staunch khadi wearers are placed in a
('69', 185, 12, 32, 334038) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('69', 185, 12, 33, 334075) 2 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('69', 186, 0, 1, 334112) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 187
('69', 186, 1, 2, 334155) fix and the weaker believers have got a secure shelter behind Panditji.
('69', 186, 1, 3, 334227) The Congress has also relaxed the rigidity in the use of khadi and you seem to be finding solace in your determined silence.
('69', 186, 1, 4, 334352) Would you just guide us and let us know our duty under the present circumstances?
('69', 186, 1, 5, 334434) Another difficulty lies on
('69', 186, 2, 6, 334461) account of the existing organization of the supplying source of khadi, the All India Spinners’Association.
('69', 186, 2, 7, 334568) Under the present conditions khadi is becoming dearer and dearer and its supply is growing less and less.
('69', 186, 2, 8, 334674) The independent and individual khadi producers have been almost debarred from producing even a yard of khadi.
('69', 186, 2, 9, 334784) The rules and restrictions seem, firstly, unreasonable, secondly, almost impossible to be followed, and thirdly, they are applied in an objectionable way and not in the spirit they might have been stipulated by you...
('69', 186, 2, 10, 335002) How do you justify the restrictions imposed on the private khadi producers who have been compelled to abandon their production?
('69', 186, 2, 11, 335130) There is a similar complaint from C.P. National Scouts.
('69', 186, 2, 12, 335186) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru was, as has been made clear by him, misreported.
('69', 186, 3, 13, 335259) In common with the other believers in khadi, till the country has attained its freedom he thinks khadi to be a vital necessity.
('69', 186, 3, 14, 335387) His doubt about its economic value has a place, if at all, only when independence is achieved and industrialization on a vast scale takes place in the country.
('69', 186, 3, 15, 335547) Surely no wise man will give up khadi now for fear of its being overwhelmed by industrialization which may or may not envelop India in the far off future.
('69', 186, 3, 16, 335702) The restrictions on private producers are intended as well in the interests of artisans, especially the spinners, as the buyers.
('69', 186, 3, 17, 335831) If they are removed the market will be flooded with spurious khadi resulting in spinners being put out of work and the buyers being deceived.
('69', 186, 3, 18, 335973) If there is irregularity in the working of the regulations, attention of the Secretary should be drawn to it and it will be set right without delay.
('69', 186, 3, 19, 336122) The increase in prices is the only question that demands satisf actory answer.
('69', 186, 3, 20, 336201) It should be remembered that when khadi was not half as good as it is now and when there was much less variety, it was much dearer than under the new scale and there was hardly any complaint against the prices then ruling.
('69', 186, 3, 21, 336424) Whilst the buyers have been benefiting all these many years, the spinners had till now practically no benefit whatsoever in the shape of rise in wages.
('69', 186, 3, 22, 336576) They were dumb and helpless.
('69', 186, 3, 23, 336605) They could not declare a strike against the Association.
('69', 186, 3, 24, 336662) In the very nature of things, they could not combine, being so scattered for the betterment of wages or anything else.
('69', 186, 3, 25, 336781) They were in such need
('69', 186, 4, 26, 336804) 1 Vide “A False Alarm”, 6 6 1936
('69', 187, 0, 1, 336837) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 187, 1, 2, 336879) of even PIES that they could not make any effective protest.
('69', 187, 1, 3, 336940) If now the conscience of a few of us has begun to rebel against the wretchedly low wage given to the spinners, we deserve help from the buyers who have hitherto enjoyed the privilege of reduction in prices.
('69', 187, 1, 4, 337147) The difficulty of poor buyers is obvious.
('69', 187, 1, 5, 337189) But the value of khadi lies in its social and moral value.
('69', 187, 1, 6, 337248) If the khadi buyers understand the implications of khadi, they will not complain of rise in prices, if and when it is conclusively shown, as it can be in the present instance, to be due to the increase in the wages of the spinners concerned.
('69', 187, 1, 7, 337490) If they have the will they will discover many ways of making up for the increase they might have to bear in the purchase of khadi.
('69', 187, 1, 8, 337621) But this they will do if they have burnt their boats and resolved never to use any other cloth but khadi so long as they are in India.
('69', 187, 1, 9, 337756) If they leave an escape door, they will make use of it on emergency.
('69', 187, 1, 10, 337825) Invention comes generally from necessity.
('69', 187, 1, 11, 337867) If the correspondents had made up their minds that for them there was no other cloth but khadi, they would not have written as they have done but, like the very large number who are no whit better off than these correspondents, they would have accommodated themselves to the slight increase that has taken place in the price of khadi.
('69', 187, 2, 12, 338202) At the same time let me comfort the correspondents by giving them the assurance that every care is being taken to make the increase as slight as possible for the poor lovers of khadi.
('69', 187, 2, 13, 338386) Let them too peruse the reports from Rajendra Babu and the Secretary, A.I.S.A., Tamil Nad, on the great success that is attending the new experiment in giving unsolicited increase to spinners in their wages.
('69', 187, 2, 14, 338594) If khadi lovers will have patience, they will find that, if the price of khadi has slightly increased, there has been corresponding improvement in the quality and durability of khadi.
('69', 187, 3, 15, 338778) Harijan, 4 7 1936
('69', 187, 4, 16, 338796) 236. INFANTICIDE OF GIRLS
('69', 187, 5, 17, 338822) It is difficult to believe that even today a cruel inhuman custom like infanticide of girls is prevalent in this unfortunate country.
('69', 187, 5, 18, 338956) But, the letter that lies before me forces me to believe it.
('69', 187, 5, 19, 339017) In the village Amarpur, in Bhagalpur District, Bihar, an association to oppose such infanticide among Rajputs has been formed.
('69', 187, 5, 20, 339144) The secretary of this
('69', 188, 0, 1, 339166) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 189
('69', 188, 1, 2, 339209) body has written a very sad letter in this regard.
('69', 188, 1, 3, 339260) A few excerpts 1 from it are given below.
('69', 188, 1, 4, 339302) Dharma teaches us that all souls are one.
('69', 188, 1, 5, 339344) Plurality, being momentary, is only an illusion.
('69', 188, 1, 6, 339393) Nationalism, too, teaches us this same lesson.
('69', 188, 1, 7, 339440) We do not think of ourselves as Rajputs, or Biharis, Punjabis and so on.
('69', 188, 1, 8, 339513) We consider ourselves Indians and we believe ourselves to be one nation and persuade others to believe so.
('69', 188, 1, 9, 339620) Therefore whether from the point of view of religion or of patriotism we are one; the responsibility of the misconduct of any one falls on all of us.
('69', 188, 1, 10, 339770) For this reason we are all responsible for the infanticide of girls among Rajputs, whether we are Rajputs or from any other community.
('69', 188, 1, 11, 339905) Had we not been indifferent to one another’s faults and troubles, infanticide of girls could not have continued to this day.
('69', 188, 1, 12, 340030) There is no religious excuse and no need for this.
('69', 188, 1, 13, 340081) There might have been a time when the life of a Rajput was insecure and therefore the birth of girls was considered calamitous.
('69', 188, 1, 14, 340209) Today this excuse does not exist.
('69', 188, 1, 15, 340243) It cannot be said that the lives of Rajputs are less safe than those of the others.
('69', 188, 1, 16, 340327) War no longer threatens the Rajputs.
('69', 188, 1, 17, 340364) Today a Rajput does not have to sleep with his sword by his side.
('69', 188, 1, 18, 340430) There is still a Rajput community, no doubt, but there is nothing like the special dharma of the Rajputs.
('69', 188, 1, 19, 340536) Why then this infanticide of girls?
('69', 188, 1, 20, 340572) Why should girls be a burden?
('69', 188, 1, 21, 340602) The burden certainly is on those who buy husbands for their daughters and have to pay such exorbitant prices that they are all but ruined.
('69', 188, 1, 22, 340741) It is God’s mercy that they have not reached the stage of killing their daughters.
('69', 188, 1, 23, 340824) I am not aware if any excuse is put forward for the infanticide of Rajput girls.
('69', 188, 1, 24, 340905) If there is any such excuse, it is the duty of this new association to throw light on the subject.
('69', 188, 1, 25, 341004) But even if there is a cause, it is our duty to remove it.
('69', 188, 1, 26, 341063) No excuse can be accepted for the continuance of this barbarous custom.
('69', 188, 1, 27, 341135) Public opinion must be mobilized to abolish this custom soon.
('69', 188, 1, 28, 341197) The burden of mobilizing public opinion must fall on the Rajput Kanya Vadha Virodhini Sabha.
('69', 188, 1, 29, 341290) This endeavour will not bear fruit by long speeches nor by passing resolutions.
('69', 188, 1, 30, 341370) A little of both these will be needed.
('69', 188, 1, 31, 341409) But the most important thing is a complete picture of the facts.
('69', 188, 1, 32, 341474) You should prepare a chart which should tell at one glance where the infanticide of girls takes place and the number of girls killed in the previous year.
('69', 188, 1, 33, 341629) It may be difficult to obtain the number of girls killed, it may even be impossible.
('69', 188, 1, 34, 341714) The point is that all available
('69', 188, 2, 35, 341746) 1 These are not translated here.
('69', 189, 0, 1, 341779) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 189, 1, 2, 341821) information must be gathered and the Sabha’s message conveyed to every home where there is a possibility of such an incident.
('69', 189, 1, 3, 341947) Mere publishing of the resolutions in newspapers will have no effect on the parents who resort to this practice.
('69', 189, 1, 4, 342060) It is important for the workers of the Sabha to remember that they should not exaggerate facts in any way.
('69', 189, 1, 5, 342167) By ceaseless, sincere and peaceful efforts success in this cause can be attained soon.
('69', 189, 1, 6, 342254) This is what I think and believe.

('69', 195, 4, 7, 351384) 248. LETTER TO AMRITLAL V. THAKKAR
('69', 195, 5, 8, 351419) July 6, 1936
('69', 195, 7, 9, 351432) At Wardha I can hardly lift my head and read letters, and if I manage to read them I cannot reply to them.
('69', 195, 7, 10, 351539) And what is more, if I am to live long, I must avoid working till late at night, or in the small hours of the morning.
('69', 195, 7, 11, 351658) Do call a meeting of the Committee in August to discuss the subjects you suggest.
('69', 195, 7, 12, 351740) Obtain Jamnalalji’s consent.
('69', 195, 7, 13, 351769) I shall be occupied between August 10 and 12. I have followed the point regarding contributions.
('69', 195, 7, 14, 351866) It is surprising that you had no success in Bombay.
('69', 195, 7, 15, 351918) I do not think we should cut down on work everywhere, though all the provinces should certainly become self supporting.
('69', 195, 7, 16, 352038) In accepting conditional Government aid for Kodambakkam I can see nothing but ruin.
('69', 195, 7, 17, 352122) I had mentioned to the Rao Bahadur very strong reasons and I thought he had been convinced.
('69', 195, 7, 18, 352214) I now see I was mistaken.
('69', 195, 7, 19, 352240) The chief reason of course is that if the money is not forthcoming from the Hindus even for this small institution, the Sangh or the Hindus cannot take the credit for running it.
('69', 195, 7, 20, 352419) Of course if you say we are concerned with the end and not with the argument, then I shall have nothing to say.
('69', 195, 7, 21, 352531) But even so I shall insist that considering the origin of the Sangh, if nothing else, our ideal should be not to shoulder any burden that the Hindus would not share.
('69', 195, 7, 22, 352697) The rest is a matter of method or means.
('69', 195, 7, 23, 352738) If it is somehow worth while running it even with Government aid, why should not the Committee run it on its own independently of the Sangh?
('69', 195, 7, 24, 352879) I would be interested in keeping the Sangh’s foundations firm and strong, though the range of my understanding is limited to Segaon.
('69', 195, 7, 25, 353012) Hence the correct decision would
('69', 196, 0, 1, 353045) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 197
('69', 196, 1, 2, 353088) be the one that the Committee takes after they have listened to me.
('69', 196, 1, 3, 353156) My Malaya or whatever you call it is Segaon, at least for the present.
('69', 196, 1, 4, 353227) If God lets me spend three seasons here, I would deem it great favour of the Big Brother.
('69', 196, 1, 5, 353317) But what flattery can work with Him?
