('69', 204, 4, 22, 368575) 262. DR.
('69', 204, 4, 23, 368584) AMBEDKAR’S INDICTMENT—I
('69', 204, 5, 24, 368608) The readers will recall the fact that Dr. Ambedkar was to have presided last May at the annual conference of the Jat Pat Torak Mandal of Lahore.
('69', 204, 5, 25, 368753) But the conference itself was cancelled because Dr. Ambedkar’s address was found by the Reception Committee to be unacceptable.
('69', 204, 5, 26, 368881) How far a Reception Committee is justified in rejecting a President of its choice because of his address that may be objectio nable to it is open to question.
('69', 204, 5, 27, 369040) The Committee knew Dr. Ambedkar’s views on caste and the Hindu scriptures.
('69', 204, 5, 28, 369115) They knew also that he had in
('69', 204, 6, 29, 369145) 1 The name has been omitted.
('69', 205, 0, 1, 369174) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 205, 1, 2, 369216) unequivocal terms decided to give up Hinduism.
('69', 205, 1, 3, 369263) Nothing less than the address that Dr. Ambedkar had prepared was to be expected from him.
('69', 205, 1, 4, 369353) The Committee appears to have deprived the public of an opportunity of listening to the original views of a man who has carved out for himself a unique position in society.
('69', 205, 1, 5, 369526) Whatever label he wears in future, Dr. Ambedkar is not the man to allow himself to be forgotten.
('69', 205, 1, 6, 369623) Dr. Ambedkar was not going to be beaten by the Reception Committee.
('69', 205, 1, 7, 369691) He has answered their rejection of him by publishing the address at his own expense.
('69', 205, 1, 8, 369776) He has priced it at 8 annas.
('69', 205, 1, 9, 369805) I would suggest a reduction to 2 annas or at least 4 annas.
('69', 205, 1, 10, 369865) No reformer can ignore the address.
('69', 205, 1, 11, 369901) The orthodox will gain by reading it.
('69', 205, 1, 12, 369939) This is not to say that the address is not open to objection.
('69', 205, 1, 13, 370001) It has to be read if only because it is open to serious objection.
('69', 205, 1, 14, 370068) Dr. Ambedkar is a challenge to Hinduism.
('69', 205, 1, 15, 370109) Brought up as a Hindu, educated by a Hindu potentate, he has become so disgusted with the so called savarna Hindus for the treatment that he and his have received at their hands that he proposes to leave not only them but the very religion that is his and their common heritage.
('69', 205, 1, 16, 370388) He has transferred to that religion his disgust against a part of its professors.
('69', 205, 1, 17, 370470) But this is not to be wondered at.
('69', 205, 1, 18, 370505) After all one can only judge a system or an institution by the conduct of its representatives.
('69', 205, 1, 19, 370600) What is more, Dr. Ambedkar found that the vast majority of savarna Hindus had not only conducted themselves inhumanly against those of their fellow religionists whom they classed as untouchables, but they had based their conduct on the authority of their scriptures, and when he began to search them he had found ample warrant for their belief in untouchability and all its implications.
('69', 205, 1, 20, 370988) The author of the address has quoted chapter and verse in proof of his therefold indictment— inhuman conduct itself, the unabashed justification for it on the part of the prepetrators, and the subsequent discovery that the justification was warranted by their scriptures.
('69', 205, 1, 21, 371260) No Hindu who prizes his faith above life itself can afford to underrate the importance of this indictment.
('69', 205, 1, 22, 371367) Dr. Ambedkar is not alone in his disgust.
('69', 205, 1, 23, 371409) He is its most uncompromising exponent and one of the ablest among them.
('69', 205, 1, 24, 371482) He is certainly the most irreconcilable among them.
('69', 205, 1, 25, 371534) Thank God, in the front rank of the leaders he is singularly alone and as yet but a representative of a very small minor ity.
('69', 205, 1, 26, 371660) But what he says is voiced with more or less vehemence by many
('69', 206, 0, 1, 371723) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 207
('69', 206, 1, 2, 371766) leaders belonging to the depressed classes.
('69', 206, 1, 3, 371810) Only the latter, for instance Rao Bahadur M.C. Rajah and Dewan Bahadur Srinivasan, not only do not threaten to give up Hinduism but find enough warmth in it to compensate for the shameful persecution to which the vast mass of Harijans are exposed.
('69', 206, 1, 4, 372058) But the fact of many leaders remaining in the Hindu fold is no warrant for disregarding what Dr. Ambedkar has to say.
('69', 206, 1, 5, 372176) The savarnas have to correct their belief and their conduct.
('69', 206, 1, 6, 372237) Above all, those who are by their learning and influence among the savarnas have to give an authoritative interpretaion of the scriptures.
('69', 206, 1, 7, 372376) The questions that Dr. Ambedkar’s indictment suggests are: 1. What are the scriptures?
('69', 206, 1, 8, 372463) 2. Are all the printed texts to be regarded as an integral part of them or is any part of them to be rejected as unauthorized interp olations?
('69', 206, 1, 9, 372606) 3. What is the answer of such accepted and expurgated scriptures on the question of untouchability, caste, equality of status, inter dining and intermarriages?
('69', 206, 1, 10, 372766) (These have been all ably examined by Dr. Ambedkar in his address).
('69', 206, 1, 11, 372834) I must reserve for the next issue 1 my own answer to these questions and a statement of the (at least some) manifest flaws in Dr. Ambedkar’s thesis.
('69', 206, 2, 12, 372983) Harijan, 11 7 1936

('69', 212, 1, 2, 382667) 269. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('69', 212, 2, 3, 382699) July 12, 1936
('69', 212, 3, 4, 382713) GANGABEHN,
('69', 212, 4, 5, 382724) Cooking and washing clothes are no small service.
('69', 212, 4, 6, 382774) There is an idea abroad these days that only the educated can do public service and the value of cooking and similar work has gone down very much.
('69', 212, 4, 7, 382921) But did you not see that at Sabarmati the responsibility of the kitchen was entrusted only to a mature and experienced Ashram worker?
('69', 212, 4, 8, 383055) When the Ashram was first established at Kochrab, I had in the beginning assumed the responsibility myself.
('69', 212, 4, 9, 383163) Subsequently it was passed on to Vinoba, Kaka and others, and a worker like Vrajlal 1 lost his life while attending to the washing of clothes.
('69', 212, 4, 10, 383306) Even when he joined, he had asked to be allowed to do all the clothes washing, though he could do accounting and possessed a handwriting beautiful as a string of pearls.
('69', 212, 4, 11, 383476) At a time of difficulty once, the charge of the store had to be entrusted to him.
('69', 212, 4, 12, 383558) Without such workers we can never hope to win swaraj.
('69', 212, 5, 13, 383612) What I have said above doesn’t mean, however, that you may not increase your knowledge of letters when you get the opportunity to do so or that you should not encourage others in their desire to learn.
('69', 212, 5, 14, 383814) All that I mean is that anybody who hankers after education, neglecting the dharma that has fallen to his lot unsought, is committing an error.
('69', 212, 5, 15, 383958) Do come to Wardha before going to Bochasan.
('69', 212, 5, 16, 384002) Gomati will try to drag you to her place.
('69', 212, 5, 17, 384044) Besides, there are Maganwadi and Mahila Ashram also.
('69', 212, 5, 18, 384097) Janakibehn is there, too, and, if you wish, you can come to me at Segaon and even stay with me, though we have only one room here for all of us.
('69', 212, 5, 19, 384242) Only lately Tukdoji Maharaj has come and has been assigned one corner.
('69', 212, 5, 20, 384313) The room is large enough, 29 x 14, with a 7’verandah running all round.
('69', 212, 5, 21, 384385) In one corner of the verandah is a small kitchen and in another a bathroom for me.
('69', 212, 5, 22, 384468) The walls are made of mud.
('69', 212, 5, 23, 384495) The entire building is constructed with purely local materials.
('69', 212, 5, 24, 384559) All around in this season our eyes rest on green fields.
('69', 212, 6, 25, 384616) 1 Vrajlal Gandhi who had descended into a well to bring up someone’s water pot which had fallen in.

('69', 215, 4, 10, 388130) 273. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('69', 215, 5, 11, 388162) Unrevised by me SEGAON, July 15, 1936
('69', 215, 6, 12, 388200) DEAR JAWAHARLAL,
('69', 215, 7, 13, 388217) (1) I hope you got my wire about The Times of India letter.
('69', 215, 7, 14, 388277) I procured it yesterday and read it through.
('69', 215, 7, 15, 388322) Nobody has ever written to me about the subject matter.
('69', 215, 7, 16, 388378) My reading of the letter confirms my view that you should take legal notice of the libel.
('69', 215, 7, 17, 388468) (2) If you will not misunderstand me, I would like you to keep me free of the Civil Liberties Union.
('69', 215, 7, 18, 388569) I do not like for the time being to join any political institution.
('69', 215, 7, 19, 388637) And there is no meaning in a confirmed civil resister joining it.
('69', 215, 7, 20, 388703) Apart however from my joining or not joining the Union, maturer consideration confirms me in my opinion that it would be a mistkae to appoint Sarojini Naidu or for that matter any civil resister as President.
('69', 215, 7, 21, 388912) I am still of opinion that the President should be a well known constitutional lawyer.
('69', 215, 7, 22, 388999) If that does not commend itself to you then, you should have an author of note who is not a law breaker.
('69', 215, 7, 23, 389104) I would also ask you to restrict the number of members.
('69', 215, 7, 24, 389160) You need quality, not quantity.
('69', 215, 7, 25, 389192) (3) Your letter is touching.
('69', 215, 7, 26, 389221) You feel to be the most injured party.
('69', 215, 7, 27, 389260) The fact is that your colleagues have lacked your courage and frankness.
('69', 215, 7, 28, 389333) The result has been disastrous.
('69', 215, 7, 29, 389365) I have always pleaded with them to speak out to you freely and fearlessly.
('69', 215, 7, 30, 389440) But having lacked the courage, whenever they have spoken they have done it clumsily and you have felt irritated.
('69', 215, 7, 31, 389553) I tell you they have dreaded you, because of your irritability and impatience of them.
('69', 215, 7, 32, 389640) They have chafed under your rebukes and magisterial manner and above all your arrogation
('69', 216, 0, 1, 389729) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 217
('69', 216, 1, 2, 389772) of what has appeared to them your infallibility and superior knowledge.
('69', 216, 1, 3, 389844) They feel that you have treated them with scant courtesy and never defended them from socialists’ridicule and even misrepr esentation.
('69', 216, 1, 4, 389979) You complain of their having called your activities harmful.
('69', 216, 1, 5, 390040) That was not to say that you were harmful.
('69', 216, 1, 6, 390083) Their letter was no occasion for recounting your virtues or your services.
('69', 216, 1, 7, 390158) They were fully conscious of your dynamism and your hold over the masses and the youth of the country.
('69', 216, 1, 8, 390261) They know that you cannot be dispensed with.
('69', 216, 1, 9, 390306) And so they wanted to give way.
('69', 216, 1, 10, 390338) I look upon the whole affair as a tragi comedy.
('69', 216, 1, 11, 390386) I would therefore like you to look at the whole thing in a lighter vein.
('69', 216, 1, 12, 390459) I do not mind your taking the A.I.C.C. into your confidence.
('69', 216, 1, 13, 390520) But I do want you not to impose on it the unbearable taks of adjusting your family quarrels or choosing between them and you.
('69', 216, 1, 14, 390646) Whatever you do you must face them with accomplished things.
('69', 216, 1, 15, 390707) Why do you resent their majority being reflected in all subcommittees, etc.?
('69', 216, 1, 16, 390784) Is it not the most natural thing?
('69', 216, 1, 17, 390818) You are in office by their unanimous choice but you are not in power yet.
('69', 216, 1, 18, 390892) To put you in office was an attempt to find you in power, quicker than you would otherwise have been.
('69', 216, 1, 19, 390994) Anyway that was at the back of my mind when I suggested your name for the crown of thorns.
('69', 216, 1, 20, 391085) Keep it on though the head be bruised.
('69', 216, 1, 21, 391124) Resume your humour at the committee meetings.
('69', 216, 1, 22, 391170) That is your most usual role, not that of a care worn irritable man ready to burst on the slightest occasion.
('69', 216, 1, 23, 391280) How I wish you could telegraph to me that on finishing my letter you felt as merry as you were on that New Year’s Day in Lahore when you were reported to have danced round the tricolour flag.
('69', 216, 1, 24, 391472) You must give your throat a chance.
('69', 216, 1, 25, 391508) I am revising my statement.
('69', 216, 1, 26, 391536) I have decided not to publish it till you have seen it.
('69', 216, 1, 27, 391592) I have decided that nobody should see our correspondence, besides Mahadev.

('69', 220, 6, 14, 396561) Why this sign of old age?

('69', 220, 6, 16, 396702) It is possible to keep the vow of abstaining from cooked food.
('69', 220, 6, 17, 396765) True discipline would lie in this: You should eat nothing to indulge the palate.
('69', 220, 6, 18, 396846) By way of medicine, you may take any food in the prescribed measure.
('69', 220, 6, 19, 396915) Your weakness and night blindness must disappear.
('69', 220, 7, 20, 396965) Blessings from BAPU

('69', 223, 9, 17, 401171) 287. TALK WITH JAIRAMDAS DOULATRAM AND DEVDAS GANDHI 2
('69', 223, 10, 18, 401226) [Before July 18, 1936] 3
('69', 223, 11, 19, 401251) I am very happy that you have come here, but, I hope, not to see this dignified hut of mine.
('69', 223, 11, 20, 401344) I am responsible for little of the planning here, and I have given to it none of my art or my labour.
('69', 223, 11, 21, 401446) But I wonder if you saw on you way Mirabehn's hut.
('69', 223, 11, 22, 401497) It was worth while coming all the way to see her hut certainly.
('69', 223, 11, 23, 401561) That is really and truly HER hut.
('69', 223, 12, 24, 401595) 1 It was a note on the programme for Gandhiji's sixty eighth birthday which was revised by Gandhiji.
('69', 223, 12, 25, 401696) It read: “ If a spinner wishes to use for himself the yarn spun by him, he will get it back as prasada; if not, it will be used to promote khadi activity.
('69', 223, 12, 26, 401851) It is not too much to hope that everyone will understand the significance of this occasion and give an impetus to khadi activity.” 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's “Weekly Letter” 3 Devdas Gandhi had reached Delhi by July 18; vide “Letter to Manilal and Sushila Gandhi”, 18 7 1936
('69', 224, 0, 1, 402132) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 225
('69', 224, 1, 2, 402175) is a hut built FOR me, not MY hut.
('69', 224, 1, 3, 402210) Here is her own hut, planned and built by herself (of course with other people's labour).
('69', 224, 1, 4, 402300) But it is not merely a hut.
('69', 224, 1, 5, 402328) It is a poem.
('69', 224, 1, 6, 402342) I studied it in detail only yesterday, and I tell you I had tears of joy as I saw the villager's mentality about everything in it.
('69', 224, 1, 7, 402473) You know I often have my quarrels with her, but let me tell you that no one from amongst us can claim to have the real rural mindedness that she has.
('69', 224, 1, 8, 402623) Did you study the position of her little bath room and the inside of it?
('69', 224, 1, 9, 402696) She has utilized every stone that the blasting of the underground rock in her well, made available to her.
('69', 224, 1, 10, 402803) The seat for the bath is all one stone fixed to the ground.
('69', 224, 1, 11, 402863) Next to the bathroom in the same little hut is the latrine.
('69', 224, 1, 12, 402923) No commode or wooden plank or any brickwork.
('69', 224, 1, 13, 402968) Just two beautiful stones, half buried in the ground, and with two halves of kerosene tins between the stones.
('69', 224, 1, 14, 403079) Any villager can do this, but never does it.
('69', 224, 1, 15, 403124) All the water naturally runs to carefully made beds for plants and vegetables.
('69', 224, 1, 16, 403203) And look at the care with which she has built the little stable for her horse, on the grooming and feeding and keeping of which she lavishes all her love and attention.
('69', 224, 1, 17, 403372) Her love of animals is a thing to learn from her.
('69', 224, 1, 18, 403422) Even whilst she is sitting and working in her hut; the stable is so arranged that she can give an occasional look to the horse.
('69', 224, 1, 19, 403550) And now let us see the inside of the hut—all mud and split bamboo and wattle of palm branches.
('69', 224, 1, 20, 403645) You note every little article in the hut and the place given to it.
('69', 224, 1, 21, 403713) Her chula (fire) is all made with her own hands, and though she has learnt it from us no one can beat her in the art.
('69', 224, 1, 22, 403831) Then see the bamboo mantelpiece (if you will give it that big name) on which she keeps her earthen cooking utensils.
('69', 224, 1, 23, 403948) Then see the little doorless windows and bamboo bookshelf and note the palms and peacocks over the windows, moulded in relief by herself.
('69', 224, 1, 24, 404086) Also note her little kitchen and the carding room.
('69', 224, 1, 25, 404137) The village where she works is about two to three furlongs from the hut.
('69', 224, 1, 26, 404210) All the women and many of the men in the village know her, and the women confide to her many of their household secrets and look to her for advice and guidance—not always an easy matter, but always unfailingly for solace and comfort.
('69', 224, 1, 27, 404444) She looks like one of them.
('69', 224, 1, 28, 404472) Well, if you have not studied her hut carefully I would like you to go there again on your way back.
('69', 224, 2, 29, 404573) Harijan, 25 7 1936
('69', 225, 0, 1, 404592) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 225, 1, 2, 404634) 288. DR.
('69', 225, 1, 3, 404643) AMBEDKAR'S INDICTMENT—II
('69', 225, 2, 4, 404668) The Vedas, Upanishads, Smritis and Puranas including Ramayana and Mahabharata are the Hindu scriptures.
('69', 225, 2, 5, 404772) Nor is this a finite list.
('69', 225, 2, 6, 404799) Evey age or even generation has added to the list.
('69', 225, 2, 7, 404850) It follows, therefore, that everything printed or even found handwritten is not scripture.
('69', 225, 2, 8, 404941) The Smritis, for instance, contain much that can never be accepted as the word of God.
('69', 225, 2, 9, 405028) Thus many of the texts that Dr. Ambedkar quotes from the smritis cannot be accepted as authentic, The scriptures properly so called can only be concerned with eternal verities and must appeal to any conscience, i.e., any heart whose eyes of understanding are opened.
('69', 225, 2, 10, 405295) Nothing can be accepted as the word of God which cannot be tested by reason or is not capable of being spiritually experienced.
('69', 225, 2, 11, 405423) And even when you have an expurgated edition of the scriptures, you will need their interpretation.
('69', 225, 2, 12, 405523) Who is the best interpreter?
('69', 225, 2, 13, 405552) Not learned men surely.
('69', 225, 2, 14, 405576) Learning there must be.
('69', 225, 2, 15, 405600) But religion does not live by it.
('69', 225, 2, 16, 405634) It lives in the experiences of its saints and seers, in their lives and sayings.
('69', 225, 2, 17, 405715) When all the most learned commentators of the scriptures are utterly forgotten, the accumulated experience of the sages and saints will abide and be an inspiration for ages to come.
('69', 225, 2, 18, 405897) Caste has nothing to do with religion.
('69', 225, 2, 19, 405936) It is a custom whose origin I do not know and do not need to know for the satisfaction of my spiritual hunger.
('69', 225, 2, 20, 406047) But I do know, that it is harmful both to spiritual and national growth.
('69', 225, 2, 21, 406120) Varna and ashrama are institutions which have nothing to do with castes.
('69', 225, 2, 22, 406193) The law of varna teaches us that we have each one of us to earn our bread by following the ancestral calling.
('69', 225, 2, 23, 406303) It defines not our rights but our duties.
('69', 225, 2, 24, 406345) it necessarily has reference to callings that are conducive to the welfare of humanity and to no other.
('69', 225, 2, 25, 406449) It also follows that there is no calling too low and none too high.
('69', 225, 2, 26, 406517) All are good, lawful, and absolutely equal in status.
('69', 225, 2, 27, 406571) The callings of a Brahmin—spiritual teacher—and a scavenger are equal, and their due performance carries equal merit before God and at one time seems to have carried identical reward before man.
('69', 225, 2, 28, 406766) Both were entitled to their livelihood and no more.
('69', 225, 2, 29, 406818) Indeed one traces even now in the villages the faint lines of this healthy operation of the law.
('69', 225, 2, 30, 406915) Living in Segaon with its population of 600, I do not find a great disparity between the earnings of different tradesmen including Brahmins.
('69', 225, 2, 31, 407056) I find too that real Brahmins are to be found even in these degenerate days who are
('69', 226, 0, 1, 407140) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 227
('69', 226, 1, 2, 407183) living on alms freely given to them and are giving freely of what they have of spiritual treasures.
('69', 226, 1, 3, 407283) It would be wrong and improper to judge the law of varna by its caricature in the lives of men who profess to belong to a varna whilst they openly commit a breach of its only operative rule.
('69', 226, 1, 4, 407474) Arrogation of a superior status by any of the varnas over another is a denial of the law.
('69', 226, 1, 5, 407564) And there is nothing in the law of varna to warrant a belief in untouchability.(The essence of Hinduism is contained in its enunciation of one and only God as Truth and its bold acceptance of ahimsa as the law of the human family.) I am aware that my interpretation of Hinduism will be disputed by many besides Dr. Ambedkar.
('69', 226, 1, 6, 407889) That does not affect my position.
('69', 226, 1, 7, 407923) It is an interpretation by which I have lived for nearly half a century and according to which I have endeavoured to the best of my ability to regulate my life.
('69', 226, 1, 8, 408084) In my opinion the profound mistake that Dr. Ambedkar has made in his address is to pick out the texts of doubtful authenticity and value and the state of degraded Hindus who are no fit specimens of the faith they, so woefully misrepresent.
('69', 226, 1, 9, 408324) Judged by the standard applied by Dr. Ambedkar, every known living faith will probably fail.
('69', 226, 1, 10, 408417) In his able address, the learned Doctor has over proved his case.
('69', 226, 1, 11, 408483) Can a religion that was professed by Chaitanya, Jnanadeva, Tukaram, Tiruvalluvar, Ramakrishna Paramahamsa, Raja Ram Mohan Roy, Mah arshi Devendranath Tagore, Vivekanand and a host of others who might be easily mentioned, be so utterly devoid of merit as is made out in Dr. Ambedkar's address?
('69', 226, 1, 12, 408776) A religion has to be judged not by its worst specimens but by the best it might have produced.
('69', 226, 1, 13, 408871) For that and that alone can be used as the standard to aspire to, if not to improve upon.
('69', 226, 2, 14, 408961) Harijan, 18 7 1936
('69', 226, 3, 15, 408980) 289. NOTES
('69', 226, 4, 16, 408991) HARIJAN SEVAK SANGH AND MUNICIPAL GRANTS.
('69', 226, 5, 17, 409033) The Secretary of the Harijan Sevak Sangh writes:
('69', 226, 6, 18, 409082) The Government auditors have raised objection to the grant made to the Harijan Sevak Sangh by the Dhulia Municipal Borough during the last year, on the ground that the work of Harijan uplift is not an educational object and the Municipal Borough cannot spend for it.
('69', 226, 6, 19, 409349) Here is a serious question to be tackled.
('69', 227, 0, 1, 409391) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 227, 1, 2, 409433) It is also contended that hostels of students are not educational institutions.
('69', 227, 1, 3, 409513) This is an astounding interpretation and unless set right at an early date will adversely affect the work of the Sangh and other institutions as well.
('69', 227, 1, 4, 409664) If what is stated here is true, there must be some misund erstanding.
('69', 227, 1, 5, 409734) It may be debatable whether Harijan uplift can be classed as an educational effort, but when a school is conducted for Harijans or a hostel run in the interests of students surely both are educational efforts, and as such there should be no objection to a municipal borough financing such institutions.
('69', 227, 1, 6, 410037) I hope, therefore, that the remarks said to have been made by the Government auditors are due to a pure misunderstanding of the position.
('69', 227, 1, 7, 410175) It may be that the Dhulia Board voted a grant for 'Harijan Uplift’and if it has no power to make grants except to educational institutions, Harijan uplift as such might not be classified under grants to education.
('69', 227, 1, 8, 410389) The matter requires further elucidation.
('69', 227, 1, 9, 410430) Any futher comment must be withheld till all the facts of the case are known.
('69', 227, 2, 10, 410508) A VILLAGER'S HUMANITY The reader will be glad to see the following two pictures sent by Miss Mary Barr of Khedi of what I have called “A Villager's Humanity”.
('69', 227, 3, 11, 410667) 1. Yesterday I found an old woman sitting in the wet with her calf.
('69', 227, 3, 12, 410735) I asked her why she did not sit in the verandah (meaning the verandah of Miss Mary Barr's Cottage) with the rest of her party and keep dry.
('69', 227, 3, 13, 410875) (They were some wandering people who had asked leave to camp for 24 hours on the verandah) She replied, 'I am sitting by this ’ëøÊ (calf).
('69', 227, 3, 14, 411014) Its mother is dead.'
('69', 227, 4, 15, 411035) 2. This afternoon I found two donkeys had come on to the verandah out of the rain and my first instinct was to 'shoo’them off as they would spoil the floor.
('69', 227, 4, 16, 411192) They obediently ‘shooed’and I immediately felt ashamed remembering yesterday's old woman and invited them back.
('69', 227, 4, 17, 411304) They came.
('69', 227, 5, 18, 411315) I am sure Tara would be glad to know that HER verandah is sheltering all kinds of men and beasts during these wet days.
('69', 227, 5, 19, 411435) The reference to Tara, i.e., the late Mary Chesley, entirely bears out what I knew of her, and now that her numerous intimate friends have come to know about her premature and unexpected death, I have been receiving touching letters about the qualities of her heart and head.
('69', 227, 5, 20, 411711) From those I copy the following.
('69', 227, 6, 21, 411744) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('69', 228, 0, 1, 411781) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 229
('69', 228, 1, 2, 411824) Polly (Miss Chesley) was built of the stuff from which martyrs are made.
('69', 228, 1, 3, 411897) She never knew fear.
('69', 228, 1, 4, 411918) She was keen pacifist and persuaded me to take the post left vacant at her mother's death as Superintendent of Peace and Arbitration in the W.C.T.U. for Cananda...
('69', 228, 1, 5, 412082) Polly and I worked together to gather money for the Russian and Chinese famines, getting ten thousand dollars.....
('69', 228, 1, 6, 412197) We also collected one thousand dollars for German children's relief.
('69', 228, 2, 7, 412266) A CORRECTION
('69', 228, 3, 8, 412279) With reference to my note ‘Barbarous If True' 1 the President of the Panchayat Board, Devakottai writes: 2
('69', 228, 4, 9, 412386) There has been no objection raised at all at any time by myself or any other member of the Board to the Harijan member taking his seat alongside the other members.
('69', 228, 4, 10, 412550) On the other hand he has been repeatedly requested during each and every meeting to take his seat.
('69', 228, 4, 11, 412649) He has complied with our request during a few of the meetings that were held during the last four months.
('69', 228, 5, 12, 412755) The Harijan member was questioned about the alleged treatment and he has issued a statement...
('69', 228, 5, 13, 412850) that he was never objected to by anybody in the Board in taking his seat, and at times when he hesitated to take his seat along with others as per age long custom, he has been promptly cheered up by the President to take his seat and advised not to get disheartened.
('69', 228, 6, 14, 413117) Finally I wish to inform you that the Harijan member is no doubt sitting along with other members during the whole of the meeting now, and I want to assure you that all facilities are accorded to him by me so that his rights and privileges are duly enjoyed by him.
('69', 228, 7, 15, 413382) I gladly publish this letter.
('69', 228, 7, 16, 413412) I am gladder still to find that the statement published was wholly untrue.
('69', 228, 7, 17, 413487) In these days of suspicion and ferment among Harijans, it is necessary for correspondents to be accurate about the information they give.
('69', 228, 7, 18, 413625) It is worth while knowing how the correspondent came to make the statement which appears to have been without any foundation whatsoever.

('69', 229, 7, 24, 414952) 291. LETTER TO MRIDULA SARABHAI
('69', 229, 8, 25, 414984) SEGAON, WARDHA, July 18, 1936

('69', 231, 0, 1, 416725) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 231, 1, 2, 416767) 294. TALK WITH STUDENTS OF VILLAGE WORKERS’ TRAINING SCHOOL 1
('69', 231, 2, 3, 416829) [July 19,1936] 2
('69', 231, 3, 4, 416846) He 3 does not talk like me; he simply sings bhajans and preaches and teaches through them.
('69', 231, 3, 5, 416937) I must needs talk as I can neither compose nor sing.
('69', 231, 4, 6, 416990) After the entertainment...
('69', 231, 4, 7, 417017) the talk began with a light banter of a student who believes in growing long hair.
('69', 231, 4, 8, 417100) Gandhiji asked him: Is this just for show, or for the sake of health?
('69', 231, 4, 9, 417170) If it is for no particular purpose, why not get rid of it?
('69', 231, 4, 10, 417229) Well, don't you run away with the idea that one can do village work by just going and sitting down in a village.
('69', 231, 4, 11, 417342) To be a real villager is to serve them, and you may remember that to be a real villager is more difficult than to obtain a graduate's degree.
('69', 231, 4, 12, 417484) I have been talking of villages and villagers for the past thirty years, but have been able to come to stay in a village only today.
('69', 231, 4, 13, 417617) And that too is just the stay and no work.
('69', 231, 4, 14, 417660) We eat unpolished rice and hand ground flour, but how can we compel the villagers to do likewise?
('69', 231, 4, 15, 417758) Even if we had the power to do so, we should not exercise it.
('69', 231, 4, 16, 417820) We have to convince them by patient persuasion.
('69', 231, 5, 17, 417868) Q. Without power, can we really achieve much?
('69', 231, 6, 18, 417914) A. Did I not say that even if we had it, we should not use it?
('69', 231, 6, 19, 417977) We have to convert them to our way of thinking.
('69', 231, 6, 20, 418025) We have to bring to bear on them moral pressure.
('69', 231, 7, 21, 418074) Q. If you take such a desperate view, where are we?
('69', 231, 8, 22, 418126) A. I am far from taking a desperate view and it would be wrong to suppose that potentially you are weaker than I. Physically of course there may be considerable difference between you and me, and the spiritual power in you may be dormant in your case, active in my case.
('69', 231, 8, 23, 418397) But this is no task where one could do things as if by magic.
('69', 231, 8, 24, 418459) What magic is there in merely staying in a village?
('69', 231, 8, 25, 418511) Even six months’stay in a village may not by itself achieve anything.
('69', 231, 9, 26, 418581) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's “Weekly Letter”, 25 7 1936 2 According to Mahadev Desai the conversation took place on a Sunday.
('69', 231, 9, 27, 418711) The Sunday prior to July 25 fell on July 19. 3 Tukdoji Maharaj
('69', 232, 0, 1, 418774) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 233
('69', 232, 1, 2, 418817) depends on the spirit in which one goes to stay there.
('69', 232, 1, 3, 418872) We stay for years in cities without affecting the life around us.
('69', 232, 1, 4, 418938) We have to go there as their voluntary servants.
('69', 232, 1, 5, 418987) They come and labour for us in cities for a wage.
('69', 232, 1, 6, 419037) We have to go to villages and labour for them without a wage.
('69', 232, 2, 7, 419099) Q. I see.
('69', 232, 2, 8, 419109) Do the village folk come to see you?
('69', 232, 3, 9, 419146) A. They do, but not without fear, and perhaps even suspicion.
('69', 232, 3, 10, 419208) These also are among the many shortcomings of villagers.
('69', 232, 3, 11, 419265) We have to rid them of these.
('69', 232, 4, 12, 419295) Q. How?
('69', 232, 5, 13, 419303) A. By gently insinuating ourselves into their affections.
('69', 232, 5, 14, 419361) We must disabuse them of the fear that we have gone there to coerce them, we must show them by our behaviour that there in no intention to coerce, nor any selfish motive.
('69', 232, 5, 15, 419532) But this is all patient work.
('69', 232, 5, 16, 419562) You cannot quickly convince them of your bona fides.
('69', 232, 6, 17, 419615) Q. Don't you think that only those who work without any remuneration or allowance can inspire confidence in them, i.e., those who accept nothing whether from any association or from the village?
('69', 232, 7, 18, 419810) They do not even know who is and who is not working for remuneration.
('69', 232, 7, 19, 419880) What does impress them is the way in which we live, our habits, our talks, even our gestures.
('69', 232, 7, 20, 419974) There may be a few who suspect us of a desire to earn; we have to dispel their suspicion no doubt.
('69', 232, 7, 21, 420073) And then do not run away with the feeling that he who accepts nothing from an association or from the villages is by any means an ideal servant.
('69', 232, 7, 22, 420218) He is often a prey to self righteousness which debases one.
('69', 232, 8, 23, 420278) Q. You teach us village crafts.
('69', 232, 8, 24, 420310) Is that to give us a means of earning our livelihood or to enable us to teach the villagers?
('69', 232, 8, 25, 420403) If it is for the latter object, how can we master a craft in the course of a year?
('69', 232, 9, 26, 420486) A. You are being taught the ordinary crafts, because unless you know the principles you will not be able to help people with suggestions.
('69', 232, 9, 27, 420624) The most enterprising among you would certainly earn a living by following a craft.
('69', 232, 9, 28, 420708) Now here you see I had a hut ready made for me, thanks to Jamnalalji and thanks to my 'Mahatmaship'!
('69', 232, 9, 29, 420809) But you will have to build your own hut, unless of course you also get a friend to build it for you—in which case I will say you were old and decrepit like me!
('69', 232, 10, 30, 420969) Q. Shri Rajagopalachariar who was here the other day told us that it was no use our going to villages without mastering a craft, for then we should not be able to
('69', 233, 0, 1, 421132) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 233, 1, 2, 421174) teach them anything.
('69', 233, 1, 3, 421195) You must be better agriculturists than they are, he said, better cobblers, better weavers, and so on.
('69', 233, 2, 4, 421297) A. What he said is true.
('69', 233, 2, 5, 421322) But we have no agricultural course here, because mastery of agriculture would take a century.
('69', 233, 2, 6, 421416) And the things we teach here are such that you are likely to be able to bring to the villagers better knowledge of them.
('69', 233, 2, 7, 421537) We have improved grinding stones and rice husking stones and oil presses.
('69', 233, 2, 8, 421611) We are carrying on experim ents in improving our tools and we have to take the improvements to them.
('69', 233, 2, 9, 421712) Above all there is truth and honesty in business that we have to teach them.
('69', 233, 2, 10, 421789) They adulterate milk, they adulterate oil, they will adulterate truth for petty gain.
('69', 233, 2, 11, 421875) It is not their fault, it is ours.
('69', 233, 2, 12, 421910) We have so long ignored them and only exploited them, never taught them anything better..
('69', 233, 2, 13, 422000) By close contact with them we can easily correct their ways.
('69', 233, 2, 14, 422061) Long neglect and isolation has dulled their intellect and even moral sense.
('69', 233, 2, 15, 422137) We have to brighten them up and revive them all along the line.
('69', 233, 3, 16, 422201) Q. What about the Harijan problem here?
('69', 233, 4, 17, 422241) A. It is as acute as anywhere else.
('69', 233, 5, 18, 422277) Q. There is untouchability as amongst the Harijans?
('69', 233, 6, 19, 422329) A. Of course.
('69', 233, 6, 20, 422343) A Mahar would keep a Bhangi at arm's length.
('69', 233, 6, 21, 422388) Here is a well belonging to Jamnalalji, no public well.
('69', 233, 6, 22, 422444) After consultation with the man in charge of the estate, we decided to declare it open to all the Harijans and invited Mahars, Chamars, Bhangis and others to use it.
('69', 233, 6, 23, 422610) They would not do it.
('69', 233, 6, 24, 422632) They hesitated.
('69', 233, 6, 25, 422648) One or two Mahars then came forward, a Bhangi also came.
('69', 233, 6, 26, 422705) That created an uproar.
('69', 233, 6, 27, 422729) The Harijans stopped using the well, and the tumult has ceased.
('69', 233, 6, 28, 422793) But there it is.
('69', 233, 6, 29, 422810) It is like an armed truce.
('69', 233, 6, 30, 422837) But it is no use blaming them.
('69', 233, 6, 31, 422868) What are we doing?
('69', 233, 6, 32, 422887) I have heard with horror the incident from Rajputana where Harijans would not be suffered to cook their food in ghee and to prepare sweetmeats, and that, because of the perversity of the savarnas, the situation reached such a pass that firing had to be resorted to and three savarnas were killed.
('69', 233, 6, 33, 423184) It is a tremendous problem.
('69', 233, 6, 34, 423212) Now, can we who have not cast out untouchability expect the Harijans to cast it out from their midst in a moment?
('69', 233, 7, 35, 423326) Harijan, 25 7 1936

('69', 234, 7, 15, 423864) 296. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('69', 234, 8, 16, 423896) WARDHA, July 20, 1936
('69', 234, 9, 17, 423918) GANGABEHN,
('69', 234, 10, 18, 423929) I have your letter.
('69', 234, 10, 19, 423949) Even if somebody offers a big donation, do not spend money received from outside on the sanitation work.
('69', 234, 10, 20, 424054) I have forbidden the spending of even a single rupee in the village here where sanitation work is being carried on, for then people miss the education.
('69', 234, 10, 21, 424206) We should work as hard as we can but must not spend money.
('69', 234, 10, 22, 424265) Let the work remain incomplete till the people themselves are prepared to pay for it.
('69', 234, 10, 23, 424351) We may ourselves do the sweeping, remove the night soil and bury it.
('69', 234, 10, 24, 424420) But until the people put up latrines with their own money, let them relieve themselves in the open.
('69', 234, 10, 25, 424520) We may instruct people in the ways but they must themselves find the means.
('69', 234, 10, 26, 424596) The Taluka Board may find the money.
('69', 234, 10, 27, 424633) It may not cost more than ten or twenty rupees.
('69', 234, 10, 28, 424681) If you do not follow all this, ask me again.
('69', 234, 10, 29, 424726) Have no doubt that sanitation work and educating the people with regard to a healthy diet is the only real medical service.
('69', 234, 10, 30, 424850) Why should not Shamalbhai, Shivabhai and the other men staying there join the sanitation work?
('69', 234, 10, 31, 424945) It will be enough to devote one hour daily.

('69', 239, 4, 9, 430664) 305. ARE WE RIVALS?
('69', 239, 5, 10, 430684) [On or before July 22,1936] 1
('69', 239, 6, 11, 430714) I have had two typical cuttings sent to me giving altogether false news about relations between Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and myself.
('69', 239, 6, 12, 430846) Remarks said to have been made by me have been reproduced in quotation marks.
('69', 239, 6, 13, 430924) Thus I am reported to have said, “My life work is ruined” (i.e., by Jawaharlal's programme); “not even the firmness and repression of the British Government have harmed my work as much as the policy outlined by Nehru.” 2
('69', 239, 7, 14, 431145) I have never said anything of the kind nor uttered one single remark attributed to me in the two articles sent to me.
('69', 239, 7, 15, 431263) What is more, I have not even entertained the opinions contained in them.
('69', 239, 7, 16, 431337) So far as I am aware, Jawaharlal has come to the conclusion that India's freedom cannot be gained by violent means and that it can be gained by non violent means.
('69', 239, 7, 17, 431500) And I know for a fact that he did not in Lucknow “come out for the use of violence in the struggle for Indepe ndence”.
('69', 239, 8, 18, 431619) No doubt there are differences of opinion between us.
('69', 239, 8, 19, 431673) They were clearly set forth in the letters we exchanged some years ago, and in reply to correspondents I hope at an early date to bring our differences up to date.
('69', 239, 8, 20, 431837) But they do not affect our personal relations in any way whatsoever.
('69', 239, 8, 21, 431906) We remain the same adherents to the Congress goal that we have ever been.
('69', 239, 8, 22, 431980) My life work is not, cannot be, ruined by Jawaharlal's programme, nor have I ever believed for that matter that it
('69', 239, 9, 23, 432095) 1 The report in The Hindustan Times carrying this item is dated July 22,1936. 2 This was reported in the Literary Digest.
('69', 239, 9, 24, 432217) 3 This was reported by Unity; vide footnote 2, “Letter to Amrit Kaur”, 18 11 1935
('69', 240, 0, 1, 432299) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 241
('69', 240, 1, 2, 432342) has been harmed even by “the firmness and repression of the British Government”.
('69', 240, 1, 3, 432423) My philosophy, if I can be said to have any, excludes the possibility of harm to one’s cause by outside agencies.
('69', 240, 1, 4, 432537) The harm comes deservedly and only when the cause itself is bad, or being good its champions are untrue, faint hearted, or unclean.
('69', 240, 1, 5, 432669) The article in question refers to “Gandhiji’s secret plans”.
('69', 240, 1, 6, 432730) 1 If I know Gandhi at all I can vouchsafe for it that he never had any secret plans in his life.
('69', 240, 1, 7, 432827) And if beyond what the readers of Harijan know there is no plan that I can disclose, it is because I know none myself.
('69', 240, 1, 8, 432946) Then one of the articles presents Jawaharlal and me as rivals.
('69', 240, 1, 9, 433009) I cannot think of myself as a rival to Jawaharlal or him to me.
('69', 240, 1, 10, 433073) Or if we are, we are rivals in making love to each other in the pursuit of the common goal, and if in the joint work for reaching the goal we at times seem to be taking different routes, I hope the world will find that we had lost sight of each other only for the moment and only to meet again with greater mutual attraction and affection.

('69', 246, 9, 25, 442642) 317. AVOIDABLE MISERY
('69', 246, 10, 26, 442664) From a correspondent's long letter of wail I take the following.
('69', 246, 11, 27, 442729) This letter is one out of many such.
('69', 246, 11, 28, 442766) The majority of letters are written in Hindi.
('69', 246, 11, 29, 442812) But we know that English education has made things
('69', 246, 12, 30, 442863) 1 Vide the following item.
('69', 246, 12, 31, 442890) 2 Vide the preceding item.
('69', 246, 12, 32, 442917) 3 Not reproduced here.
('69', 246, 12, 33, 442940) The correspondent, a father of seven daughters, had dwelt on his straitened circumstances and sought Gandhiji's help in meeting the expenses of one of his daughter's marriage.
('69', 247, 0, 1, 443116) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 247, 1, 2, 443158) no better for parents of daughters.
('69', 247, 1, 3, 443194) In some cases they have become worse in that the market price of possible young men who would suit an English educated daughter of an English educated father suffers an appreciable increase.
('69', 247, 1, 4, 443385) In a case like the Bengali father's the best help that can be rendered is not a loan or a gift of the required sum, but it should consist in persuading and strengthening the parent to refuse to purchase a match for his daughter but choose or let the daughter choose one who would marry her for love, not for money.
('69', 247, 1, 5, 443700) This means a voluntary extension of the field of choice.
('69', 247, 1, 6, 443757) There must be a breach in the double wall of caste and province.
('69', 247, 1, 7, 443822) If India is one and indivisible, surely there should be no artificial divisions creating innumerable little groups which would neither inter dine nor intermarry.
('69', 247, 1, 8, 443984) There is no religion in this cruel custom.
('69', 247, 1, 9, 444027) It would not do to plead that individuals cannot make the commencement and that they must wait till the whole society is ripe for the change.
('69', 247, 1, 10, 444169) No reform has ever been brought about except through intrepid individuals breaking down inhuman customs or usages.
('69', 247, 1, 11, 444284) And after all what hardships can the schoolmaster suffer if he and his daughters refused to treat marriage as a marketable transaction instead of a status or a sacrament which it undoubtedly is.
('69', 247, 1, 12, 444479) I would, therefore, advise my correspondent courageously to give up the idea of borrowing or begging and to save the four hundred rupees he can get on his life policy by choosing in consultation with his daughter a suitable husband no matter to what caste or province he belongs.
('69', 247, 2, 13, 444759) Harijan, 25 7 1936
('69', 247, 3, 14, 444778) 318. IN WATERLESS SALEM
('69', 247, 4, 15, 444802) The Secretary, Salem District Harijan Sevak Sangh, writes:
('69', 247, 5, 16, 444861) The District is dry and the Harijans are not allowed to take water from the wells owned by caste Hindus.
('69', 247, 5, 17, 444966) The Gandhi Ashram has provided wells in two or three villages.
('69', 247, 5, 18, 445029) In the village of Avangier the Harijans are now depending on the visit of the railway engine to the railway station for their drinking water supply.
('69', 247, 5, 19, 445178) The engine driver doles out some water and the villagers have to be content with that.
('69', 247, 5, 20, 445265) There is another place called Managalapuram where water scarcity is severe.
('69', 247, 5, 21, 445341) This reveals a shocking state of affairs.
('69', 247, 5, 22, 445383) No private organization can ever cope with this terrible distress.
('69', 247, 5, 23, 445450) As it is, Salem District has a
('69', 248, 0, 1, 445481) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 249
('69', 248, 1, 2, 445524) perpetual scarcity of water.
('69', 248, 1, 3, 445553) And when to this is added scarcity of common fellow feeling on the part of a large part of its inhabitants, the distress becomes unbearable as it has become in the case of Harijans in Salem District.
('69', 248, 1, 4, 445753) Is it not the first duty of the District Board to ensure a regular supply of water for the Harijans the most neglected and yet the most useful servants of society?
('69', 248, 1, 5, 445917) And now that the Government of Madras has a department dealing with difficulties of such classes as Harijans, one may hope to hear less and less of scarcity of pure water for Harijans.
('69', 248, 1, 6, 446102) But this is not to mean that Harijan sevaks are to relax their vigilanice or that private charity need not concern itself with water supply to Harijans.
('69', 248, 1, 7, 446255) Aid must reach Harijans in the shape of water no matter from what source it comes.
('69', 248, 1, 8, 446338) And it will come only when all sources combine to cope effectively with the distress.
('69', 248, 2, 9, 446424) Harijan, 25 7 1936

Moonje's proposal, accepted by Dr. Ambedkar, was as follows: “ If Dr. Ambedkar were to announce his decision that he and his followers are prepared to embrace Sikhism in preference to Islam and Christianity, and that he shall honestly and sincerely cooperate with the Hindus and the Sikhs in propagating their culture and in counteracting the Moslem movement for drawing the Depressed Classes into the Moslem fold, the Hindu Mahasabha will be prepared, in view of their having agreed to remain within the Hindu culture, to make an announcement that it will not object: (I) To the conversion of the Depressed classes to Sikhism (ii) To the inclusion of the neo Sikhs in the list of the Scheduled Castes; and (iii) To the enjoyment by the Depressed Classes of the political rights of the Poona Pact by free competition between the non Sikh and the neo Sikh Depressed Classes as provided for under the Poona Pact.” For Gandhiji's views, vide” Letter to B.S. ('69', 257, 3, 5, 459147) on behalf of the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('69', 257, 3, 6, 459185) Gandhiji cannot be expected to tour as he did in 1933 34 for collections and stirring public conscience.

('69', 257, 6, 14, 459925) July 30, 1936
('69', 257, 7, 15, 459939) I heartily endorse this appeal 3. Removal of untouchability is a matter of change of heart.
('69', 257, 7, 16, 460031) Hearts are not changed by expenditure of money however wise it may be.
('69', 257, 7, 17, 460102) The change will come when we have enough selfless spiritually minded workers.
('69', 257, 7, 18, 460180) Monetary contributions will be an effective test of the existence of such persons.

('69', 259, 0, 1, 462214) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 259, 1, 2, 462256) 338. LETTER TO ANANDSHANKAR B. DHRUVA
('69', 259, 2, 3, 462294) July 30, 1936 1
('69', 259, 3, 4, 462310) SUJNA BHAISHRI (PROF.
('69', 259, 3, 5, 462332) DHRUVA) 2,
('69', 259, 4, 6, 462343) I have carefully gone through both your letters to Mahadev.
('69', 259, 4, 7, 462403) What I want is not something for the learned but something which Harijans and workers can understand and put into practice.
('69', 259, 4, 8, 462527) I do not want you to make a fresh study, but only that form your wide knowl edge you should send me something which you can write in...
('69', 259, 4, 9, 462663) 3 hours or at the most in eight hours.
('69', 259, 4, 10, 462702) I had already written to you that I liked your book on Hindu religion very much.
('69', 259, 4, 11, 462783) I will certainly read it again.
('69', 259, 4, 12, 462815) But I do not wantextracts from anything.
('69', 259, 4, 13, 462856) For a moment imagine yourself among Harijans in a village, converse with the old men, women and children and teach them religion.
('69', 259, 4, 14, 462986) I want whatever is available in this way and it should have your stamp.
('69', 259, 4, 15, 463058) Mahadev won't even translate it into English.
('69', 259, 4, 16, 463104) The testimonial you give him is deserved, but first he hasn't the time and then I want your language.
('69', 259, 4, 17, 463206) It is not beyond you to write simple English and finally you will grant the two of us the right to make some suggestions.
('69', 259, 4, 18, 463328) Won't you?
('69', 259, 4, 19, 463339) The suggestions will be put into the writing only if you approve of them.
('69', 259, 4, 20, 463413) Now about your programme.
('69', 259, 4, 21, 463439) Going through it I am scared.
('69', 259, 4, 22, 463469) At the moment Gujarat or Hindu religion does not require scholarship.
('69', 259, 4, 23, 463539) That will not save either religion or India or Gujarat.
('69', 259, 4, 24, 463595) I do not mean to say that there is absolutely no need for scholarship.
('69', 259, 4, 25, 463666) There are many who will give us scholarly writings.
('69', 259, 4, 26, 463718) But there are very few religious enthusiasts who would make themselves one with the people.

('69', 265, 1, 2, 471869) 347. DISCUSSION WITH VISITORS 1
('69', 265, 2, 3, 471901) [Before August 1, 1936]
('69', 265, 3, 4, 471925) The sadhu or the Buva 2 who is for the moment a member of the family has for visitors a number of devotees.
('69', 265, 3, 5, 472033) They are frankly surprised that the sadhu is not only associating with the Mahatma but eats under his roof food cooked by a Harijan boy....They come and argue, sometimes the sadhu cannot solve their doubts and difficulties and they turn to Gandhiji.
('69', 265, 4, 6, 472283) [A VISITOR:] But, even the lower creation observes untouchability, Mahatmaji, and you would have even man to shed it!
('69', 265, 4, 7, 472401) [GANDHIJI:] Now that's something novel.
('69', 265, 4, 8, 472441) Let me understand.
('69', 265, 5, 9, 472460) Donkeys don't associate with dogs; a crow would not touch a pigeon's eggs.
('69', 265, 5, 10, 472535) Every species has its own sphere, its own place, its own use in God's creation.
('69', 265, 5, 11, 472615) But cows, donkeys and dogs will gladly remain under the same roof if you feed them and own them.
('69', 265, 5, 12, 472712) And do you hold that there is the same difference between you and an untouchable, as there is between a cow and a dog?
('69', 265, 6, 13, 472831) Don't we shun wild animals?
('69', 265, 6, 14, 472859) You shun lions and tigers and snakes, because they are untouchable?
('69', 265, 6, 15, 472927) Absurd!
('69', 265, 6, 16, 472935) You shun them because you fear them.
('69', 265, 6, 17, 472972) You would fain tame them if you could, and crowds flock and attribute miraculous powers to one who can domesticate them.
('69', 265, 7, 18, 473093) But we don't touch pigs because they are dirty, and not because we are afraid of them.
('69', 265, 7, 19, 473180) Well, then, supposing a man in cleaner clothes looked upon you as dirty and regarded you as an untouchable, you won't mind?
('69', 265, 7, 20, 473304) And what of your women who do all the dirty jobs for your children?
('69', 265, 7, 21, 473372) They are the mistresses of the family.
('69', 265, 7, 22, 473411) Why so?
('69', 265, 7, 23, 473419) Well, then, supposing the so called untouchables were dressed as well as you, and washed themselves clean after doing the dirty jobs for you, and for which you should thank them rather than despise or shun them, would you touch them?
('69', 265, 7, 24, 473653) Supposing they ate clean food and did not touch beef or carrion, would you touch them?
('69', 265, 7, 25, 473740) I tell you there are numerous so called Harijans in India who satisfy all these conditions, who live cleaner and purer lives than we do and yet we regard them as
('69', 265, 8, 26, 473902) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's “Weekly Letter” 2 Tukdoji Maharaj
('69', 266, 0, 1, 473969) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 267
('69', 266, 1, 2, 474012) untouchables.
('69', 266, 1, 3, 474026) How will God forgive this heinous sin of ours?
('69', 266, 2, 4, 474073) But you want us to admit them to the temples too!
('69', 266, 2, 5, 474123) How can people doing dirty jobs be admitted to temples?
('69', 266, 2, 6, 474179) Have I ever asked them to go to temples with baskets of filth on their heads?
('69', 266, 2, 7, 474257) Have I not said that they would satisfy all the conditions about bath and cleanliness that the other Hindus satisfy?
('69', 266, 2, 8, 474374) According to you all surgeons and all nurses are unfit to go to our temples!

('69', 266, 4, 10, 474469) 348. DISCUSSION WITH A FRIEND 1
('69', 266, 5, 11, 474501) [Before August 1, 1936]
('69', 266, 6, 12, 474525) [FRIEND:] Why do you insist on eight hours’manual work a day?
('69', 266, 6, 13, 474587) Is it not possible in a well ordered society to reduce the working day to two hours and leave the citizen ample leisure for intellectual and artistic pursuits?
('69', 266, 6, 14, 474747) [GANDHIJI:] We know that those who get all that leisure—both the working and the intellectual class—do not make the best use of it.
('69', 266, 6, 15, 474879) In fact we too often find the idle mind being turned into the devil's workshop.
('69', 266, 7, 16, 474959) No; he would not be idling away.
('69', 266, 7, 17, 474992) Supposing we divided the day into two hours’physical labour and six hours’intellectual labour; would it not be good for the nation?
('69', 266, 7, 18, 475124) I do not know that it would be feasible.
('69', 266, 7, 19, 475165) I have not mathem atically calculated it, but if a man will do the intellectual labour only for profit and not for the nation, I am sure that the scheme will break down; unless of course the State pays him amply for the two hours’labour and compels him to do other work without paying him anything.
('69', 266, 7, 20, 475464) That would be a fine thing, but it cannot be done without a kind of State conscription.
('69', 266, 8, 21, 475552) But take for instance you.
('69', 266, 8, 22, 475579) You cannot in the nature of things do eight hour's physical labour, and have to do eight hours’or more intellectual work.
('69', 266, 8, 23, 475701) You do not abuse your leisure?
('69', 266, 8, 24, 475732) It is compulsory work and leaves no leisure, as for instance it would if I was going out to play tennis.
('69', 266, 8, 25, 475837) But I tell you even taking my case that I am sure our minds would have been infinitely better if we
('69', 266, 9, 26, 475937) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's “Weekly Letter”
('69', 267, 0, 1, 475986) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 267, 1, 2, 476028) laboured with our hands for eight hours.
('69', 267, 1, 3, 476069) We would not have a single idle thought, and I may tell you that my mind is not entirely free from idle thoughts.
('69', 267, 1, 4, 476183) Even now I am what I am because I realized the value of physical labour at a very early stage of my life.
('69', 267, 2, 5, 476289) But then if physical work has such inherent virtue, our people have been working more than eight hours a day, not with any appreciable effect on the purity or strength of their minds.
('69', 267, 2, 6, 476473) Physical labour by itself is not an education even as mental labour is not.
('69', 267, 2, 7, 476549) It has been with our people deadly drudgery without their knowing this, and that deadens one's finer instincts.
('69', 267, 2, 8, 476661) That is where I have my strongest complaint against the savarna Hindus.
('69', 267, 2, 9, 476733) They have rendered work for the proletariat a task of hard drudgery, from which they have no pleasure and in which they have no interest.
('69', 267, 2, 10, 476871) If they had been considered members of the society enjoying the same status as they, theirs would have been the proudest position in life.
('69', 267, 2, 11, 477010) This is supposed to be the Kaliyuga.
('69', 267, 2, 12, 477047) In the Satyayuga, or golden age, whenever it was, the society I dare say was better ordered than today.
('69', 267, 2, 13, 477151) Ours is an ancient land where civilizations have come and gone, and it is difficult to say what exactly we were like in a particular age.
('69', 267, 2, 14, 477289) But there is no doubt that we are where we are because we have long neglected the Shudras.
('69', 267, 2, 15, 477380) Today's village culture, if culture it can be called, is an awful culture.
('69', 267, 2, 16, 477455) The villagers live as worse than animals.
('69', 267, 2, 17, 477497) Nature compels animals to work and live naturally.
('69', 267, 2, 18, 477548) We have so dabased our working classes that they cannot work and live naturally, If our people had laboured intelligently and with joy, we should have been quite different today.
('69', 267, 3, 19, 477727) Work and culture cannot be separated, then?
('69', 267, 3, 20, 477771) They tried to do it in ancient Rome and failed miserably.
('69', 267, 3, 21, 477829) Culture without labour, or culture which is not the fruit of labour, would be 'Vomitoria’as a Roman Catholic writer says.
('69', 267, 3, 22, 477951) The Romans made indulgence a habit, and were ruined.
('69', 267, 3, 23, 478004) Man cannot develop his mind by simply writing and reading or making speeches all day long.
('69', 267, 3, 24, 478095) All my reading I tell you was done in the leisure hours I got in jails, and I have benefited by it because all of it was done not desultorily but for some purpose.
('69', 267, 3, 25, 478259) And though I have worked physically for days and months for eight hours on end I don't think I suffered from mental decay.
('69', 267, 3, 26, 478382) I have often walked as much as 40 miles a day and yet never felt dull.
('69', 267, 4, 27, 478453) But you had this mental equipment.
('69', 268, 0, 1, 478488) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 269
('69', 268, 1, 2, 478531) No fear.
('69', 268, 1, 3, 478540) You don't know how mediocre I was at school and in England.
('69', 268, 1, 4, 478600) I had never the courage to speak at debating society meetings or even in a gathering of vegetarians.
('69', 268, 1, 5, 478701) Don't you run away with the thought that I was blessed with any extraordinary powers.
('69', 268, 1, 6, 478787) God, I think, advisedly did not give me then the power to speak.
('69', 268, 1, 7, 478852) You must know, among us I am the least read man.
('69', 268, 2, 8, 478901) Harijan, 1 8 1936
('69', 268, 3, 9, 478919) 349. DISCUSSION WITH STUDENTS OF VILLAGE WORKERS’TRAINING SCHOOL 1
('69', 268, 4, 10, 478986) [Before August 1, 1936]
('69', 268, 5, 11, 479010) Q. How to dipossess people of ill gotten gains which is what the Socialists are out to do?
('69', 268, 6, 12, 479101) A. Who is to judge what gains or riches are ill gotten or well gotten?
('69', 268, 6, 13, 479172) God alone can judge, or a competent authority appointed both by the 'haves’and the 'have nots’can judge.
('69', 268, 6, 14, 479277) Not anyone and everyone.
('69', 268, 6, 15, 479302) But if you say that All property and possession is theft, all must give up property and wealth.
('69', 268, 6, 16, 479398) Have we given it up?
('69', 268, 6, 17, 479419) Let us make a beginning, expecting the rest of follow.
('69', 268, 6, 18, 479474) For those who are convinced that their own possessions are ill gotten, there is of course no other alternative but to give them up.
('69', 268, 7, 19, 479606) Q. What is the root of violence?
('69', 268, 7, 20, 479639) Does it not take place to prevent injustice and humiliation?
('69', 268, 8, 21, 479700) A. Hardly.
('69', 268, 8, 22, 479711) The root of violence is selfishness, anger, lust, etc.
('69', 268, 9, 23, 479766) Q. I have not made myself understood.
('69', 268, 9, 24, 479804) I see in front of me terrible wrong being done and I am provoked to violence.
('69', 268, 9, 25, 479882) Is not the wrong at the root of it?
('69', 268, 9, 26, 479918) A. No, anger is at the root of your violence.
('69', 268, 9, 27, 479964) Whether your violence is justified or not on such an occasion is another question, but there is no doubt that anger is at the root.
('69', 268, 10, 28, 480096) Q. How to deal with beggars?
('69', 268, 10, 29, 480125) How can we turn them away when we see they are famishing?
('69', 268, 11, 30, 480183) A. Beggars must be distinguished from famishing people.
('69', 268, 11, 31, 480239) Beggars are often enough sturdy.
('69', 268, 11, 32, 480272) Some are theives.
('69', 268, 11, 33, 480290) There is nothing like a right to beg, there is certainly a right to ask for work.
('69', 268, 11, 34, 480372) And whilst
('69', 268, 12, 35, 480383) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's “Weekly Letter”
('69', 269, 0, 1, 480432) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 269, 1, 2, 480474) you may not give alms, it is your duty to give work to those who ask for it.
('69', 269, 2, 3, 480551) Q. But how are you going to do it when you have work for four and eight turn up?
('69', 269, 2, 4, 480632) Will you engage all the eight?
('69', 269, 3, 5, 480663) A. No, because I must recognize my limitations.
('69', 269, 4, 6, 480711) Q. Then they will beg rather than starve?
('69', 269, 5, 7, 480753) A. They shall not beg.
('69', 269, 5, 8, 480776) They must do some work.
('69', 269, 5, 9, 480800) I have not yet settled down in Segaon.
('69', 269, 5, 10, 480839) When I do so I shall see that no one goes away for want of work.
('69', 269, 5, 11, 480904) I will have spinning wheels and chakkis for those who being in want of work ask for it.
('69', 269, 6, 12, 480992) Q. When we go to villages we are bound to come up against opposition.
('69', 269, 6, 13, 481062) For instance, they are opposed to sanitation work.
('69', 269, 6, 14, 481113) What are we to do?
('69', 269, 7, 15, 481132) A. We have to put up with the opposition.
('69', 269, 8, 16, 481174) Q. They boycott us, they will not allow us to use their wells.
('69', 269, 9, 17, 481237) A. They may; we will use other wells, but we shall not fight them.
('69', 269, 9, 18, 481304) We will not provoke them, but argue with them until they understand.
('69', 269, 9, 19, 481373) We have to face all kinds of difficulties.
('69', 269, 10, 20, 481416) Q. My difficulty is that if my sanitation work scares people away, if they will not attend the prayers, if they will not do even spinning, must I persist?
('69', 269, 11, 21, 481571) A. It depends on the spirit in which you have sat down there.
('69', 269, 11, 22, 481633) If you have gone there principally for sanitation work, you will certainly not give it up, whatever happens.
('69', 269, 11, 23, 481742) After all we will certainly do our own sanitation, keep our own surroundings clean.
('69', 269, 11, 24, 481826) But it is open to one to begin with spinning, night classes, etc., and go on to sanitation if one thinks that would enable one to do one's work easier.
('69', 269, 12, 25, 481978) Harijan, 1 8 1936
('69', 269, 13, 26, 481996) 350. A COBWEB OF MISUNDERSTANDINGS
('69', 269, 14, 27, 482031) I have before me a number of cuttings from various Urdu papers severely and even bitterly criticizing the proceedings 1 of the recently formed Bharatiya Sahitya Parishad and thereanent Babu Rajendra Prasad, Babu Purushottamdas Tandon, Pandit Jawaharlal and me.
('69', 269, 14, 28, 482292) They attribute motives and designs to which, I know, we are all strangers.
('69', 269, 14, 29, 482367) The writers have not taken the trouble of even understanding what was said or done by us or at the Parishad.
('69', 269, 15, 30, 482476) 1 At Nagpur; vide “Speech at Akhil Bharatiya Sahitya Parishad”, 24 4 1936
('69', 270, 0, 1, 482550) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 271
('69', 270, 1, 2, 482593) they think that the design at the bottom of the Association is to push Hindi at the expense of Urdu, and so to Sanskritize Hindi as to make it almost impossible for Mussalmans to understand it.
('69', 270, 1, 3, 482787) They also infer from a speech of Babu Purushottamdas Tandon delivered at Allahabad at the time of the opening of the Literary Museum of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan that he distorted facts when he claimed that there were nearly 23 crores of Indians who spoke or at least understood Hindi.
('69', 270, 1, 4, 483074) There are in these writings other innuendoes which I need not notice, my purpose being simply to remove if possible the misunderstandings that have led to the innuendoes.
('69', 270, 1, 5, 483245) To take the last first.
('69', 270, 1, 6, 483269) If the writers had the whole speech of Tandonji before them they would have known that in the 23 crores he deliberately included the Urdu speaking Hindus and Mussal mans.
('69', 270, 1, 7, 483440) He therefore included Urdu in the use of the word Hindi.
('69', 270, 1, 8, 483497) This will be clear if it is borne in mind that Hindi according to the resolution adopted at Indore in 1935, 1 to which Tandonji was party, meant that language which was spoken in the North by Hindus and Mussalmans and was written either in Devanagari or Urdu scripts.
('69', 270, 1, 9, 483765) If the writers had known this definition, surely they would have had no complaint on any account unless they objected to the very name Hindi.
('69', 270, 1, 10, 483907) If they did, it was deplorable.
('69', 270, 1, 11, 483939) Hindi is the original word for the language of the North.
('69', 270, 1, 12, 483997) Urdu, as is well known, was the name specially given for a special purpose.
('69', 270, 1, 13, 484073) The script was also a graft for the convenience of the Muslim rulers.
('69', 270, 1, 14, 484143) If that is the historical sequence, there ought not to be any opposition to the use of the word 'Hindi’so long as it is used inclusively.
('69', 270, 1, 15, 484281) In any event at the most the difference, if there must be any, narrows itself down to the use of one word or the other for signifying the same thing.
('69', 270, 1, 16, 484431) The complaint about Sanskritizing has some justification in that some writers of Hindi insist on unnecessarily introducing Sanskrit words in their writings.
('69', 270, 1, 17, 484588) A similar charge can justly be brought against some Urdu writers who insist on equally unnecessarily introducing Persian or Arabic words.
('69', 270, 1, 18, 484726) And what is worse, they even alter the grammar of the language.
('69', 270, 1, 19, 484790) These extremes are bound to disappear in course of time because they would never be adopted by the masses.
('69', 270, 1, 20, 484897) A speech that is beyond the comprehension of the masses has but a brief existence.
('69', 270, 2, 21, 484980) 1 At the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan held from April 20 to 23; vide “ Two Good Resolutions”, 4 5 1935
('69', 271, 0, 1, 485077) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 271, 1, 2, 485119) As for the Bharatiya Sahitya Parishad, it aims at making through Hindi as above defined available to the whole of India the best thought in the provinces.
('69', 271, 1, 3, 485274) Surely there is in this nothing sinister or communal, as suggested in some writings.
('69', 271, 1, 4, 485359) The adoption of 'Hindi Hindustani’was at my instance.
('69', 271, 1, 5, 485413) It was adopted in order to bring out in a compound word the meaning of the definition of Hindi.
('69', 271, 1, 6, 485509) Moulvi Abdul Kadar Sahib had suggested the use either only of Hindustani or Hindi Urdu instead of Hindi Hindustani.
('69', 271, 1, 7, 485625) I should personally have no objection to either course, but the Bharatiya Sahitya Parishad could not ignore its own origin.
('69', 271, 1, 8, 485749) The idea was born at the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan at Indore and took a definite shape at Nagpur under its aegis.
('69', 271, 1, 9, 485860) The retention of the word 'Hindi’was therefore necessary in the nature of things.
('69', 271, 1, 10, 485942) The substitution of Urdu would have been bad for the reasons I have already stated.
('69', 271, 1, 11, 486026) But as I have endeavoured to show, Hindi, Hindustani and Urdu are synon ymous terms and refer substantially to the same language.
('69', 271, 2, 12, 486156) Harijan, 1 8 1936
('69', 271, 3, 13, 486174) 351. A CRIMINAL TRIBE
('69', 271, 4, 14, 486196) Perhaps there are not many places on this globe where crime is the profession of tribes as it is in India and it flourishes under the garb of religion.
('69', 271, 4, 15, 486348) We have therefore in this country a law called the Criminal Tribes Act.
('69', 271, 4, 16, 486420) The Aheris of Hissar District are supposed to be one of such tribes.
('69', 271, 4, 17, 486489) On 7th June a conference of Aheris was held in the village of Gangan Kheri under the presidentship of Lala Thakurdas Bhargava.
('69', 271, 4, 18, 486616) It was attended by over 1,000 Aheris and over 200 savarna Hindus.
('69', 271, 4, 19, 486682) From the report before me it appears that the Aheris were told by some persons that if they embraced Islam they would be helped to become free from the application of the Act and the stigma of being a criminal tribe would no longer attach to them.
('69', 271, 4, 20, 486930) Therefore the Aheris assembled declared their 'undying faith’in Hinduism and appealed to the Government to free them from the application of the Act.
('69', 271, 4, 21, 487080) In these days of ferment mere conferences and resolutions will not prevent appeals for conversions against material inducements nor bring the freedom sought.
('69', 271, 4, 22, 487238) The only way to avert danger of defection and to procure freedom from special hardships is self purification and selfless continuous service of the depressed people by the savarnas.
('69', 271, 4, 23, 487420) Criminal tribes and untouchable castes are a scourge upon Hindu
('69', 272, 0, 1, 487484) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 273
('69', 272, 1, 2, 487527) society for its godless treatment of its own members in the sacred name of religion.
('69', 272, 1, 3, 487612) You cannot have a diseased limb without the whole body being affected.
('69', 272, 1, 4, 487683) Therefore the only effective method is reform from within.
('69', 272, 1, 5, 487742) If the whole society is purified, it will be immune from external attacks, no matter how fierce they are.
('69', 272, 1, 6, 487848) Conversely, no battling against external attacks can prevent internal disintegration.
('69', 272, 1, 7, 487934) Indeed the energy expended in repelling external attacks must result in further exhaustion and therefore speedier destruction.
('69', 272, 1, 8, 488061) I hope that the respon sible savarna Hindus who attended the Conference will continue the work begun at the Conference and direct their energy in constructive channels.
('69', 272, 2, 9, 488230) Harijan, 1 8 1936

('69', 286, 7, 13, 512163) The Gujarati translator and publisher is Shekh Umarbhai Mohmedbhai and the pamphlet is printed in Ahmedabad.
('69', 286, 7, 14, 512272) I take the following 2 from the correspondent’s letter.
('69', 286, 8, 15, 512328) Permit me to send you a copy of a pamphlet published...with a view to induce Harijans for conversion to Islam and create hatred among them against Hindus.
('69', 286, 8, 16, 512483) This pamphlet is full of such remarks about the Hindu religion and the Hindu rites as are not only false but are likely to intensify the communal tension....
('69', 286, 9, 17, 512641) You will kindly...suggest the course to be adopted so that these poor and illiterate Harijan people may not be entrapped by such false and inflammatory pamphlets.
('69', 286, 9, 18, 512804) I had the pain of going through the pamphlet.
('69', 286, 9, 19, 512850) It is as mischievous as it has been described by the correspondent.
('69', 286, 9, 20, 512918) It is in the form of a dialogue between two Harijans, father and son.
('69', 286, 9, 21, 512988) At the instance of the father the son reads Hindu scriptures and ridicules them.
('69', 286, 9, 22, 513069) Everything held sacred by Hindus is caricatured so as to excite disgust towards Hinduism and savarna Hindus.
('69', 286, 9, 23, 513178) Even the sacred name of Swami Shraddhanandji has been dragged in the discussion and words have been put into his mouth which I hold him to be incapable
('69', 286, 10, 24, 513330) 1 Not reproduced here

('69', 287, 1, 2, 513431) of having uttered.
('69', 287, 1, 3, 513450) Here is a sentence which no gentleman would write of his fellow men: “Some Hindus sit in squares smeared with cow dung as if they were sitting to evacuate themselves.
('69', 287, 1, 4, 513617) Cursed be such eaters.” the pamphlet is full of distortions.
('69', 287, 1, 5, 513678) And it holds out material hopes to Harijans which can hardly be fulfilled especially about the mass of Harijans if they are ever tempted to forsake their ancestral faith.
('69', 287, 1, 6, 513849) Thus the Moulvi who is responsible for the conversion of the Harijan’s son is represented to be a convert from being a Chamar and having married a girl belonging to a noble Muslim family.
('69', 287, 1, 7, 514037) The new convert drinks from the same cup as the Moulvi and the remains of the water are drunk by the company.
('69', 287, 1, 8, 514147) He is treated to a feast at a Munshi’s palatial house.
('69', 287, 1, 9, 514202) The feast fills the dining hall with fragrance.
('69', 287, 1, 10, 514250) “Every morsel was a nectar, every potion the water of life,” and this erstwhile Harijan is treated to the inhalation of a hookah which goes the round of the whole company.
