('69', 287, 2, 20, 515373) 373. NOTES
('69', 287, 3, 21, 515384) WHEELERS, NOT SHOULDERS Shri C. Tejpal has for years been conducting a campaign in favour of using light vehicles instead of shoulders for carrying dead bodies.
('69', 287, 3, 22, 515545) He knows that he has to fight against a sentiment cherished by millions of Hindus and Mussalmans from times immemorial.
('69', 287, 3, 23, 515665) Persons
('69', 288, 0, 1, 515673) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 289
('69', 288, 1, 2, 515716) vie with one another in giving their shoulders for carrying the dead.
('69', 288, 1, 3, 515786) The carrying of corpses on human shoulders is an impressive sight.
('69', 288, 1, 4, 515853) So at any rate we have been used to think.
('69', 288, 1, 5, 515896) But apart from sentiment there is nothing to recommend the practice.
('69', 288, 1, 6, 515965) Where the burial ground or the crematorium is some distance from the place where death occurs, carrying on shoulders becomes a trying task.
('69', 288, 1, 7, 516105) Again when a caste has only a few members, or it is a poor man who has lost a relative, no matter how near the place of disposal is the question assumes serious proportions.
('69', 288, 1, 8, 516279) And we know that in times of plague and famine corpses are often left in the streets to rot or to be food for vultures.
('69', 288, 1, 9, 516399) There is no doubt, therefore, that there is much to be said in favour of carrying corpses on carts.
('69', 288, 1, 10, 516499) Shri Tejpal has constructed a cart which costs a little over 100 rupees.
('69', 288, 1, 11, 516572) In a poor country like India a hundred rupees is a consideration not to be lightly dismissed.
('69', 288, 1, 12, 516666) But if village Mahajans 1 and municipalities were to own such carts and hire them out at a trifling charge, the question of expense can be elimin ated.
('69', 288, 1, 13, 516818) And local enthusiasts who appreciate the reform may popular ize the practice in their surroundings.
('69', 288, 1, 14, 516918) Shri Tejpal informs me that the Municipality of Ahmedabad keeps one such cart and so do Mahajans or Seva Samitis in Surat, Baroda, Jamnagar and Porbandar.
('69', 288, 1, 15, 517073) The Prarthana Samaj of Bombay is also reported to have one.
('69', 288, 1, 16, 517133) It will be interesting to know the extent to which the reform has made headway in the places where such carts are kept.
('69', 288, 2, 17, 517253) HAND GINNING
('69', 288, 3, 18, 517266) Like the wheel, the carding bow and the hand gins have been undergoing progressive improvements though not to the same extent as the wheel.
('69', 288, 3, 19, 517406) But the processes anterior to spinning are just as important as spinning itself.
('69', 288, 3, 20, 517487) Evenness, strength and speed depend upon good cotton, good picking, good ginning and good carding.
('69', 288, 3, 21, 517586) If any of the processes are defective, they tell upon the quality and the quantity of yarn turned out in a given time.
('69', 288, 3, 22, 517705) Experiments are therefore being conducted by Shri Radhakrishna Bajaj in Wardha in finding out the possibility of improvement in the hand gin.
('69', 288, 3, 23, 517847) If there are khadi lovers who have made improvements, they should correspond with Shri Radhakrishna and send him specimens if any.
('69', 288, 4, 24, 517978) Harijan, 8 8 1936
('69', 288, 5, 25, 517996) 1 A representative body of responsible citizens

('69', 298, 2, 3, 532287) SEGAON,
('69', 298, 3, 4, 532295) August 13, 1936
('69', 298, 4, 5, 532311) MANGIBAI,
('69', 298, 5, 6, 532321) I have just heard of your husband’s death.
('69', 298, 5, 7, 532364) Why should we grieve over the death of our loved ones.
('69', 298, 5, 8, 532419) In the long run death spares no one.
('69', 298, 5, 9, 532456) This too should be regarded as one of God’s blessings.
('69', 298, 5, 10, 532511) Now be calm and devote yourself to service.
('69', 298, 6, 11, 532555) Blessings from BAPU
('69', 298, 7, 12, 532575) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 172
('69', 298, 8, 13, 532615) 388. LETTER TO F. MARY BARR WARDHA, August 14, 1936
('69', 298, 9, 14, 532667) MY DEAR SISTER,
('69', 298, 10, 15, 532683) This is to acknowledge your letter to Bapu of the 9th inst.
('69', 298, 10, 16, 532743) I assume that you are still in Khedi though Dr. Baretto told me that he was expecting you on Tuesday last.
('69', 298, 10, 17, 532850) Evidently his date did not suit you and you asked for another, otherwise you should have been here by now.
('69', 298, 11, 18, 532957) In your letter too, you do not say when exactly you are arriving here.
('69', 298, 11, 19, 533028) Bapu likes very much your idea of taking a brief holiday in England.
('69', 298, 11, 20, 533097) We will discuss the details about your travel after you arrive.
('69', 298, 11, 21, 533161) In the mean time he wants me to tell you that much as he likes the idea of your getting England to take a bigger share in helping India’s poor, you must not think that you are not giving to India more than you are taking from her.
('69', 298, 11, 22, 533392) You must dismiss the thought from your mind that you have ever been a burden or are ever likely to be one.
('69', 298, 11, 23, 533499) Whilst you may ask for support from English friends, it will not be in order to find the wherewithal for your livelihood, but in order to help our work here.
('69', 298, 11, 24, 533657) You are a member of the family and are entitled to wage as much as the rest of us.
('69', 298, 11, 25, 533740) More when we meet.
('69', 298, 11, 26, 533759) Yours sincerely, MAHADEV MISS MARY BARR KHEDI SAOLIGARH DISTT.
('69', 298, 11, 27, 533822) BETUL, C.P.
('69', 298, 12, 28, 533834) From a photostat: G. N. 6066. Courtesy: F. Mary Barr
('69', 299, 0, 1, 533887) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 299, 1, 2, 533929) 389. TALK WITH A PATIL 1
('69', 299, 2, 3, 533954) [Before August 15, 1936]
('69', 299, 3, 4, 533979) The old Patil...
('69', 299, 3, 5, 533996) went one evening to Gandhiji saying, “I am ready to have the barber’s services...immediately after he has served Govind.” 2
('69', 299, 4, 6, 534120) [GANDHIJI:] What then is the difficulty?
('69', 299, 5, 7, 534161) [PATIL:] But now he is asking of me a thing I cannot give.
('69', 299, 5, 8, 534220) [GANDHIJI:] What is that?
('69', 299, 6, 9, 534246) [PATIL:] It is that I should once go and feed at his place.
('69', 299, 6, 10, 534306) With God as witness, Maharaj, I say I have never in my life of about four score years had tea or any kind of refreshment in a hotel.
('69', 299, 6, 11, 534439) How does he expect me to go and feed at his place?
('69', 299, 6, 12, 534490) I quite appreciate what you say, but why does he insist on your feeding at his place?
('69', 299, 7, 13, 534576) Because he thinks his castemen might boycott him, and he wants to make assurance doubly sure by having me in his place to eat.
('69', 299, 7, 14, 534703) Now, Maharaj, is that part of your anti untouchability programme?
('69', 299, 7, 15, 534769) Certainly not.
('69', 299, 7, 16, 534784) I am satisfied if you have conquered the prejudice of touch.
('69', 299, 7, 17, 534845) Inter dining is no part of the anti untouchability progra mme, though as you know I am having Govind to cook for me.
('69', 299, 7, 18, 534962) But that is what I would expect every Harijan sevak to do, not you.
('69', 299, 8, 19, 535030) Harijan, 15 8 1936
('69', 299, 9, 20, 535049) 390. TALK WITH A BARBER 3
('69', 299, 10, 21, 535075) SEGAON, [Before August 15, 1936]
('69', 299, 11, 22, 535108) One morning when I went to Segaon, I found Gandhiji busy pulling to pieces a hair cropping machine, in order to clean and oil it.
('69', 299, 11, 23, 535238) That done, he began having a crop with his own hands with a mirror in front of him.
('69', 299, 12, 24, 535322) At the same moment one of the devotees of the sadhu came in, and he happened to be a barber.
('69', 299, 12, 25, 535415) “Bapuji,” shouted the sadhu from the opposite corner, “Let Bhima crop your hair.
('69', 299, 12, 26, 535496) He knows the art.”
('69', 299, 13, 27, 535515) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”, 15 8 1936 2 The barber for fear of being boycotted by the village Patil and others had refused to shave Govind, a Harijan boy.
('69', 299, 13, 28, 535692) 3 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('69', 300, 0, 1, 535741) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 301
('69', 300, 1, 2, 535784) [GANDHIJI:] But how does he know it?
('69', 300, 2, 3, 535821) He is a barber by profession.
('69', 300, 2, 4, 535851) Ah, that is very good.
('69', 300, 2, 5, 535874) Come along then.
('69', 300, 3, 6, 535891) But as soon as Bhima began the operation, Gandhiji asked him: But I hope you have no prejudice against shaving our Harijan brethren.
('69', 300, 3, 7, 536024) Have you?
('69', 300, 4, 8, 536034) He slightly hesitated, and said: “I have in my heart no prejudice against Harijans.” That I can believe.
('69', 300, 4, 9, 536139) But will you shave a Harijan on the same terms as you would shave me?
('69', 300, 5, 10, 536209) Again he hesitated.
('69', 300, 5, 11, 536229) Thereupon Gandhiji said to the sadhu: I thought you had ascertained from him this thing before you asked me to have his services.
('69', 300, 6, 12, 536359) “I am sorry,” said the sadhu, “that aspect had for the moment escaped me.” Then I shall have to consider whether I should stop in the middle of the crop and dispense with Bhima.
('69', 300, 7, 13, 536537) But Bhima said: “No, though I do not usually do it, I promise from now to serve Harijans on the same terms.”
('69', 300, 8, 14, 536646) Harijan, 15 8 1936
('69', 300, 9, 15, 536665) 391. MORE COBWEBS
('69', 300, 10, 16, 536683) A seeker of truth cannot afford to write or speak to please anybody.
('69', 300, 10, 17, 536752) During my long search after truth in all things which have come my way, I know that I have hardly ever succeeded in convincing all of the correctness of my position regarding the matters then in question.
('69', 300, 10, 18, 536957) In the matter of Hindi propaganda, if I have displeased certain Muslim friends I have no less displeased Hindu friends.
('69', 300, 10, 19, 537077) But unless my critics convince me of my error, they should not expect me to change merely because they want me to.
('69', 300, 10, 20, 537192) Thus a correspondent actually says that although my position is logically and historically correct, I should change it to suit the Muslim critics who would have me either to advocate the adoption of the expression ‘Hindi Urdu’ or merely ‘Urdu’ to denote the same common speech, the objection being not to the speech but the name which it has hitherto carried.
('69', 300, 10, 21, 537552) Now there is a letter before me which quarrels with my address to the
('69', 301, 0, 1, 537622) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 301, 1, 2, 537664) Hindi Prachar Convocation recently held at Bangalore 1 from another standpoint.
('69', 301, 1, 3, 537744) It is a long letter from which I quote below the most relevant extracts:
('69', 301, 2, 4, 537817) In your convocation address at Bangalore you have asked the 11 million men and women of Karnatak to learn Hindi in order to establish contact with them.
('69', 301, 2, 5, 537970) You have not even restricted the appeal to those who are already educated in the mother tongue.
('69', 301, 2, 6, 538066) Even taking for granted that all are educated in the mother tongue, it is neither possible nor desirable, though possible, nor natural that the masses should learn a language other than their mother tongue.
('69', 301, 2, 7, 538273) Only all India national workers, business men and other people who come in daily contact with the people of North India can and should learn Hindi.
('69', 301, 2, 8, 538421) Necessity will make them learn the language even without any propaganda.
('69', 301, 3, 9, 538494) Though you say that Hindi does not supplant but supplements the provincial languages, in effect it is not so.
('69', 301, 3, 10, 538604) The bulk of the intellectuals of Tamil Nad today don’t think nor even feel in Tamil but in English.
('69', 301, 3, 11, 538704) They have completely neglected Tamil.
('69', 301, 3, 12, 538742) You can understand to what depths of cultural slavery they have fallen when you know that they are even proud of declaring in public meetings and other places that they cannot speak or write well in Tamil but they can do both fluently in English.
('69', 301, 3, 13, 538989) Now some of them have taken to the study of Hindi more with the help of English than with the help of Tamil.
('69', 301, 3, 14, 539098) The result is going to be the same.
('69', 301, 3, 15, 539134) They will begin to think in Hindi instead of English.
('69', 301, 3, 16, 539188) If a Gujarati tells you that he can write a beautiful essay in Hindi but not in Gujarati, you will be only sorry for him and think that our country is far from attaining purna swaraj.
('69', 301, 3, 17, 539372) Many have begun to say in Tamil Nad that they know Hindi better than Tamil.
('69', 301, 4, 18, 539448) One should not learn any language even though it be the language of the gods, to the detriment of one’s own mother tongue.
('69', 301, 4, 19, 539571) In this connection I used to cite your own example to the Hindi fanatics.
('69', 301, 4, 20, 539645) Though you declare that Hindi is the common language of India you have not written either your Autobiography or Satyagraha in South Africa in Hindi but in Gujarati.
('69', 301, 4, 21, 539810) If you had written them in Hindi many more people would have known what you say in your own words.
('69', 301, 4, 22, 539909) But you preferred to write them in Gujarati.
('69', 301, 4, 23, 539954) Though your teaching and personal example differ in this matter, I hold your action to be correct and proper.
('69', 301, 4, 24, 540064) Therefore I want people to follow not what you say but what you do.
('69', 301, 5, 25, 540132) Swaraj should not mean the imposition of one language over those who speak different languages.
('69', 301, 5, 26, 540228) Primary importance ought to be given only to the
('69', 301, 6, 27, 540277) 1 On June 12, 1936; vide “Convocation Address at Hindi Prachar Sabha, Bangalore”, 12 6 1936
('69', 302, 0, 1, 540369) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 303
('69', 302, 1, 2, 540412) mother tongue.
('69', 302, 1, 3, 540427) Only secondary importance can be given to Hindi, the common language of India.
('69', 302, 1, 4, 540506) Real inspiration and elevation can come only through the mother tongue.
('69', 302, 2, 5, 540578) Let me come to the question of script.
('69', 302, 2, 6, 540617) In Harijan dated 4 5 1935, writing on the resolution passed by the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan held at Indore you show a partiality for the Urdu script which passes my understanding.
('69', 302, 2, 7, 540795) In your convocation address at Bangalore also you show the same partiality for the Urdu script.
('69', 302, 2, 8, 540891) You want to destroy the scripts of all Indian languages derived from or largely influenced by Sanskrit and substitute Devanagari for them for the sake of those who want to learn the various languages.
('69', 302, 2, 9, 541092) You want to preserve the two scripts, Devanagari and Urdu, for one and the same language spoken by Hindus and Muslims.
('69', 302, 2, 10, 541211) Others, who also number millions and who have the misfortune of speaking different languages, should allow their scripts to be destroyed and displaced by Devanagari, learn Hindi Hindustani and also learn Urdu script in order to understand and come into contact with 130 million Hindus and 70 million Muslims!
('69', 302, 2, 11, 541520) Does this not sound ridiculous and represent the highest from of tyranny?
('69', 302, 2, 12, 541594) The logical conclusion of this policy would inevitably be the abolition of all languages except Hindi with both of its scripts, for the Devanagari script would have been adopted for all the languages, all would have learnt Hindi and all the important works in the mother tongue would have been translated in [to] Hindi.
('69', 302, 2, 13, 541914) I want you to reflect for a moment whether this consummation would be desirable in the best interestes of India, our common land of birth.
('69', 302, 2, 14, 542053) Before you propose to destroy the various scripts, should you not attempt to destroy one of the scripts, Devanagari and Urdu, for one and the same language?
('69', 302, 2, 15, 542210) Why should Muslims and Hindus speaking the same language use two different scripts?
('69', 302, 3, 16, 542294) I do not know that I asked all 11 million men and women of Karnatak to learn Hindi Hindustani.
('69', 302, 3, 17, 542389) I should be more than satisfied if all those who ever have to come in contact with the people from the North would learn Hindi Hindustani.
('69', 302, 3, 18, 542528) But I would certainly not only not deplore, as my correspondent would have me to, on the contrary I would welcome, all people of all the non Hindi provinces learning Hindi.
('69', 302, 3, 19, 542701) Why is it not desirable or natural for all India to know an all India speech in addition to every province knowing its own language and in addition knowing All India speech?
('69', 302, 3, 20, 542875) Why should such knowledge be the privilege of the cultured few and not of the masses?
('69', 302, 3, 21, 542961) It will surely show a very high degree of culture for a whole nation of over 300 million souls to know two languages.
('69', 302, 3, 22, 543079) That such an event is highly improbable is unfortunately too true.
('69', 303, 0, 1, 543146) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 303, 1, 2, 543188) What, however, would be most unfortunate would be for any province to neglect its own language and to prefer another speech as the correspondent complains is happening in Tamil Nad.
('69', 303, 1, 3, 543370) My frequent travels in Tamil Nad have confirmed the opinion expressed by my correspondent.
('69', 303, 1, 4, 543461) But latterly I have noticed a change for the better in that province.
('69', 303, 1, 5, 543531) And the process of preferring the provincial speech to every other where the choice is possible will be hastened without an effort as the educated in every province recognize more and more the necessity of seeking and establishing contact with the masses.
('69', 303, 1, 6, 543787) The correspondent incidentally touches the eternal rivalry between English and Hindi Hindustani to be the common speech.
('69', 303, 1, 7, 543908) I have held and declared, ever since I have entered public life, the definite opinion that English never can or ought to be the all Inida speech and that it can only be Hindi, i.e., Hindustani, the speech spoken by the millions of Hindus and Mussalmans of the North.
('69', 303, 1, 8, 544175) The attempt to treat English as such is to establish a permanent bar between the masses and the English educated classes and to retard the progress of the country to its destination.
('69', 303, 1, 9, 544358) I have repeatedly explained that English has a definite place in our culture.
('69', 303, 1, 10, 544436) In order to understand the rulers and the whole Western world and to bring to India the best that the West has to give, a few of us must learn English which is the most widely known speech of the West.
('69', 303, 1, 11, 544638) But a thousand times more Indians have to know Hindi Hindustani if the illiterate masses are to be one with the educated classes.
('69', 303, 1, 12, 544768) The correspondent is wholly ignorant of my opinion when he thinks that I have even been guilty of advising preference for Hindi over the provincial speech.
('69', 303, 1, 13, 544924) There is no hiatus between my principle and my practice in this connection.
('69', 303, 1, 14, 545000) I heartily endorse the proposition that primary importance should be given to the mother tongue.
('69', 303, 1, 15, 545097) On the question of script my correspondents’s fear is justified, nor do I apologize for the opinion I hold.
('69', 303, 1, 16, 545205) Different languages descended from or intimately connected with Sanskrit ought to have one script and that is surely Devanagari.
('69', 303, 1, 17, 545334) Different scripts are an unnecessary hindrance to the learning by the people of one province the language of other provinces.
('69', 303, 1, 18, 545460) Even Europe which is not one nation has generally adopted one script.
('69', 303, 1, 19, 545530) Why should India, which claims to be and is one nation, not have one script?
('69', 303, 1, 20, 545607) I know I am inconsistent when I tolerate both Devanagari and Urdu scripts for the same language.
('69', 303, 1, 21, 545704) But my inconsistency is not quite foolish.
('69', 303, 1, 22, 545747) There is Hindu 
('69', 304, 0, 1, 545763) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 305
('69', 304, 1, 2, 545806) Muslim friction at the present moment.
('69', 304, 1, 3, 545845) It is wise and necessary for the educated Hindus and Muslims to show mutual respect and toleration to the utmost extent possible.
('69', 304, 1, 4, 545975) Hence the option for Devanagari or Urdu scripts.
('69', 304, 1, 5, 546024) Happily there is no friction between provinces and provinces.
('69', 304, 1, 6, 546086) Hence the desirability of advocating a reform which means a closer knitting together of provinces in more ways than one.
('69', 304, 1, 7, 546207) And let it be remembered that the vast mass of the people are wholly illiterate.
('69', 304, 1, 8, 546288) It would be suicidal to impose on them different scripts for no other reason than a false sentiment and laziness to think.
('69', 304, 1, 9, 546411) Harijan, 15 8 1936
('69', 304, 2, 10, 546430) 392. VARNA V. CASTE
('69', 304, 3, 11, 546450) Shri Sant Ramji, of the Jat Pat Torak Mandal of Lahore, wants me to publish the following:
('69', 304, 4, 12, 546541) I have read your remarks 1 about Dr. Ambedkar and the Jat Pat Torak Mandal, Lahore.
('69', 304, 4, 13, 546625) In that connection I beg to submit as follows:
('69', 304, 5, 14, 546672) We did not invite Dr. Ambedkar to preside over our conference because he belonged to the Depressed Classes, for we do not distinguish between a touchable and an untouchable Hindu.
('69', 304, 5, 15, 546852) On the contrary our choice fell on him simply because his diagnosis of the fatal disease of the Hindu community was the same as ours, i.e., he too was of the opinion that caste system was the root cause of the disruption and downfall of the Hindu.
('69', 304, 5, 16, 547100) The subject of the Doctor’s thesis for doctorate being caste system, he has studied the subject thoroughly.
('69', 304, 5, 17, 547208) Now the object of our conference was to persuade the Hindus to annihilate caste, but the advice of a non Hindu in social and religious matters can have no effect on them.
('69', 304, 5, 18, 547379) The Doctor in the supplementary portion of his address insisted on saying that that was his last speech as a Hindu, which was irrelevant as well as pernicious to the interests of the conference.
('69', 304, 5, 19, 547574) So we requested him to expunge that sentence, for he could easily say the same thing on any other occasion.
('69', 304, 5, 20, 547682) But he refused and we saw no utility in making merely a show of our function.
('69', 304, 5, 21, 547760) In spite of all this, I cannot help praising his address which is, as far as I know, the most learned thesis on the subject and worth translating into every vernacular of India.
('69', 304, 6, 22, 547938) Moreover I want to bring to your notice that your philosophical difference between caste and varna is too subtle to be grasped by people in general, because for all practical purposes in the Hindu society caste and varna are one and the same thing, for the function of both of them is one and the
('69', 304, 7, 23, 548235) 1 Vide “Dr. Ambedkar’s Indictment I”, 11 7 1936
('69', 305, 0, 1, 548283) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 305, 1, 2, 548325) same, i.e., to restrict intercaste marriages and inter dining.
('69', 305, 1, 3, 548388) Your theory of varnavyavastha is impracticable in this age and there is no hope of its revival in the near future.
('69', 305, 1, 4, 548503) But Hindus are slaves of caste and do not want to destroy it.
('69', 305, 1, 5, 548565) So when you advocate your ideal or imaginary varnavyavastha they find justification for clinging to caste.
('69', 305, 1, 6, 548672) Thus you are doing a great disservice to social reform by advocating your imaginary utility of division of varnas, for it creates hindrance in our way.
('69', 305, 1, 7, 548824) To try to remove untouchability without striking disease or to draw a line on the surface of water.
('69', 305, 1, 8, 548924) As in the heart of their hearts dwijas 1 do not want to give social equality to the so called touchable and untouchable Shudras, so they refuse to break caste, and give liberal donations for the removal of untouchability, simply to evade the issue.
('69', 305, 1, 9, 549173) To seek the help of the Shastras for the removal of untouchability and caste is simply to wash mud with mud.
('69', 305, 1, 10, 549282) The last paragraph of the letter surely cancels the first.
('69', 305, 1, 11, 549341) If the Mandal rejects the help of the Shastras, they do exactly what Dr. Ambedkar does, i.e., cease to be Hindus.
('69', 305, 1, 12, 549455) How then can they object to Dr. Ambedkar’s address merely because he said that that was his last speech as a Hindu?
('69', 305, 1, 13, 549571) The position appears to be wholly untenable especially when the Mandal, for which Shri Sant Ram claims to speak, applauds the whole argument of Dr. Ambedkar’s address.
('69', 305, 1, 14, 549739) But it is pertinent to ask what the Mandal believes if it rejects the Shastras.
('69', 305, 1, 15, 549819) How can a Muslim remain one if he rejects the Quran, or a Christian remain Christian if he rejects the Bible?
('69', 305, 1, 16, 549929) If caste and varna are convertible terms and if varna is an integral part of the Shastras which define Hinduism, I do not know how a person who rejects caste, i.e., varna can call himself a Hindu.
('69', 305, 1, 17, 550126) Shri Sant Ram likens the Shastras to mud.
('69', 305, 1, 18, 550168) Dr. Ambedkar has not, so far as I remember, given any such picturesque name to the Shastras.
('69', 305, 1, 19, 550261) I have certainly meant it when I have said that if the Shastras support the existing untouchability I should cease to call myself a Hindu.
('69', 305, 1, 20, 550400) Similarly, if the Shastras support caste as we know it today in all its hideousness, I may not call myself or remain a Hindu since I have no scruples about inter dining or intermarriage.
('69', 305, 1, 21, 550587) I need not repeat my position regarding the Shastras and their interpretation.
('69', 305, 1, 22, 550666) I venture to suggest to Shri Sant Ram that it is the only rational and correct and morally defensible position and it has ample warrant in Hindu tradition.
('69', 305, 2, 23, 550822) Harijan, 15 8 1936

('69', 306, 1, 2, 550901) 393. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('69', 306, 2, 3, 550943) SEGAON WARDHA, August 16, 1936
('69', 306, 3, 4, 550974) MANILAL, SUSHILA,
('69', 306, 4, 5, 550992) I have your letters.
('69', 306, 4, 6, 551013) There is no need at all for you to come here if you are happy where you are.
('69', 306, 4, 7, 551090) No matter where we are we should render whatever services we can, and regard the people wherever we are as members of our own family.
('69', 306, 4, 8, 551224) The true meeting is that of hearts, and they are quite close though we are millions of miles apart.
('69', 306, 4, 9, 551324) If the hearts of two prisoners in the same cell are not one their physical proximity is meaningless.
('69', 306, 4, 10, 551425) Hence, I do not long to have you come here to see me.
('69', 306, 4, 11, 551479) You may live there permanently if you find your peace there.
('69', 306, 4, 12, 551540) Now a surprise for you both.
('69', 306, 4, 13, 551569) Kanti’s mind is now set on getting formal education and obtaining a degree.
('69', 306, 4, 14, 551645) However one may try, he cannot possibly be deterred.
('69', 306, 4, 15, 551698) I tried hard, but without success.
('69', 306, 4, 16, 551733) Now, the question of the expenses for his education remains.
('69', 306, 4, 17, 551794) Kanti, too, agrees that it cannot be paid from the public funds and that it would be a crime to take anything from his mother’s sisters who have already spent a good deal on him.
('69', 306, 4, 18, 551973) Hence, either you three brothers should pay his expenses or he must earn and learn.
('69', 306, 4, 19, 552057) In my opinion, you three should share the burden, which is likely to be Rs. 75 to Rs. 100 a month, though I do not know about it.
('69', 306, 4, 20, 552187) It is enough if you give your share of Rs. 33. Start sending the sum if you agree with the proposal.
('69', 306, 4, 21, 552288) Manu and Ba are with me.
('69', 306, 4, 22, 552313) We are getting on quite well.
('69', 306, 4, 23, 552343) I got a letter from Harilal, his first after his conversion.
('69', 306, 4, 24, 552404) He asks for a copy of the Golden Number 1 and wants to see me.
('69', 306, 4, 25, 552467) I have written 2
('69', 306, 5, 26, 552484) to him, saying that he may come provided he agrees to my terms for the visit.
('69', 306, 6, 27, 552562) Blessings from BAPU

('69', 307, 6, 7, 552918) 395. LETTER TO N.R. MALKANI

('69', 311, 5, 7, 558940) 403. A LETTER 1
('69', 311, 6, 8, 558956) [Before August 22, 1936]
('69', 311, 7, 9, 558981) I see that you do not know the origin of the word ‘Harijan’ as applied to the so called untouchables.
('69', 311, 7, 10, 559083) Hindu literature and, so far as I know, even Christian literature is full of the idea that the despised of the earth are favoured children of God; and so we have a proverb in daily use which means that God is the help of the helpless.
('69', 311, 7, 11, 559318) Who could be better fitted to be called Harijans in this sense than the millions whom the insolence of men has made the outcastes of society?
('69', 311, 7, 12, 559460) It would be a different thing if the untouchables themselves said, ‘We are Harijans because we are without sin’—but can any man born of woman say ‘I am without sin whether he has experienced what you call ‘new birth’ or not?
('69', 311, 8, 13, 559685) Harijan, 22 8 1936
('69', 311, 9, 14, 559704) 404. DISCUSSION WITH A PANDIT 2
('69', 311, 10, 15, 559736) [Before August 22, 1936]
('69', 311, 11, 16, 559761) A Pandit was one of the visitors to Segaon the other day.
('69', 311, 11, 17, 559819) He was introduced as one learned in the Shastras and as one who gave regular discourses on the Gita.
('69', 311, 11, 18, 559920) Gandhiji asked him if untouchability had the sanction of the Gita.
('69', 311, 11, 19, 559987) It seemed to depend, according to him, on how one defined an untouchable.
('69', 311, 11, 20, 560061) He said:
('69', 311, 12, 21, 560070) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('69', 311, 12, 22, 560120) The addressee, a missionary, had enquired: “Does it not indicate that to be really and truly Harijans we must have the experience of a new birth, a spiritual regeneration, which the ordinary man can have no very great understanding of, so long as he is in the unregenerate state?
('69', 311, 12, 23, 560400) Instead of designating the poor villagers who are still ‘dead in trespasses and sins’ as ‘sons of God’, would it not be better to call them all men and women who might become true sons of God?” 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('69', 312, 0, 1, 560643) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 313
('69', 312, 1, 2, 560686) An untouchable is he who thinks evil thoughts, speaks foul language, does evil deeds.
('69', 312, 1, 3, 560772) Such a one would be an untouchable according to the Gita.
('69', 312, 1, 4, 560830) But at that rate every one of us would be an untouchable.
('69', 312, 1, 5, 560888) Who is there amongst us who is without sin?
('69', 312, 1, 6, 560932) Let me ascertain.
('69', 312, 1, 7, 560950) Tukde Maharaj, are you without sin?
('69', 312, 2, 8, 560986) No, by no means.
('69', 312, 2, 9, 561003) Then, Khan Saheb, what about you?
('69', 312, 3, 10, 561037) The same thing.
('69', 312, 3, 11, 561053) Who can claim to be perfect?
('69', 312, 3, 12, 561082) Which means that we are all untouchable.
('69', 312, 3, 13, 561123) Anyway, it is better that we regard ourselves as less pure than others, for we know ourselves better than we do others, and we may judge none.
('69', 312, 3, 14, 561266) That is why saint Surdas sang: “There is none so wicked and base as I.”
('69', 312, 4, 15, 561338) “But then one needs the help of the Shastras to purge onself of evil thoughts?” said the Pandit.

('69', 312, 4, 17, 561611) Such a Shastra, far from purging us of sin, adds to our load of sin.
('69', 312, 5, 18, 561680) Harijan, 22 8 1936

('69', 312, 8, 22, 561941) Service of His creation is the service of God.
('69', 312, 9, 23, 561988) But how can we serve the whole of God’s creation.
('69', 312, 9, 24, 562038) We can but serve that part of God’s creation which is nearest and best known to us.
('69', 312, 9, 25, 562122) We can start with our next door neighbour.
('69', 312, 9, 26, 562165) We should not be content with keeping our courtyard clean, we should see that our neighbour’s courtyard is also clean.

('69', 313, 1, 2, 562667) which we live.

('69', 313, 3, 8, 562972) 406. A DANGEROUS PROPOSAL
('69', 313, 4, 9, 562998) Rao Bahadur Rajah has rendered public service by publishing the correspondence between himself and Dr. Moonje.
('69', 313, 4, 10, 563109) 1 There was no breach of confidence in the publication.
('69', 313, 4, 11, 563165) Privilege of confidence is surely not available for proposals which the receiver may regard to be dangerous or harmful to a cause as the Moonje Ambedkar proposal most undoubtedly is.
('69', 313, 4, 12, 563348) That neither Dr. Moonje nor Dr. Ambedkar regards his proposal as dangerous does not make it less so in the estimation of those who disapprove of it.
('69', 313, 4, 13, 563497) What else was R.B. Rajah todo if he intended by all legitimate means to thwart it?
('69', 313, 4, 14, 563580) He entered into correspondence with some of those who were parties to the Yeravda Pact, and when he saw that not one of them favoured the proposal he promptly released the correspondence for publication.
('69', 313, 4, 15, 563784) One may hope that we have seen the last of any bargaining between.
('69', 313, 4, 16, 563851) Dr. Ambedkar and savarna Hindus for the transfer to another form of several million dumb Harijans as if they were chattels.
('69', 313, 4, 17, 563975) The Pact is between one large section of Hindus and another.
('69', 313, 4, 18, 564036) It frustrated the attempt to cut the Hindu body into two and gave the opportunity to savarna Hindus to make reparation to those millions whom they had ill treated for centuries.
('69', 313, 4, 19, 564214) Dr. Ambedkar wants to scourge the savarna Hindus as he has every right to do, but he may not expect the latter to be party to it.
('69', 313, 4, 20, 564344) He has every right to be impatient.
('69', 313, 4, 21, 564380) But prejudices and superstitions centuries old do not die in a moment.
('69', 313, 4, 22, 564451) No one who has at all cared to study the reform movement will deny that every attempt humanly possible has been and is being made to bring home to the savarna Hindus the message of the anti untouchability movement.
('69', 313, 4, 23, 564666) If Dr. Ambedkar’s proposal were accepted, the reform movement would receive a setback which might mean death to it in the end.
('69', 313, 5, 24, 564793) 1 Vide “Letter to M.C. Rajah”, 26 6 1936
('69', 314, 0, 1, 564834) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 315
('69', 314, 1, 2, 564877) contemplates a paper but legal transfer of Harijans from the Hindu fold to some other, no matter by what name the latter is called.
('69', 314, 1, 3, 565009) It must mean fratricide.
('69', 314, 1, 4, 565034) Harijans themselves will be cut up into two rival sections, and if they are both classified as Harijans within the meaning of the Pact their state then will be worse than it is today, and it will be an evil day for unhappy India if such a calamity descends on her.
('69', 314, 1, 5, 565299) It is futile to argue that although there will be nominal change of religion, there won’t be a real one, and if there is any, it would not be so bad as if Harijans were called Christians or Muslims.
('69', 314, 1, 6, 565498) If it is a change of religion, it matters little under what label they are classified.
('69', 314, 1, 7, 565585) Only if they are said to belong to another religion and still remain Harijans, an additional cause of internecine quarrel would be created; and all this to satisfy the desire to punish savarna Hindus.
('69', 314, 1, 8, 565786) If in his anger or impatience Dr. Ambedkar refuses to see the obvious result, surely Dr. Moonje ought to.
('69', 314, 1, 9, 565892) And who are we, the self constituted leaders, to barter away the religious freedom of Harijans?
('69', 314, 1, 10, 565988) Has not every Harijan, however dull or stupid he may be, the right to make his own choice?
('69', 314, 1, 11, 566079) It is one thing for Dr. Ambedkar and those who wish to change over to some other religion to do so, and wholly another for political or other parties to assume such change for the mass of Harijans and to base thereon legal and other consequences of a farreaching character.
('69', 314, 1, 12, 566353) If the leaders of different religions in India ceased to compete with one another for enticing Harijans into their fold, it would be well for this unfortunate country.
('69', 314, 1, 13, 566521) I have the profound conviction that those who are engaged in the competition are not serving the cause of religion.
('69', 314, 1, 14, 566637) By looking at it in terms of politics or economics they reduce the religious values, whereas the proper thing would be to esitmate politics and every other thing in terms of religion.
('69', 314, 1, 15, 566821) Religion deals with the science of the soul.
('69', 314, 1, 16, 566866) Great as the other forces of the world are, if there is such a thing as God soul force is the greatest of all.
('69', 314, 1, 17, 566977) We know as a matter of fact that the greater the force the finer it is.
('69', 314, 1, 18, 567049) Hitherto electricity has held the field among the finer physical powers.
('69', 314, 1, 19, 567122) And yet nobody has seen it except through its wonderful results.
('69', 314, 1, 20, 567187) Scientific speculation dares to talk of a force finer even than that of electricity.
('69', 314, 1, 21, 567272) But no instrument devised by man has been able to know anything positive of soul force or spiritual force.
('69', 314, 1, 22, 567379) It is on that force that the true religious reformer has hitherto relied and never without hope fulfilled.
('69', 314, 1, 23, 567486) It is that force which will finally govern the welfare of
('69', 315, 0, 1, 567544) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('69', 318, 5, 10, 572568) 414. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('69', 318, 6, 11, 572610) August 24, 1936
('69', 318, 7, 12, 572626) MANILAL, SUSHILA,
('69', 318, 8, 13, 572644) I have your letters to me and have also read the one to Kishorelal.
('69', 318, 8, 14, 572712) The idea of having share holders does not seem right.
('69', 318, 8, 15, 572766) Where there is a field ready for share holders, one for customers and expert workers can well be assumed.
('69', 318, 8, 16, 572872) Having share holders does not mean having subscribers or expert workers.
('69', 318, 8, 17, 572945) In my opinion, there may be difficulty in getting men in spite of a flow of funds.
('69', 318, 8, 18, 573028) Plainly speaking, the subscribers to Indian Opinion are not exactly its readers but rather patrons.
('69', 318, 8, 19, 573128) This is a pitiable situation.
('69', 318, 8, 20, 573158) You should stop running around and find another honest trade which can support both of you.
('69', 318, 8, 21, 573250) You may pay the loss in running Indian Opinion or those who desire its continuance should give a guarantee to bear the loss.
('69', 318, 8, 22, 573375) You should close down Indian Opinion if this cannot be done.
('69', 318, 8, 23, 573436) The insistence on continuing it could be right only up to a point.
('69', 318, 8, 24, 573503) You ought to have the ability to support yourself by means of some other trade in case Indian Opinion cannot run.
('69', 318, 8, 25, 573617) You should also be equipped to support yourself solely on agriculture.
('69', 318, 8, 26, 573688) You ought to think over all this patiently.
('69', 318, 8, 27, 573732) Very little help can be had through exchange of ideas across this distance.
('69', 318, 8, 28, 573808) You alone know the present condition there.
('69', 318, 8, 29, 573852) It may, however, be right to inform me before taking a final decision.
('69', 318, 8, 30, 573923) If there is no time for it there is no harm in deciding independently.
('69', 318, 8, 31, 573994) In any case do observe these conditions: (1) Incur no debts.
('69', 318, 8, 32, 574055) (2) Transact no business on credit.
('69', 319, 0, 1, 574091) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 319, 1, 2, 574133) (3) Take up no business in forbidden goods such as selling bidis.
('69', 319, 1, 3, 574199) (4) Don’t engage in a business to get rich quickly.
('69', 319, 1, 4, 574251) I am pained to read about Sorabji.
('69', 319, 1, 5, 574286) Sheth Rustomji’s fears about him seem to be proving true.
('69', 319, 1, 6, 574344) After all things must go the destined way and one’s understanding follows the same way.

('69', 319, 5, 14, 574878) 415. A DISCUSSION WITH MAURICE FRYDMAN 2
('69', 319, 6, 15, 574919) [On or before August 25, 1936] 3
('69', 319, 7, 16, 574952) [GANDHIJI:] So that is Frydman.
('69', 319, 7, 17, 574984) You have come to study the spinning wheel.
('69', 319, 7, 18, 575027) But you will not win the Rs. 100,000 prize, as the prize has been withdrawn.
('69', 319, 8, 19, 575104) [Maurice Frydman] joined heartily in the laughter and said, “Oh, no, I do not want the prize, my only aim is to give you the wheel you want.”
('69', 319, 9, 20, 575246) He again asked a number of questions about the wheel, discussed various improvements and left for Wardha.
('69', 319, 10, 21, 575352) He inquired if Gandhiji’s aim was just humanitarian in sitting down in the village, just serving the villagers as best he could !
('69', 319, 10, 22, 575482) I am here to serve no one else but myself, to find my own self realization through the service of these village folk.
('69', 319, 10, 23, 575600) Man’s ultimate aim is the realization of God, and all his activities, social, political,
('69', 319, 11, 24, 575689) 1 Vide “Letter to Manilal and Sushila Gandhi”, 16 8 1936 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('69', 319, 11, 25, 575796) Maurice Frydman was a Polish engineer, interested in village reconstruction movement, who had met Gandhiji earlier at Nandi Hill.
('69', 319, 11, 26, 575926) He was given the name Bharatanand.
('69', 319, 11, 27, 575961) 3 According to the source the discussion took place on a Tuesday.
('69', 319, 11, 28, 576027) The Tuesday before 29 8 1936 fell on 25 8 1936. 4 The discussion which follows took place on a subsequent visit.
('69', 320, 0, 1, 576140) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 321
('69', 320, 1, 2, 576183) religious, have to be guided by the ultimate aim of the vision of God.
('69', 320, 1, 3, 576254) The immediate service of all human beings becomes a necessary part of the endeavour simply because the only way to find God is to see Him in His creation and be one with it.
('69', 320, 1, 4, 576428) This can only be done by service of all.
('69', 320, 1, 5, 576469) And this cannot be done except through one’s country.
('69', 320, 1, 6, 576523) I am part and parcel of the whole, and I cannot find Him apart from the rest of humanity.
('69', 320, 1, 7, 576613) My countrymen are my nearest neighbours.
('69', 320, 1, 8, 576654) They have become so helpless, so resourceless, so inert that I must concentrate on serving them.
('69', 320, 1, 9, 576751) If I could persuade myself that I should find Him in a Himalayan cave, I would proceed there immediately.
('69', 320, 1, 10, 576857) But I know that I cannot find Him apart from humanity.
('69', 320, 2, 11, 576912) But some comforts may be necessary even for man’s spiritual advancement.
('69', 320, 2, 12, 576985) One could not advance himself by identifying himself with the discomfort and squalour of the villager?
('69', 320, 2, 13, 577088) A certain degree of physical harmony and comfort is necessary, but above a certain level it becomes a hindrance instead of help.
('69', 320, 2, 14, 577217) Therefore the ideal of creating an unlimited number of wants and satisfying them seems to be a delusion and a snare.
('69', 320, 2, 15, 577334) The satisfaction of one’s physical needs, even the intellectual needs of one’s narrow self, must meet at a certain point a dead stop, before it degenerates into physical and intellectual voluptuousness.
('69', 320, 2, 16, 577537) A man must arrange his physical and cultural circumstances so that they do not hinder him in his service of humanity, on which all his energies should be concentrated.
('69', 320, 3, 17, 577705) What then was the secret of his concentration on the village?
('69', 320, 3, 18, 577767) I have been saying that if untouchability stays, Hinduism goes; even so I would say that if the village perishes, India will perish too.
('69', 320, 3, 19, 577904) It will be no more India, Her own mission in the world will get lost.
('69', 320, 3, 20, 577974) The revival of the village is possible only when it is no more exploited.
('69', 320, 3, 21, 578048) Industrialization on a mass scale will necessarily lead to passive or active exploitation of the villagers as the problems of competition and marketing come in.
('69', 320, 3, 22, 578209) Therefore we have to concentrate on the village being self contained, manufacturing mainly for use.
('69', 320, 3, 23, 578309) Provided this character of the village industry is maintained, there would be no objection to villagers using even the modern machines and tools that they can make and can afford to use.
('69', 320, 3, 24, 578496) Only they should not be used as a means of exploitation of others.
('69', 320, 4, 25, 578563) Harijan, 29 8 1936

('69', 326, 1, 2, 585520) 425. LETTER TO PRABHAVATI
('69', 326, 2, 3, 585546) SEGAON, WARDHA, [About August 27, 1936] 1
('69', 326, 3, 4, 585588) PRABHA, You must have got my letter to the Sitab Diyara address though you have gone to Patna.
('69', 326, 3, 5, 585683) Now obtain milk and fruit there and improve your health.
('69', 326, 3, 6, 585740) Look after the household properly.

('69', 328, 4, 16, 588929) 429. NOTES
('69', 328, 5, 17, 588940) UNCERTIFIED V. CERTIFIED
('69', 328, 6, 18, 588965) The difficulty that cropped up in the Tamil Nad on the introduction of the new scale of wages for spinning has arisen in other places and specially in Andhra, as appears from several letters I have received from that part of India.
('69', 328, 6, 19, 589197) Correspondents complain bitterly of the harm uncertified dealers of khadi are doing to the cause of the poor women who have no chance of earning an additional pice.
('69', 328, 6, 20, 589362) I do not know whether the uncertified dealers will listen to my exhortation not to be so selfish as to snatch the pice from thousands of poor spinners.
('69', 328, 6, 21, 589514) I hope they will.
('69', 328, 6, 22, 589532) But the real remedy lies in the hands of the khadi buying public.
('69', 328, 6, 23, 589598) If they will not buy khadi except from the bhandars certified by the A.I.S.A., the uncertified bhandars will haveto close down.
('69', 328, 6, 24, 589726) The public should realize that there can be no khadi if there is no A.I.S.A. Until khadi becomes current coin and has found general favour in the villages, it must be nursed by a vigilant body having the capacity for performing the onerous duty.
('69', 328, 6, 25, 589972) Such a body is the A.I.S.A. The public know or ought to know that it is a purely philanthropic institution having no interest save that of the millions of poor women spinners of the villages of India.
('69', 328, 6, 26, 590173) As its name
('69', 329, 0, 1, 590185) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 329, 1, 2, 590227) implies, all its activities are intended to subserve their interest.
('69', 329, 1, 3, 590296) Economic salvation of the villages is impossible, unless the millions of women who have no occupation for nearly six months in the year have a steady and profitable occupation fitted to their constitutions.
('69', 329, 1, 4, 590503) There is no such universal occupation as hand spinning.
('69', 329, 1, 5, 590559) I have been obliged to restate this oft told truth in order to emphasize the necessity of the public patronizing certified khadi bhandars to the exclusion of uncertified ones, even though the latter sell khadi at less than the Association rates.
('69', 329, 1, 6, 590805) The public should know that the Association rates alone make it possible to pay higher wages to spinners.
('69', 329, 2, 7, 590911) HUTS WITHOUT MONEY
('69', 329, 3, 8, 590930) Last year I had 60 Harijans accommodated in the village of my future abode.
('69', 329, 3, 9, 591006) The question of building huts for them was ticklish.
('69', 329, 3, 10, 591059) But it was solved for me by Harijans themselves.
('69', 329, 3, 11, 591108) When I went to the village a month after their settlement, I found 12 huts already erected evidently without the cost of a pice.
('69', 329, 3, 12, 591237) The walls were made of palm branches or stalks of juari, cotton or tuver; the roof of split stalks of juari, knitted into chatais 1 and those were covered with leaves of khakhra.
('69', 329, 3, 13, 591416) The ropes were made from the fibres of khakhra roots.
('69', 329, 3, 14, 591470) Thus writes an enthusiastic agriculture graduate who is keen on settling down in a village.
('69', 329, 3, 15, 591562) Where labour is not exploited and where it has free access to the material that Nature produces in abundance and which is generally allowed to go to waste or sold for a trifle, poor Harijans have no difficulty in getting for themselves comfortable cottages and other amenities of life.
('69', 329, 3, 16, 591848) But orthodox prejudice makes it a sin or a crime for Harijans to touch even its wells !
('69', 329, 3, 17, 591936) Harijan, 29 8 1936

('69', 333, 0, 1, 596932) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 333, 1, 2, 596974) 435. A TALK 1
('69', 333, 2, 3, 596988) [Before September 2, 1936] 2
('69', 333, 3, 4, 597017) It was interesting one morning to watch a number of urchins collected in the verandah of Gandhiji’s hut....Their eyes were fixed on a snake in a glass jar....Though the place cannot...
('69', 333, 3, 5, 597202) be said to be infested with snakes, a fair number of snakes are to be found there during the season.
('69', 333, 3, 6, 597303) There must therefore be a fair number of cases of snake bites, and in all cases the villagers kill the snakes at sight.
('69', 333, 3, 7, 597423) Explaning the presence of the exhibit Gandhiji said: That is hardly proper or necessary.
('69', 333, 3, 8, 597512) We cannot tell a poisonous from a non poisonous snake and therefore we kill all without discrimination.
('69', 333, 3, 9, 597616) The bulk of them are non poisonous, and in many cases it is the fright that kills the victim of snake bite.
('69', 333, 3, 10, 597724) The snakes have their place in the agricultural economy of the village, but our villagers do not seem to realize it.
('69', 333, 3, 11, 597841) They perform a particularly useful function, in that they clear the fields of rats, vermin and other pests.
('69', 333, 3, 12, 597949) It is best therefore to know the elementary principles of snake lore and to teach them to the villagers.
('69', 333, 3, 13, 598054) They must know how to distinguish between a poisonous and a non poisonous snake, they must know that it is not necessary to kill all snakes, which although they may be poisonous do not usually bite unless they are trodden upon or mishandled, and they must also know that certain snakes at least are useful.
('69', 333, 3, 14, 598361) With that purpose in view I have decided to have here snakes alive or dead to be shown to the villagers.
('69', 333, 3, 15, 598466) This one in the jar was caught alive by an inmate of our household.
('69', 333, 3, 16, 598534) We have a simple device with which it is easy to catch snakes alive without doing them physical injury, and this one was found clinging to a roof in the farmyard over there.
('69', 333, 3, 17, 598708) I decided to send it on to the Civil Surgeon for examination.
('69', 333, 3, 18, 598770) He was good enough to examine it.
('69', 333, 3, 19, 598804) He found that it was a Krait, one of the most poisonous varieties, and so he killed it and sent it back.
('69', 333, 3, 20, 598909) I decided to preserve it and sent for a glass jar with rectified spirit.
('69', 333, 3, 21, 598982) We had to wait several hours for the jar to come, and when it did come we found on opening the basket that the snake was alive.
('69', 333, 3, 22, 599110) It seems to be particularly tenacious of life, and so it lingered on until the third day, when we decided to end its pains by immersing it in water.
('69', 333, 3, 23, 599259) The fact was that the
('69', 333, 4, 24, 599281) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 2 This and the subsequent interviews evidently took place before Gandhiji was hospitalized on September 2, 1936.
('69', 334, 0, 1, 599443) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 335
('69', 334, 1, 2, 599487) Civil Surgeon had smashed its brain and stunned it, and as he explained later its spinal cord was intact and therefore it had remained alive.
('69', 334, 1, 3, 599629) I have now got a cage to keep live specimens in.
('69', 334, 1, 4, 599678) As you see, the little urchins are already being attracted.
('69', 334, 1, 5, 599738) I have begun to study snake lore and hope to place before the villagers the broad facts regarding these creatures.
('69', 334, 1, 6, 599853) Harijan, 5 9 1936
('69', 334, 2, 7, 599871) 436. DISCUSSION WITH TEACHERS 1
('69', 334, 3, 8, 599903) [Before September 2, 1936]
('69', 334, 4, 9, 599930) A group of school teachers went to Segaon one morning with that old Platonic problem—Knowledge is virtue—and asked if it was true.
('69', 334, 4, 10, 600061) Why was it that though we knew very well indeed that a particular course of action was morally wrong, we could not avoid it?
('69', 334, 4, 11, 600186) Replying to them Gandhiji said: Human life is a series of compromises and it is not always easy to achieve in practice what one has found to be true in theory.
('69', 334, 4, 12, 600346) Take this very simple case.
('69', 334, 4, 13, 600374) The principle is that all life is one and we have to treat the sinner and the saint alike, as the Gita says we have to look with an equal eye on a learned pundit and a dog and a dog eater.
('69', 334, 4, 14, 600563) But there I am.
('69', 334, 4, 15, 600579) Though I have not killed the snake, I know I have been instrumental in killing it.
('69', 334, 4, 16, 600662) I know that I should not have done so.
('69', 334, 4, 17, 600701) I know, besides, that snakes are kshetrapals (guardians of the field); and therefore too I should not have helped in killing it.
('69', 334, 4, 18, 600830) But as you see I have not been able to avoid it.
('69', 334, 4, 19, 600879) But it is no use my thinking that I cannot avoid it.
('69', 334, 4, 20, 600932) I do not give up the principle which is true for all time that all life is one, and I pray to God that He may rid me of the fear of snakes and enable me to achieve the non violences necessary to handle snakes and as we handle other domestics.
('69', 334, 4, 21, 601175) Take another instance, again a very simple one.
('69', 334, 4, 22, 601223) I know that as a villager and as one who has made it his business to promote village crafts, I must use a village made razor, but you see that I am using a foreign one.
('69', 334, 5, 23, 601392) I might have got a village made razor, if I had written to friends to procure one for me.
('69', 334, 5, 24, 601482) But I thought I must help the village barber, no matter what kind of razor he used.
('69', 334, 5, 25, 601566) I therefore decided to cultivate him, and put up with his dirty clothes and uncouth instruments.
('69', 334, 5, 26, 601663) But on one thing I could not possibly compromise.
('69', 334, 5, 27, 601713) He said he would not
('69', 334, 6, 28, 601734) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 2 Gandhiji was having a shave when the teachers arrived.
('69', 335, 0, 1, 601840) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 335, 1, 2, 601882) shave Harijans on the same terms as he was prepared to shave me, and I had to do without his services.
('69', 335, 1, 3, 601985) Now you find me having a shave with a foreign razor, though it is open to me to procure a village made one.
('69', 335, 1, 4, 602093) Here there is obviously an indefensible compromise.
('69', 335, 1, 5, 602145) And yet there is an explanation.
('69', 335, 1, 6, 602178) I have been sticking on to a set of shaving tackle given me by a loving sister, whose gift I could not resist and whose feelings I could not hurt by rejecting the foreign razor and insisting on having a village made one.
('69', 335, 1, 7, 602399) But there it is, the compromise is there.
('69', 335, 1, 8, 602441) I do not commend it for imitation.
('69', 335, 1, 9, 602476) We must be prepared to displease the dearest ones for the sake of principles.
('69', 335, 1, 10, 602554) There are eternal principles which admit of no compromise, and one must be prepared to lay down one’s life in the practice of them.
('69', 335, 1, 11, 602686) Supposing someone came and asked you to give up your religion and to embrace another at the point of the sword, would you do it?
('69', 335, 1, 12, 602815) Supposing someone were to compel you to drink wine or eat beef, or tell a lie, would you not rather lay down your life than yield to the coercion?
('69', 335, 1, 13, 602962) A principle is a principle, and in no case can it be watered down because of our incapacity to live it in practice.
('69', 335, 1, 14, 603078) We have to strive to achieve it, and the striving should be conscious, deliberate and hard.
('69', 335, 1, 15, 603170) Has not our Poet sung for all time that fearless striving is the very condition of freedom?
('69', 335, 2, 16, 603262) Where the mind is without fear, and the head is held high,...Where tireless striving stretches its arms towards perfection;...
('69', 335, 2, 17, 603389) Into that heaven of freedom, Oh Father, let my country awake.
('69', 335, 3, 18, 603451) Harijan, 5 9 1936
('69', 335, 4, 19, 603469) 437. TALK WITH BHARATAN KUMARAPPA 2
('69', 335, 5, 20, 603505) [Before September 2, 1936] I have no heart in this correspondence, no zest in it.
('69', 335, 5, 21, 603587) I am actually tired of it and feel like asking people not to write to me at all.
('69', 335, 5, 22, 603668) I long to wander among the villages around us rather than go to Wardha where so many friends are coming and I may have to go.
('69', 335, 5, 23, 603794) But I feel it a wrench to be torn from my work.
('69', 335, 5, 24, 603842) It is, if I may call it, my sadhana, and I would, if I could, not let anything interrupt it.
('69', 335, 6, 25, 603935) 1 Gitanjali, 35 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('69', 336, 0, 1, 604000) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 337
('69', 336, 1, 2, 604044) two or three engagements which I accepted long ago and I shall have to keep them, though I would love to find some excuse to put them off or avoid them.
('69', 336, 1, 3, 604197) I would like to walk out every morning to the villages in our neighbourhood.
('69', 336, 1, 4, 604274) I am doing practically little physical work now, and I am longing to do it.
('69', 336, 1, 5, 604350) We have taken a couple of cows and are trying the experiment of making our own ghee.
('69', 336, 1, 6, 604435) Now I should like to look after the cow myself, look after her feed and her general upkeep.
('69', 336, 1, 7, 604527) My idea is to show these villagers that a cow can easily pay for her feed and the charges of her upkeep.
('69', 336, 1, 8, 604632) Then look at the number of ailments these villagers suffer from, and how they will try all kinds of quack remedies but will not do the simplest things they must do.
('69', 336, 1, 9, 604797) All this is slow work, and it is no use expecting startling results as those of the Five Year Plan in Soviet Russia.
('69', 336, 1, 10, 604914) We have to realize that we are eating the salt of the poor, and we have to make an adequate return to them.
('69', 336, 1, 11, 605022) Never mind if you do not get agents for this difficult work.
('69', 336, 1, 12, 605083) If we have only one genuine agent, I should be satisfied.
('69', 336, 1, 13, 605141) Indeed I should not worry even if we had none.
('69', 336, 1, 14, 605188) Our acid test is: Have we organized any single village according to our programme?
('69', 336, 1, 15, 605271) Have we introduced food reform there?
('69', 336, 1, 16, 605309) Are their roads and their lanes clean and perfect?
('69', 336, 1, 17, 605360) Have we revived any industries?
('69', 336, 1, 18, 605392) Have we tackled the problem of drink and vice?
('69', 336, 1, 19, 605439) If we could do this successfully even in one village, I should think we had achieved a good deal.
('69', 336, 1, 20, 605537) From individuals you may get a response but I should not call it making headway.
('69', 336, 1, 21, 605618) Making headway is touching one whole village.
('69', 336, 1, 22, 605664) Jajuji 1 was wondering if we might not have a wider scheme.
('69', 336, 1, 23, 605724) No, we cannot have it.
('69', 336, 1, 24, 605747) It is not one item of work like hand spinning for instance.
('69', 336, 1, 25, 605807) It is whole village work, and today our work centres round three or four things I have mentioned.
('69', 336, 1, 26, 605905) It may centre round thirty things some day, but not today.
('69', 336, 2, 27, 605964) Harijan, 5 9 1936

('69', 338, 4, 6, 607429) 443. GOD OF LOVE, NOT WAR
('69', 338, 5, 7, 607455) The Statesman of Delhi has devoted four articles to an unmeasured condemnation of the no war movement led by Canon Sheppard and other earnest Christians in England.
('69', 338, 5, 8, 607620) The paper has dragged into its support the authority of the Bhagavad Gita in these words:
('69', 338, 6, 9, 607710) Indeed the true but difficult teaching of Christianity seems to be that society must fight its enemies but love them.
('69', 338, 7, 10, 607828) Such, too,—will Mr. Gandhi please note—is the clear teaching of the Bhagavad Gita, where Krishna tells Arjuna that victory also goes to him who fights with complete fearlessness and is utterly devoid of hatred.
('69', 338, 7, 11, 608039) Indeed on the highest plane the argument between the conscientious objector and the knightly warrior is for ever settled in the second book of that great classic.
('69', 338, 7, 12, 608202) We have little space to quote and the whole poem deserves to be read not once but many times.
('69', 338, 7, 13, 608296) The writer of the articles perhaps does not know that the terrorist has also used in his defence the very verses quoted by him.
('69', 338, 7, 14, 608424) But the fact is that a dispassionate reading of the Bhagavad Gita has revealed to me a meaning wholly contrary to the one given to it by the Statesman writer.
('69', 338, 7, 15, 608583) He has forgotten that Arjuna was no conscientious objector in the sense the Western war resisters are.
('69', 338, 7, 16, 608686) Arjuna believed in war.
('69', 338, 7, 17, 608710) He had fought the Kaurava hosts many times before.
('69', 338, 7, 18, 608761) But he was unnerved when the two armies were drawn up in battle array and when he suddenly realized that he had to fight his nearest kinsmen and revered
('69', 338, 8, 19, 608914) 1 This was conveyed by Mahadev Desai to Amrit Kaur in a letter which, inter alia, read: “[Gandhiji] deliberately went to the hospital in order that the doctor may not have to be troubled over and over again.
('69', 338, 8, 20, 609122) He is being properly looked after and is progressing well.
('69', 338, 8, 21, 609181) There was no fever until 2.30 [p.m.] Even if it does come, I am sure it will be mild.
('69', 338, 8, 22, 609267) He is taking complete rest .
('69', 339, 0, 1, 609296) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 339, 1, 2, 609338) teachers.
('69', 339, 1, 3, 609348) It was not love of man or the hatred of war that had actuated the questioner.
('69', 339, 1, 4, 609426) Krishna could give no other answer than he did.
('69', 339, 1, 5, 609474) The immortal author of the Mahabharata, of which the Gita is one—no doubt the brightest—of the many gems contained in that literary mine, has shown to the world the futility of war by giving the victors an empty glory, leaving but seven victors alive out of millions said to have been engaged in the fight in which unnamable atrocities were used on either side.
('69', 339, 1, 6, 609836) But the Mahabharata has a better message even than the demonstration of war as a delusion and a folly.
('69', 339, 1, 7, 609939) It is the spiritual history of man considered as an immortal being and has used with a magnifying lens a historical episode considered in his times of moment for the tiny world round him but in terms of present day values of no significance.
('69', 339, 1, 8, 610181) In those days the globe had not shrunk to a pinhead, as it has today, on which the slightest movement on one spot affects the whole.
('69', 339, 1, 9, 610314) The Mahabharata depicts for all time the eternal struggle that goes on daily between the forces of good and evil in the human breast and in which though good is ever victorious evil does put up a brave show and baffles even the keenest conscience.
('69', 339, 1, 10, 610562) It shows also the only way to right action.
('69', 339, 1, 11, 610606) But whatever the true message of the Bhagavad Gita may be, what matters to the leaders of the peace movement is not what the Gita says but what the Bible, which is their spiritual dictionary, says and then, too, not what meaning the Church authorities give to it, but what meaning a prayerful reading of it yields to the reader.
('69', 339, 1, 12, 610935) What matters most of all is the objector’s knowledge of the implications of the law of love or ahimsa, inadequately rendered in English as non violence.
('69', 339, 1, 13, 611088) The articles of The Statesman are perhaps a fair challenge to the objectors.
('69', 339, 1, 14, 611165) I am sorry I do not know enough of the movement to give a definite opinion.
('69', 339, 1, 15, 611241) My opinion need have no weight whatsoever with the objectors.
('69', 339, 1, 16, 611303) But it has, inasmuch as I know intimately some of them, who even correspond with me.
('69', 339, 1, 17, 611388) And now they have gone a step further in that they have adopted alomst as their textbook Mr. Richard Gregg’s book called The Power of Non violence which is claimed by its author to be a Westen interpretation of what non violence as I interpret it stands for.
('69', 339, 1, 18, 611647) It may not therefore be presumptuous on my part if I set down without argument the implications and conditions of success of non violence.
('69', 339, 1, 19, 611786) Here they are:
('69', 339, 2, 20, 611801) (1) Non violence is the law of the human race and is infinitely greater than and superior to brute force.
('69', 340, 0, 1, 611907) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 341
('69', 340, 1, 2, 611951) (2) In the last resort it does not avail to those who do not possess a living faith in the God of Love.
('69', 340, 1, 3, 612055) (3) Non violence affords the fullest protection to one’s selfrespect and sense of honour, but not always to possession of land or movable property, though its habitual practice does prove a better bulwark than the possession of armed men to defend them.
('69', 340, 1, 4, 612309) Non violence in the very nature of things is of no assistance in the defence of ill gotten gains and immoral acts.
('69', 340, 1, 5, 612424) (4) Individuals or nations who would practise non violence must be prepared to sacrifice (nations to the last man) their all except honour.
('69', 340, 1, 6, 612564) It is therefore inconsistent with the possession of other people’s countries, i.e., modern imperialism which is frankly based on force for its defence.
('69', 340, 1, 7, 612716) (5) Non violence is a power which can be wielded equally by all—children, young men and women or grown up people— provided they have a living faith in the God of love and have therefore equal love for all mankind.
('69', 340, 1, 8, 612930) When non violence is accepted as the law of life it must pervade the whole being and not applied to isolated acts.
('69', 340, 1, 9, 613045) (6) It is a profound error to suppose that whilst the law is good enough for individuals it is not for masses of mankind.
('69', 340, 2, 10, 613167) Harijan, 5 9 1936
('69', 340, 3, 11, 613185) 444. WHAT A GIRL NEEDS
('69', 340, 4, 12, 613208) A fair correspondent writes: 1
('69', 340, 5, 13, 613239) Your article “Avoidable Misery” 2 seems to me to be incomplete....If parents were to educate their daughters as they educate their sons, so as to enable them to earn an independent living, they would not have to worry themselves over the selection of husbands for their daughters....
('69', 340, 5, 14, 613523) When girls have had the opportunity of developing their minds fairly and are able to support themselves in a dignified manner, they have no difficulty, when they are desirous of marrying, in being suitably matched...
('69', 340, 5, 15, 613740) What I plead for is a training of girls in useful knowledge and some calling that would make them fully confident about their ability to face the world and not to feel dependent upon parents or their future husbands....
('69', 340, 5, 16, 613960) I wish you could emphasize this
('69', 340, 6, 17, 613992) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('69', 340, 6, 18, 614029) 2 Vide “Avoidable Misery”, 25 7 1936
('69', 341, 0, 1, 614066) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 341, 1, 2, 614108) aspect of the question in considering the difficulties of parents having on their hands daughters of marriageable age!!
('69', 341, 1, 3, 614228) I heartily endorse the sentiments expressed by my correspondent.
('69', 341, 1, 4, 614293) Only I had to deal with the case of a parent who had made himself miserable not because he had an incompetent daughter, but because he and perhaps even his daughter wanted to restrict themselves, in the choice of a husband, to their own little caste.
('69', 341, 1, 5, 614544) The ‘ accomplishment’ of the girl was itself a hindrance in this case.
('69', 341, 1, 6, 614615) If the girl was illiterate, she could have accommodated herself to any young man.
('69', 341, 1, 7, 614697) But being an accomplished girl, naturally she would need an equally accomplished husband.
('69', 341, 1, 8, 614787) It is our misfortune that the sordidness of exacting a price for marrying a girl is not regarded as a decided disqualification.
('69', 341, 1, 9, 614915) An altogether artificial value is put upon English collegiate education.
('69', 341, 1, 10, 614988) It covers a multitude of sins.
('69', 341, 1, 11, 615019) If the definition of ‘accomplishment’ was more sensible than it has become among the classes whose educated young men exact a price for accepting marriage proposals on behalf of girls, the difficulty of selecting suitable matches for girls would be much lessened, If not entirely removed.
('69', 341, 1, 12, 615308) Whilst, therefore, I commend the proposal of my fair correspondent to the attention of parents, I must insist on the necessity of breaking down the highly injurious caste barriers.
('69', 341, 1, 13, 615489) Breaking down the barriers will widen the range of choice and thus in a great measure prevent exactions.

('69', 350, 8, 23, 630838) 458. WHAT IT IS LIKE
('69', 350, 9, 24, 630859) The recent debate between Dr. Sokhey and Dr. Mangaldas Mehta on the ever green topic of birth control emboldens me to disclose the opinion of the late Dr. Ansari of revered memory
('69', 350, 10, 25, 631039) 1 A thin crisp chapati 2 The addressee has placed this letter in August/September, 1936. It appears to have been written from the hospital in Wardha where Gandhiji’s food used to be sent from Maganwadi; vide the preceding item.
('69', 350, 10, 26, 631267) Gandhiji was discharged on September 12.
('69', 351, 0, 1, 631308) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 351, 1, 2, 631350) supporting Dr. Mangaldas’s position.
('69', 351, 1, 3, 631387) It was now nearly a year ago I wrote to the deceased asking him whether as a medical man he could endorse the position I had taken up on the vexed question.
('69', 351, 1, 4, 631544) Much to my agreeable surprise he wrote heartily supporting it.
('69', 351, 1, 5, 631607) When I was in Delhi last, I had a brief discussion with him on the subject and he promised at my request to contribute a series of articles showing by facts and figures from his own experience and that of other medical men how the practice had hurt both men and women who were party to it.
('69', 351, 1, 6, 631897) He gave a graphic account of the condition to which the men were reduced after they had mated for some time with their wives or other women who they knew were using contraceptives.
('69', 351, 1, 7, 632078) Freedom from the fear of the natural consequence of coition had made them reckless in self indulgence leading to an inordinate craving for seeing women which ended in dementia.
('69', 351, 1, 8, 632255) he died just when he was about to write the promised series.
('69', 351, 1, 9, 632316) Bernard Shaw is reported to have said that coition accompanied by the use of contraceptives was nothing less than sexual masturbat ion.
('69', 351, 1, 10, 632452) A moment’s reflection would show how accurate the description is.
('69', 351, 1, 11, 632518) I receive almost daily piteous letters from students and some times even from teachers complaining how they had become slaves to the habit and were being gradually reduced to loss of manhood.
('69', 351, 1, 12, 632710) Recall, too, the correspondence 1 published in these columns from the principal of the Sanatan Dharma College, Lahore, bitterly complai ning of teachers practising unnatural vice on their pupils and the consequences of the practice on their health and character.
('69', 351, 1, 13, 632973) The deduction I draw from these examples is that even the union between husband and wife bereft of the possibility of its natural consequence must cause the same ruination that invariably attends masturbation or unnatural vice.
('69', 351, 1, 14, 633201) It is the philanthropic motive that no doubt impels many birth control reformers to a whirlwind campaign in favour of the use of contraceptives.
('69', 351, 1, 15, 633346) I invite them to contemplate the ruinous consequ ences of their misplaced philanthropy.
('69', 351, 1, 16, 633434) Those whom they want to reach will never use them in any appreciable numbers.
('69', 351, 1, 17, 633512) Those who ought not to use them will, without doubt, use them to the undoing of themselves and their partners.
('69', 351, 1, 18, 633623) This would not matter in the least if the use of contraceptives was incontestably proved to be right physically
('69', 351, 2, 19, 633735) 1 Vide “A Growing Vice”, 27 4 1935
('69', 352, 0, 1, 633770) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 353
('69', 352, 1, 2, 633814) and morally.
('69', 352, 1, 3, 633827) Dr. Ansari’s opinion, if my testimony about it is accepted, is a grave warning to the reformers and would be reformers.
('69', 352, 2, 4, 633947) Harijan, 12 9 1936

('69', 357, 4, 22, 642073) 467. LETTER TO SUBHAS CHANDRA BOSE
('69', 357, 5, 23, 642108) September 13, 1936
('69', 357, 6, 24, 642127) MY DEAR SUBHAS, I hope you were given my wire in reply to your kind enquiry.
('69', 357, 6, 25, 642204) My fever—an attack after twelve years of freedom—was the cause of the lateness of my reply to your questions.
('69', 357, 6, 26, 642314) (1) Tea or coffee I do not consider to be essential to health.
('69', 357, 6, 27, 642377) They often do harm.
('69', 357, 6, 28, 642397) They may remain harmless, if tea is weak and straw colour and coffee drunk with plenty of milk with only a spoonful or two of coffee.
('69', 357, 6, 29, 642531) (2) If received fresh from the udder well cleaned and from a healthy cow, milk drunk fresh unboiled unwarmed is the best food.
('69', 357, 6, 30, 642658) Next best is pasteurized milk.
('69', 357, 6, 31, 642689) For some stomachs sweet curds are the best.
('69', 357, 6, 32, 642733) They having the yeast obviate even the use of fruit.
('69', 357, 6, 33, 642786) (3) Leafy vegetables must always be taken, better if taken as salads.
('69', 357, 6, 34, 642856) All leaves are not edible in the raw state.
('69', 357, 6, 35, 642900) Onion, pumpkin with
('69', 358, 0, 1, 642920) VOL. 69 : 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 359
('69', 358, 1, 2, 642964) the skin, pandora, brinjal, lady’s finger, turnips, carrots, parsnips, cabbage, cauliflower are good additions to leaves.
('69', 358, 1, 3, 643086) Potatoes and starchy tubers should be taken sparingly.
('69', 358, 1, 4, 643141) (4) Dates are a fine food for a healthy stomach.
('69', 358, 1, 5, 643190) Raisins are more digestible.
('69', 358, 1, 6, 643219) I can take both freely but all cannot.
('69', 358, 1, 7, 643258) All can take raisins and sultanas.
('69', 358, 1, 8, 643293) (5) Garlic and onion in a raw state are strongly recommended in the West.
('69', 358, 1, 9, 643367) I take raw garlic regularly for blood pressure.
('69', 358, 1, 10, 643415) It is the best antitoxin for internal use.
('69', 358, 1, 11, 643458) It is also recommended for tubercular patients.
('69', 358, 1, 12, 643506) I think the prejudice against these two harmless vegetables is due to the odour which is the essence of them and it arose with the rise of Vaishnavism.
('69', 358, 1, 13, 643658) Ayurveda sings the praise of both unstintingly.
('69', 358, 1, 14, 643706) Garlic is called poor man’s musk and so it is.
('69', 358, 1, 15, 643753) I do not know what villagers would do without garlic and onion.
('69', 358, 1, 16, 643817) (6) Yes, lemons and gur or honey are a good substitute for sweet oranges.
('69', 358, 1, 17, 643891) I think this answers all your questions.
('69', 358, 1, 18, 643932) I hope you are well.
('69', 358, 1, 19, 643953) I would like to know the result of Drs.
('69', 358, 1, 20, 643993) Sircar’s and Roy’s examination.
('69', 358, 1, 21, 644025) M. K. GANDHI
