('69', 363, 1, 2, 651292) 475. LETTER TO H. L. SHARMA
('69', 363, 2, 3, 651320) September 14, 1936
('69', 363, 3, 4, 651339) SHARMA, I have your letter.
('69', 363, 3, 5, 651367) I do not have anyone of the kind you want.
('69', 363, 3, 6, 651410) You must yourself find such men.
('69', 363, 3, 7, 651443) Your idea of staying in a village does not appeal to me in the least.
('69', 363, 3, 8, 651513) At the moment we cannot spend so much money for propaganda work among the villages.
('69', 363, 3, 9, 651597) Do not expect any help from me in this programme.
('69', 363, 3, 10, 651647) Even now I would suggest that you start your work without any money, settle down in a village and assess your ability.
('69', 363, 3, 11, 651766) But I find you have your head in the sky, while I am a creature of the earth and do not want to move my feet away from the earth.
('69', 363, 3, 12, 651896) It seems, therefore, that our paths at present are different.
('69', 363, 3, 13, 651958) What will you gain by going to Satis Babu’s?

('69', 372, 6, 23, 666616) ABOUT TARABEHN MARY CHESLEY
('69', 372, 7, 24, 666644) Almost every foreign mail, letters are being received from the late Mary Chesley’s relatives and friends extolling her many virtues and telling me of the benefactions received by most of them from her and of promises of help made by her and even a will or wills left by her.
('69', 372, 7, 25, 666919) Though Mahadev Desai has been giving these correspondents such detailed information as he can during the limited time at his disposal, it is necessary to make a public announcement for the benefit of all concerned that the will made by her in my favour just before her lamented death does not, in the opinion of legal friends, appear to be valid according to the Indian Succession Act.
('69', 372, 7, 26, 667305) Even if it
('69', 373, 0, 1, 667316) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 373, 1, 2, 667358) can be proved, I have no desire whatsoever to use her property, except with the concurrence of her relatives and friends, for the sake of the Indian village industries work, which was her latest and last love for which she slaved and died heroically.
('69', 373, 1, 3, 667609) If the property came into my hands, of which there is very little chance, I should examine all her commitments and promises in the West and try to satisfy them before making use of anything left by her undisposed of in her lifetime.
('69', 373, 1, 4, 667842) I have cheques coming from her Bank which lie with me uncashed.
('69', 373, 1, 5, 667906) My advice to her cousins, of whom I see there are many, is that the nearest of them should take out letters of administration and send me legal authority to part with whatever is in my hands or Miss Mary Barr’s.
('69', 373, 1, 6, 668118) I possess the uncashed cheques and the latter her papers and trinkets.
('69', 373, 1, 7, 668189) The deceased had so reduced her personal wants in India that there is hardly anything left which can be converted into money.
('69', 373, 1, 8, 668315) All she received during her lifetime was generally made over to me for village work.
('69', 373, 1, 9, 668400) I hope this gives to all concerned such information as is in my possession about the affairs of the deceased humanitarian.

('69', 374, 3, 7, 670190) 491. OF MY RECENT ILLNESS
('69', 374, 4, 8, 670216) I would not tax the reader about my recent malaria fever except for the fact that friends are involved in the decision I have prayerfully made and which I hope God will let me fulfil.
('69', 374, 4, 9, 670400) It went against the grain for me, a confirmed believer in nature cure methods, to go to Wardha and seek admission to the hospital.
('69', 374, 4, 10, 670531) Left entirely to myself, I would have treated myself in accordance with nature cure methods as far as possible.
('69', 374, 4, 11, 670643) But I could not do so without offending the friends who happened to be near me at the time.
('69', 374, 4, 12, 670735) I knew that Jamnalalji too had a special responsibility, in that I had settled in a village near Wardha, his permanent place of residence.
('69', 374, 4, 13, 670874) With the choice of the village he has had nothing to do.
('69', 374, 4, 14, 670931) It was entirely Mirabehn’s and it was made because Segaon was predominantly a Harijan village and far enough from Wardha and yet not too far.
('69', 374, 4, 15, 671073) I was drawn to the village in accordance with a certain declaration I had made when Mirabehn went to Segaon.
('69', 374, 4, 16, 671182) Jamnalalji to an extent and Sardar Vallabhbhai altogether were against my settling in a village as yet and then in Segaon.
('69', 374, 4, 17, 671305) But I bore down their opposition when I told them that I was bound by the declaration to which I have referred to settle down in Segaon.
('69', 374, 4, 18, 671442) No doubt the promise was agreeable to me for my heart was in the village.
('69', 374, 4, 19, 671516) Having gone to Segaon it was my intention not to stir out of it for full three seasons, i.
('69', 374, 4, 20, 671607) e., one year.
('69', 374, 4, 21, 671621) Unfortunately there are obligations undertaken before the decision to settle in Segaon, which I shall have to fulfil and which will disturb the unbroken year’s stay.
('69', 374, 4, 22, 671787) I urge friends, therefore, not to make further inroads upon the period.
('69', 374, 4, 23, 671859) For me it is my sadhana.
('69', 374, 4, 24, 671884) I set the greatest value upon the village problem.
('69', 374, 4, 25, 671935) It may not be put off except at the cost of our very existence.
('69', 374, 4, 26, 671999) India lives in her villages, not in her cities.
('69', 374, 4, 27, 672047) I am supposed to guide and direct the village industries movement to which at Bombay an autonomous existence was given by the

('69', 375, 1, 20, 673965) I am fatalist enough to believe that no one can put off the hour of death when it has struck.
('69', 375, 1, 21, 674059) Not the greatest medical assistance available has saved kings and emperors from the jaws of death.

('69', 381, 9, 18, 684470) 500. LETTER TO G.D. BIRLA
('69', 381, 10, 19, 684496) September 21, 1936
('69', 381, 11, 20, 684515) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, I become more and more convinced each day that for Harijan work in each province the necessary funds should be raised within the province.
('69', 381, 11, 21, 684673) If money has to be provided by the centre to enable provinces to carry on their work, work thus accomplished cannot be enduring.
('69', 381, 11, 22, 684802) We shall also not be able to gauge the feelings of the caste Hindu.
('69', 381, 11, 23, 684870) Rather than we should be forced later to cut down on our work, it is better that we should recognize our limitations.
('69', 381, 11, 24, 684988) What it means is that each province should now submit its budget in the light of the above and having examined these budgets we should then provide to each province such assistance as may be feasible for a year or two.

('69', 389, 0, 1, 697654) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 389, 1, 2, 697696) 510. PREFACE TO “GITAPADARTHAKOSHA” 1
('69', 389, 2, 3, 697734) SEGAON, WARDHA, September 24, 1936
('69', 389, 3, 4, 697769) Kakasaheb has explained in his own foreword why this kosha, which was prepared twelve years ago 2 and which has not come up to the required standard yet, is being published today.
('69', 389, 3, 5, 697949) This kosha is indeed necessary for those who are at all interested in the translation 3 which has been published under my name.
('69', 389, 3, 6, 698077) Maybe it will be useful to other students of the Gita as well.
('69', 389, 3, 7, 698140) To them I would suggest that if they do not like the interpretations given in the Padarthakosha and prefer others, they should note these down in the book itself.
('69', 389, 3, 8, 698303) By doing so, they will have a glossary of their own liking with very little effort.
('69', 389, 3, 9, 698387) And if such students send me the interpretations of their choice, I shall be grateful.
('69', 389, 3, 10, 698474) The more I study the Gita, the more I am made aware of its uniqueness.
('69', 389, 3, 11, 698545) For me, it is a spiritual dictionary.
('69', 389, 3, 12, 698583) Whenever I am in doubt as to what I should or should not do, I fall back upon it, and so far it has never disappointed me.
('69', 389, 3, 13, 698706) It is indeed a Kamadhenu 4. In the beginning, we recited one sloka a day, then two, then five, then a chapter a day, then a complete recitation in two weeks and, finally, in the last few years some of us have been able to do a complete recita tion in seven days.
('69', 389, 3, 14, 698969) And on particular days of the week the sound of particular chapters is heard around 4.30 a.m.
('69', 389, 3, 15, 699063) Some—a very few— have learnt all the eighteen chapters by heart.
('69', 389, 3, 16, 699128) The morning prayers include the chapters in the following order during the days of the week.
('69', 389, 3, 17, 699221) Friday I, II Tuesday XIII, XIV, XV Saturday III, IV, V Wednesday XVI, XXII Sunday VI, VII, VIII Thursday XVIII.
('69', 389, 3, 18, 699333) Monday IX, X, XI, XII
('69', 389, 4, 19, 699355) 1 This appeared in the book under the title Request to Readers and also in Harijanbandhu, 25 10 1936, under the title “Gitarupi Kamadhenu”.
('69', 389, 4, 20, 699495) A padarthakosha is a concordance as well as a glossary.
('69', 389, 4, 21, 699551) 2 Gandhiji had prepared this Padarthakosha while in the Yeravda jail in 1922 24; vide “My Jail Experiences XI”, 17 9 1924 3 Anasaktiyoga; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 23 5 1935 4 Mythical cow that gave anything that was desired
('69', 390, 0, 1, 699784) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 391
('69', 390, 1, 2, 699827) Suffice it to say that there has been some deliberation behind this schedule.
('69', 390, 1, 3, 699905) Our experience has been that this order facilitates understanding of the text.
('69', 390, 1, 4, 699984) It may well be asked why the recitation has to begin on a Friday.
('69', 390, 1, 5, 700050) The reason for this is simply the following: For considerable length of time a complete recitation used to take fourteen days.
('69', 390, 1, 6, 700177) In the Yeravda jail I thought of a seven day recitation and the idea was put into effect on a Friday.
('69', 390, 1, 7, 700279) In this way and since that day, the recitation week begins on a Friday.
('69', 390, 1, 8, 700351) There are two reasons why I mention the matter of complete recitation here: to show how far devotion to the Gita has taken some of us up to date and to indicate to the reader the way to encourage its study.
('69', 390, 1, 9, 700558) But we are not to rest content with merely reciting the Gita.
('69', 390, 1, 10, 700620) It is a spiritual dictionary; it is a tremendous force for straightening the creases of the soul; it is the refuge of the afflicted; it is an awakener from stupor.
('69', 390, 1, 11, 700784) Only those who have this faith can derive help from reciting the Gita.
('69', 390, 1, 12, 700855) I do not in the least suggest that recitation of the Gita without an understanding of its meaning is by itself beneficial to a man.
('69', 390, 1, 13, 700987) With sufficient effort a tame parrot can certainly be taught to memorize the Gita.
('69', 390, 1, 14, 701070) But that is not going to bring the slightest merit either to the parrot or to its trainer.
('69', 390, 1, 15, 701161) The Gita is the living, life giving immortal mother.
('69', 390, 1, 16, 701214) The mother who suckled us will one day disappear and leave us in the lurch.
('69', 390, 1, 17, 701290) We see countless mothers failing to protect their children from peril.
('69', 390, 1, 18, 701361) But one who seeks the support of Mother Gita saves himself from the greatest peril.
('69', 390, 1, 19, 701445) She is ever wakeful and she never lets one down.
('69', 390, 1, 20, 701494) But a mother will not give one nourishment unless one asks for it.
('69', 390, 1, 21, 701561) Mother Gita too gives nothing without our asking for it.
('69', 390, 1, 22, 701618) Before taking anyone under her wing she tests him severely, expects whole hearted devotion.
('69', 390, 1, 23, 701710) The devotion, too, should not be dry.
('69', 390, 1, 24, 701748) She wants single minded devotion.
('69', 390, 1, 25, 701782) Hence, she plainly refuses to help those who are not prepared to surrender their all to her.
('69', 390, 1, 26, 701875) The student of physics gains an insight into his subject only when he is crazy after it.
('69', 390, 1, 27, 701964) Those who obtain M.A. and B.A. degrees read day and night, spend money and put themselves to great physical strain.
('69', 390, 1, 28, 702080) From amongst those who make such efforts, only a few are successful at the first attempt.

('69', 390, 1, 30, 702261) And in the
('69', 391, 0, 1, 702272) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 391, 1, 2, 702314) For those who wish to drink the nectar that is the Gita, much greater effort than this should be and is required.
('69', 391, 1, 3, 702428) But how many want to partake of that nectar?

('69', 391, 1, 11, 703087) May it bear fruit.

('69', 398, 4, 6, 713100) 524. THE LAW OF OUR BEING
('69', 398, 5, 7, 713126) The Statesman has devoted a reasoned article to the argument advanced by me in reply 1 to its criticism of Canon Sheppard’s war against war.
('69', 398, 5, 8, 713267) In that article a very clever attempt has been made to dispute the whole of the position taken up by me.
('69', 398, 5, 9, 713372) The writer says that whilst the Bhagavad Gita assists him, it does not assist the terrorist.
('69', 398, 5, 10, 713465) Once you admit the lawfulness of the use of physical force for purposes other than the benefit of the person against whom it is used, as in the case of a surgeon against his patient, you cannot draw an arbitrary line of distinction.
('69', 398, 5, 11, 713698) The Mahabharata, of which the Gita is only a tiny chapter, describes in gruesome detail a night slaughter of the innocents which, but for our recent experiences of our civilized war, would be considered unbelievable in actual practice.
('69', 398, 5, 12, 713934) The grim fact is that the terrorists have in absolute honesty, earnestness and with cogency used the Gita, which some of them know by heart, in defence of their doctrine and policy.
('69', 398, 5, 13, 714116) Only they have no answer to my interpretation of the Gita, except to say that mine is wrong and theirs is right.
('69', 398, 5, 14, 714229) Time alone will show whose isright.
('69', 398, 5, 15, 714265) The Gita is not a theoretical treatise.
('69', 398, 5, 16, 714305) It is a living but silent guide whose directions one has to understand by patient striving.
('69', 398, 5, 17, 714397) The Statesman writer next likens Canon Sheppard’s position to that of Arjuna.
('69', 398, 5, 18, 714475) Surely this is a faulty analogy, hastily drawn.
('69', 398, 5, 19, 714523) Arjuna was the Commander in Chief of the Pandava forces.
('69', 398, 5, 20, 714580) He became suddenly paralysed when he contemplated the awful scene before him.
('69', 398, 5, 21, 714658) As general he knew exactly what he had to do.
('69', 398, 5, 22, 714704) He knew that he had to war against his cousins.
('69', 398, 5, 23, 714752) His paralysis was due to momentary weakness.
('69', 398, 5, 24, 714797) He could not have given up the task before him without creating the utmost confusion and disorder, and bringing disgrace on himself and his innumerable friends and followers.
('69', 398, 5, 25, 714972) He was bound to engage himself and his followers in the terrible slaughter for which he
('69', 398, 6, 26, 715060) 1 Vide “God of Love, Not War”, 5 9 1936
('69', 399, 0, 1, 715100) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 399, 1, 2, 715142) had trained himself and them.
('69', 399, 1, 3, 715172) It is profitless to conjecture what would have happened if non violence in thought, word and deed had suddenly but really possessed him.
('69', 399, 1, 4, 715309) That rich possession, let us hope, has come to Dick Sheppard and his companions.
('69', 399, 1, 5, 715390) Anyway, so far as I know, his position is wholly different from Arjuna’s.
('69', 399, 1, 6, 715464) He is no general of an army drawn up in battle array.
('69', 399, 1, 7, 715518) He makes no distinction between kinsmen and others.
('69', 399, 1, 8, 715570) For him man is man, no matter where he is born of what his skin is, or what he calls himself.
('69', 399, 1, 9, 715664) After having prayerfully searched through the book which for him is the Book of Life, he has been driven to the conclusion that he may not hurt his fellowmen for gain for himself or his country, and that therefore he must himself abstain from participation, direct or indirect, in war.
('69', 399, 1, 10, 715950) He naturally takes the next step of preaching to his neighbours the doctrine of peace or love and goodwill towards men without exception.
('69', 399, 1, 11, 716088) This is a position which Arjuna never took up.
('69', 399, 1, 12, 716135) But the Statesman writer has many strings to his bow.
('69', 399, 1, 13, 716189) And the strongest is his denial of non violence or love as the law of the human race.
('69', 399, 1, 14, 716275) If love or non violence be not the law of our being, the whole of my argument falls to pieces, and there is no escape from a periodical recrudescence of war, each succeeding one outdoing the preceding one in ferocity.
('69', 399, 1, 15, 716493) I cannot undertake, and least of all through a newspaper article written during moments snatched from the daily routine, to prove that love is the source and end of life.
('69', 399, 1, 16, 716664) But I venture to make some relevant suggestions which may pave the way for an understanding of the Law.
('69', 399, 1, 17, 716768) All the Teachers that ever lived have preached that law with more or less vigour.
('69', 399, 1, 18, 716850) If Love was not the law of life, life would not have persisted in the midst of death.
('69', 399, 1, 19, 716936) Life is a perpetual triumph over the grave.
('69', 399, 1, 20, 716980) If there is a fundamental distinction between man and beast, it is the former’s progressive recognition of the law and its application in practice to his own personal life.
('69', 399, 1, 21, 717153) All the saints of the world, ancient and modern, were each according to his light and capacity a living illustration of that supreme Law of our Being.
('69', 399, 1, 22, 717304) That the brute in us seems so often to gain an easy triumph is true enough. That, however, does not disprove the law.
('69', 399, 1, 23, 717422) It shows the difficulty of practice.
('69', 399, 1, 24, 717459) How should it be otherwise with a law which is as high as truth itself?When the practice of the law becomes universal, God will reign on earth as He does in Heaven.
('69', 399, 1, 25, 717624) I need not be reminded that earth and heaven are in us.
('69', 399, 1, 26, 717680) We know the earth, we are strangers to the Heaven within us.
('69', 399, 1, 27, 717741) If it is allowed that for some the practice of love

('69', 400, 1, 2, 717836) is possible, it is arrogance not to allow even the possibility of its practice in all the others.

('69', 400, 1, 4, 718054) No doubt in those days too there were Dick Sheppards who must have been laughed at and possibly pilloried for preaching (to them) the strange doctrine of refusing to eat fellow men.
('69', 400, 1, 5, 718236) Modern science is replete with illustrations of the seemingly impossible having become possible within living memory.
('69', 400, 1, 6, 718354) But the victories of physical science would be nothing against the victory of the Science of Life which is summed up in Love which is the Law of our Being.
('69', 400, 1, 7, 718510) I know that it cannot be proved by argument.
('69', 400, 1, 8, 718555) It shall be proved by persons living it in their lives in utter disregard of consequences to themselves.
('69', 400, 1, 9, 718660) There is no real gain without sacrifice.
('69', 400, 1, 10, 718701) And since demonstration of the Law of Love is the realest gain, sacrifice too must be the greatest required.
('69', 400, 1, 11, 718810) The rest of the argument advanced by the Statesman writer in refutation of mine needs no answer if the Law is recognized.
('69', 400, 1, 12, 718932) His argument is valid if the Law is denied or doubted.
('69', 400, 1, 13, 718987) One point may, however, be dealt with in passing.
('69', 400, 1, 14, 719037) The writer seems to pooh pooh the idea of honour derived from 1 individual and national gain.
('69', 400, 1, 15, 719131) He says: “What is this honour that would be left to a nation that voluntarily destroyed itself?” There is no question for one 2 of self destruction, voluntary or otherwise.
('69', 400, 1, 16, 719304) But there is of “anation allowing itself to be destroyed” for the sake of preserving its honour, as would be the case, say, if Indians died to the man, without lifting a finger, in their determination not to surrender to the will of an invading host.

('69', 400, 1, 18, 719684) Young Prahlad non violently risked his life to defend his honour, which consisted in his persistence in declaring his belief in God.
('69', 400, 1, 19, 719817) Jesus defended his honour and that of man when he preferred the death of a felon to the denial of his faith.

('69', 401, 3, 6, 720285) Please repeat it on a separate sheet.
('69', 401, 3, 7, 720323) Surely it is ‘idiotic’ to pass summer in Simla merely because you possess a house there.

('69', 401, 3, 9, 720492) Remember one of the attributes of non violence.
('69', 401, 3, 10, 720540) It seldom speaks, it simply and silently acts.
('69', 401, 3, 11, 720587) It appeals not to the intellect, it pierces the heart.
('69', 401, 3, 12, 720642) The more it speaks and argues, the less effective it becomes.
('69', 401, 3, 13, 720704) Therefore do not hesitate to let your case be lost by default.
('69', 401, 3, 14, 720767) Apparent defeat may be the hour of victory.
('69', 401, 3, 15, 720811) Speech is often a sign of weakness.
('69', 401, 3, 16, 720847) You will please give a trial to meat if Shummy says it is necessary.
('69', 401, 3, 17, 720916) Your vegetarianism will be on surer ground for your yielding now, if yielding becomes a duty.

('69', 403, 4, 6, 723343) 529. LETTER TO K. M. MUNSHI
('69', 403, 5, 7, 723371) September 26, 1936
('69', 403, 6, 8, 723390) BHAI MUNSHI,
('69', 403, 7, 9, 723403) Kakasaheb’s acquaintance with you has been growing and he is having the opportunity of reading your works.
('69', 403, 7, 10, 723510) He read Prithvi vallabh and has pressed me to read it and give my opinion on it.
('69', 403, 7, 11, 723591) I read it four days ago and now send my opinion direct to you.
('69', 403, 7, 12, 723654) Kakasaheb will read it.
('69', 403, 7, 13, 723678) You had already sent me some of your books when I was in jail where, however, I could read none of them.
('69', 403, 7, 14, 723783) You had even then asked for my opinion.
('69', 403, 7, 15, 723823) I read Prithvivallabh with interest.
('69', 403, 7, 16, 723860) Not one character appealed to me.
('69', 403, 7, 17, 723894) I did not at all wish to be like Munj.
('69', 403, 7, 18, 723933) Why so?
('69', 403, 7, 19, 723941) It would not be quite in the fitness of things for you to say that you delineate the characters as they are.
('69', 403, 7, 20, 724050) Some at least in this wide and varied world are likely to be noble, free from hypocrisy, loyal.
('69', 403, 7, 21, 724146) Mrinal you reduced to pieces, and poor Vilas melted like wax before Rasanidhi.
('69', 403, 7, 22, 724225) Could it be that men are so cunning and that even a forty year old, homely and self restrained woman would fall for a man’s love talk and suggestive gestures?
('69', 403, 7, 23, 724384) What does a man read for?
('69', 403, 7, 24, 724410) For mere enjoyment?
('69', 403, 7, 25, 724430) And that too so low?
('69', 403, 7, 26, 724451) Kalidasa wrote nothing of the kind.
('69', 403, 7, 27, 724487) Shakespeare made no such impression on me.
('69', 403, 7, 28, 724530) From them I learn something.
('69', 403, 7, 29, 724559) Why not from you?
('69', 403, 7, 30, 724577) Personally you appear to me nice and pleasant.
('69', 403, 7, 31, 724624) I am drawn to you.
('69', 403, 7, 32, 724643) I have hopes of getting much from you both.
('69', 403, 7, 33, 724687) How did I fail to get a glimpse of your personality in Prithvivallabh which is regarded—or isn’t it—your best work?
('69', 403, 7, 34, 724803) I have little hope that Kaka can solve this puzzle for me.
('69', 403, 7, 35, 724862) You alone can do it.
('69', 403, 7, 36, 724883) There is of course no question in this which calls for a reply immediately.
('69', 403, 7, 37, 724959) Now allow me to have a little fun.
('69', 403, 7, 38, 724994) Your last sentence is somewhat like this: Crushed under the elephant’s foot, Munj’s body lay flat like a rotlo 1. The word rotlo was all right; but did it ever occur

('69', 407, 1, 2, 729051) 536. LETTER TO LAKSHMI NARAYAN GADODIA
('69', 407, 2, 3, 729090) September 27, 1936
('69', 407, 3, 4, 729109) BHAI LAKSHMI NARAYANJI, I am very happy to see that you are both taken up with hydrot herapy.
('69', 407, 3, 5, 729203) Let this always continue.
('69', 407, 3, 6, 729229) You have found a pure altruistic activity in which both of you have such great faith and I see the greatest good where the energies of you both are equally applied.
('69', 407, 3, 7, 729394) I continued my morning hip bath even through the attack of malaria, and my walks too.
('69', 407, 3, 8, 729480) The hipbath still continues though the hour has been shifted to ten o’clock.
('69', 407, 3, 9, 729557) After the morning prayers I go to sleep and I cannot manage a walk after the hip bath at 10 o’clock.
('69', 407, 3, 10, 729658) Anyway I do go for walks twice a day.
('69', 407, 3, 11, 729696) I cannot take friction bath because due to lack of practice the foreskin cannot be drawn back in the required manner.
('69', 407, 3, 12, 729814) I had made an attempt on receiving your first letter.
('69', 407, 3, 13, 729868) The skin is intact and I used to take friction bath years ago.
('69', 407, 3, 14, 729931) I have not yet started having the abdominal mud pack at bedtime.
('69', 407, 3, 15, 729996) Formerly I used to try mud packs on many occasions and now I shall try it for your sake if for no other reason.
('69', 407, 3, 16, 730108) If I come across an honest naturopath, I would certainly keep him with me and popularize the treatment.
('69', 407, 3, 17, 730212) I have not so far found such a person.
('69', 407, 3, 18, 730251) Most of the hydropaths in India have reduced their treatment to a means of making money.
('69', 407, 3, 19, 730340) There are very few like your Moulvi Saheb, and they cannot give up their occupations.
('69', 407, 3, 20, 730426) What can we do under such circumstances?
('69', 407, 3, 21, 730467) I have thecheque for Rs. 200. I shall see how it can be utilized in Segaon.
('69', 407, 3, 22, 730543) Three fourths of the Segaon village is owned by Jamnalalji and he has authorized me to spend for the villagers’ benefit whatever returns he gets from the property and I think the amount is sufficient.
('69', 407, 3, 23, 730744) Hence I cannot tell you just now how and when I shall be able to use your Rs. 200 for the welfare of the people of Segaon.
('69', 407, 4, 24, 730867) Blessings from BAPU
('69', 407, 5, 25, 730887) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 5624

('69', 417, 13, 20, 744298) 556. REMNANT OF BARBARISM
('69', 417, 14, 21, 744324) We know by painful experience of what is daily happening in India that there are husbands enough who regard their wives as their property like their cattle or household furniture, and therefore think they have the right to beat them as they would their cattle.
('69', 417, 14, 22, 744585) But I was unprepared for a judicial endorsement of the brutal habit till a friend put into my hands a newspaper cutting reporting a decision of the Sessions Judge of Madura recognizing the legal right of a husband of beating his wife.
('69', 417, 14, 23, 744820) Fortunately an English Judge on going through the calendar detected this extraordinary Judgment of the Madura Sessions Judge and issued notice to the accused husband to show cause.
('69', 417, 14, 24, 745001) In due course the case was heard by Justices Pandurang Row and K. S.
('69', 418, 0, 1, 745070) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 419
('69', 418, 1, 2, 745113) Menon, whose judgement 1 I make apology for quoting below:
('69', 418, 2, 3, 745172) It is perhaps enough to say that though the learned Judge may be entitled to have his own views on the subject in a private capacity, yet he was not justfied in laying down the law in this manner from his seat on the Bench declaring that the husband has the right of punishing his wife by beating her for impudence or impertinence.
('69', 418, 2, 4, 745504) No such right is recognized by the Indian Penal Code and wife beating is not one of the exceptions in the chapter of ‘General Exceptions’.
('69', 418, 3, 5, 745643) One can easily imagine the serious consequences of such a declaration being made from the Bench by a Sessions Judge unless the declaration is declared to be wrong and unfounded by this court.
('69', 418, 3, 6, 745835) That is the reason why we thought it necessary to state in unmistakable terms that the learned Sessions Judge’s declaration of the rights of husbands in this regard has no foundation, so that no one may rely upon that in future as any justification or excuse for beating wives.
('69', 418, 3, 7, 746113) It has to be confessed with shame that even educated husbands are not free from the belief in the right of husbands to treat their wives as chattels and beat them whenever they feel the impulse to do so.
('69', 418, 3, 8, 746317) Would that this judgment would show them that such treatment of wives is a remnant of barbarism.
('69', 418, 4, 9, 746414) Harijan, 3 10 1936
('69', 418, 5, 10, 746433) 557. TEACHING OF HINDUISM
('69', 418, 6, 11, 746459) Referring to my recent articles 2 on the English peace movement led by Canon Sheppard, a friend writes:
('69', 418, 7, 12, 746563) I hold the view that independently of the context of the Gita and the preliminary conversation between Arjuna and Shri Krishna, Hinduism does not stand decisively for non violence in regard to organized invasion.
('69', 418, 7, 13, 746776) It would be straining too much to interpret all out best scriptures in this way.
('69', 418, 7, 14, 746857) Hinduism no doubt holds the spirit of compassion and love as the very highest duty for man.
('69', 418, 7, 15, 746949) But it does not preach what you or the pacifists preach, and it is no good straining everything into an allegory for this object.
('69', 418, 8, 16, 747079) 1 Of which only extracts are reproduced here.
('69', 418, 8, 17, 747125) 2 Vide “God of Love, Not War”, 5 9 1936 and “The Law of Our Being”, 26 9 1936
('69', 419, 0, 1, 747203) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 419, 1, 2, 747245) I have admitted in my introduction 1 to the Gita known as Anasaktiyoga that it is not a treatise on non violence nor was it written to condemn war.
('69', 419, 1, 3, 747393) Hinduism as it is practised today, or has even been known to have ever been practised, has certainly not condemned war as I do.
('69', 419, 1, 4, 747521) What, however, I have done is to put a new but natural and logical interpretation upon the whole teaching of the Gita and the spirit of Hinduism.
('69', 419, 1, 5, 747667) Hinduism, not to speak of other religions, is ever evolving.
('69', 419, 1, 6, 747728) It has no one scripture like the Quran or the Bible.
('69', 419, 1, 7, 747781) Its scriptures are also evolving and suffering addition.
('69', 419, 1, 8, 747838) The Gita itself is an instance in point.
('69', 419, 1, 9, 747879) It has given a new meaning to karma, sannyasa, yajna, etc.
('69', 419, 1, 10, 747938) It has breathed new life into Hinduism.
('69', 419, 1, 11, 747978) It has given an original rule of conduct.
('69', 419, 1, 12, 748020) Not that what the Gita has given was not implied in the previous writings, but the Gita put these implications in a concrete shape.
('69', 419, 1, 13, 748152) I have endeavoured in the light of a prayerful study of the other faiths of the world and, what is more, in the light of my own experiences in trying to live the teaching of Hinduism as interpreted in the Gita, to give an extended but in no way strained meaning to Hinduism, not as buried in its ample scriptures, but as a living faith speaking like a mother to her aching child.
('69', 419, 1, 14, 748532) What I have done is perfectly historical.
('69', 419, 1, 15, 748574) I have followed in the footsteps of our forefathers.
('69', 419, 1, 16, 748627) At one time they sacrificed animals to propitiate angry gods.
('69', 419, 1, 17, 748689) Their descendants, but our less remote ancestors, read a different meaning into the word ‘sacrifice’ and they taught that sacrifice was meant to be of our baser self, to please not angry gods but the one living God within.
('69', 419, 1, 18, 748912) I hold that the logical outcome of the teaching of the Gita is decidedly for peace at the price of life itself.
('69', 419, 1, 19, 749024) It is the highest aspiration of the human species.
('69', 419, 1, 20, 749075) The Mahabharata and the Ramayana, the two books that milli ons of Hindus know and regard as their guides, are undoubtedly allegories as the internal evidence shows.
('69', 419, 1, 21, 749240) That they most probably deal with historical figures does not affect my proposition.
('69', 419, 1, 22, 749325) Each epic describes the eternal duel that goes on between the forces of darkness and of light.
('69', 419, 1, 23, 749420) Anyway, I must disclaim any intention of straining the meaning of Hinduism or the Gita to suit any preconceived notions of mine.
('69', 419, 1, 24, 749549) My notions were an outcome of a study of the Gita, Ram ayana, Mahabharata, Upanishads, etc.

('69', 420, 1, 2, 749749) 558. HEADING FOR PROMISCUITY
('69', 420, 2, 3, 749778) Thus writes a young man:
('69', 420, 3, 4, 749803) You want everyone to become moral in order to change the world.
('69', 420, 3, 5, 749867) I do not exactly know what you mean by morality whether you confine it to matters sexual, or whether it covers the whole field of human conduct.
('69', 420, 3, 6, 750012) I suspect the former, because I do not see you pointing out to your capitalist and landlord friends the great injustice and harm they are doing by making huge profits at the expense of labourers and tenants, while you are never tired of castigating young men and women for their moral lapses in sexual matters and upholding before them the virtues of celibacy.
('69', 420, 3, 7, 750373) You claim to know the mind of Indian youth.
('69', 420, 3, 8, 750417) I do not claim to represent anybody, but as a solitary young man I beg to challenge your claim.
('69', 420, 3, 9, 750513) You do not seem to know through what environment the modern middle class youth is passing, what with long spells of unemployment, crushing social customs and traditions, and temptations of co education!
('69', 420, 3, 10, 750716) It is all a conflict between the old and the new ideas, resulting usually in the defect and misery of youth.
('69', 420, 3, 11, 750825) I humbly request you to be kind and compassionate to the youth and not to judge them by your puritanic standards of morality.
('69', 420, 3, 12, 750951) After all, I think every act, when it is performed with mutal consent and mutual love, is moral whether it is performed within marriage or without.
('69', 420, 3, 13, 751099) Since the invention of contraceptives the sexual basis of the institution of marriage has been knocked down.
('69', 420, 3, 14, 751208) It has now become an institution mainly for the protection and welfare of children.
('69', 420, 3, 15, 751292) You will, perhaps, be shocked at these ideas.
('69', 420, 3, 16, 751338) I would here venture to ask you not to forget your own youth when judging the present day youth.
('69', 420, 3, 17, 751435) You were an over sexed individual given to excessive indulgence, which seems to have created in you a sort of disgust towards the sexual act and hence your asceticism and the idea of sin.
('69', 420, 3, 18, 751623) Compared to you, I think many young men of today are better in this respect.
('69', 420, 4, 19, 751700) This is from a typical letter.
('69', 420, 4, 20, 751731) To my knowledge the writer has gone through several changes even during the past three months that I have known him.
('69', 420, 4, 21, 751848) He is still passing through a crisis.
('69', 420, 4, 22, 751886) The extract quoted is from a long letter which together with many of his other writings he would gladly have me publish.
('69', 420, 4, 23, 752007) But what I have quoted just represents the attitude of many a youth.
('69', 420, 4, 24, 752076) Of course my sympathies are with young men and young women.
('69', 420, 4, 25, 752136) I have a vivid recollection of the days of my own youth.
('69', 420, 4, 26, 752193) And it is because of my faith in the youth of the country that I am never tired of dealing with problems that face them.

('69', 421, 1, 2, 752484) And religion divorced from morality is like ‘sounding brass’ good only for making a noise and breaking heads.
('69', 421, 1, 3, 752594) Morality includes truth, ahimsa and continence.
('69', 421, 1, 4, 752642) Every virtue that mankind has ever practised is referable to and derived from these three fundamental virtues.
('69', 421, 1, 5, 752753) Non violence and continence are again derivable from Truth, which for me is God.

('69', 421, 1, 17, 754139) Since my own experiences are relevant to the consideration of the sex problem, let me just warn the reader who has not read my autobiographical chapters against drawing the conclusion that my correspondent has drawn about my sins of indulgence.
('69', 421, 1, 18, 754384) Whatever over indulgence there was with me, it was strictly restricted to my wife.
('69', 421, 1, 19, 754467) And I was living in a big joint family where there was hardly any privacy except for a few hours at night.
('69', 421, 1, 20, 754574) I awoke to the folly of indulgence for the sake of it even when I was twenty three years old, and decided upon total brahmacharya in 1899, 1 i.e., when I was thirty years old.
('69', 421, 1, 21, 754750) It is wrong to call me an ascetic.
('69', 421, 1, 22, 754785) The ideals that regulate my life are presented for acceptance by mankind in general.
('69', 421, 1, 23, 754870) I have arrived at
('69', 421, 2, 24, 754888) 1 However, Gandhiji actually, took the vow in 1906; vide “An Autobiography” sub title “ Brahmacharya I”

('69', 422, 1, 2, 755035) them by gradual evolution.
('69', 422, 1, 3, 755062) Every step was thought out, well considered, and taken with the greatest deliberation.

('69', 428, 3, 4, 764968) If you feel like going because you think it would please your parents better if you were in the hospital or under Kakasaheb’s roof, you should certainly go.
('69', 428, 3, 5, 765125) I can ask for a stretcher at once and have you shifted.

('69', 428, 4, 11, 765656) or as clearly as I knew that I should pull my son Manilal through his enteric which lasted for 42 days.
('69', 428, 4, 12, 765760) 4 The doctors in both cases gave me grave warnings and said the responsibility for their deaths would be mine.
('69', 428, 4, 13, 765871) But I was as ready to sacrifice them as I was anxious to save them and careful to nurse them.
('69', 428, 4, 14, 765965) Well, God tried my faith, but He also gave me the strength to stand the trial.
('69', 428, 4, 15, 766044) I may tell you, as you are a brave man, that I am not afraid to lose you, if it should come to it, but I know that I am doing all that is needed to pull you through.
('69', 428, 4, 16, 766210) If, therefore, you will decide to leave me out of pity for me, you will be untrue to me and to yourself.
('69', 428, 4, 17, 766315) I am making this so clear to you because we are satyagrahis, we have to weigh the motives and springs of action of everything that we do, and we should deceive neither ourselves nor others.
('69', 428, 5, 18, 766505) Nanavati had no difficulty about answering: “I am thinking of going only because of you.
('69', 428, 5, 19, 766594) I feel that I should not be the source of so much worry to you.
('69', 428, 5, 20, 766658) Otherwise I know that nowhere else in the world am I going to get better nursing and more loving attention”.
('69', 428, 5, 21, 766767) And he elected to stay.

('69', 429, 2, 3, 767546) SEGAON, WARDHA, October 4, 1936
('69', 429, 3, 4, 767578) KANTI, Your letter reached Wardha yesterday evening and came to my hand this morning.
('69', 429, 3, 5, 767664) You must have received the telegram I immediately sent just for the peace of your mind even though it is Sunday.
('69', 429, 3, 6, 767777) I shall not write at length as I am sitting between two sick beds.
('69', 429, 3, 7, 767844) Balwantsinha and Nanavati are in the grip of fever.
('69', 429, 3, 8, 767896) You are in a painful situation from which you will no doubt free yourself.
('69', 429, 3, 9, 767971) Have patience and courage.
('69', 429, 3, 10, 767998) You should refuse politely but firmly to see her, saying that you have orders from me.
('69', 429, 3, 11, 768085) I am writing 1
('69', 429, 4, 12, 768100) to her also not to see you at all and not to annoy you.
('69', 429, 4, 13, 768156) For fear of the nuisance she may cause you, you do not have to go to Ahmedabad where too she is likely to follow you.
('69', 429, 4, 14, 768274) I have myself suggested to her that she might go to Ahmedabad or to Rajkot.
('69', 429, 4, 15, 768350) I have told her not to go to Trivandrum while she is unwell.
('69', 429, 4, 16, 768411) 2 Even if she follows you everywhere, you will be free from her only be refusing to see her.
('69', 429, 4, 17, 768504) However, if you otherwise like the idea of going to Ahmedabad you may by all means go.
('69', 429, 4, 18, 768591) You may stay with Maganbhai and Diwan and Ballubhai will welcome you [to their school].
('69', 429, 4, 19, 768679) Devdas will pay the fees.
('69', 429, 4, 20, 768705) I only want you to pursue your studies in peace, without any obstacle.
('69', 429, 4, 21, 768776) I shall see that you do not have to suffer annoyance from Amtul Salaam.
('69', 429, 4, 22, 768848) Write to me from time to time.

('69', 431, 2, 3, 770549) October 5, 1936
('69', 431, 3, 4, 770565) DEAR MR. HOFMEYER,
('69', 431, 4, 5, 770584) It was a great pleasure to receive your warm letter.
('69', 431, 4, 6, 770637) 1 I do hope you are having a profitable time in this land and that you find the people you meet to be hospitable.
('69', 431, 4, 7, 770751) It will be a matter of regret to me that although you have so many friends in India, we may not meet at all.

('69', 433, 1, 2, 773184) 575. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI
('69', 433, 2, 3, 773213) [October 5, 1936] 1
('69', 433, 3, 4, 773233) MAHADEV,
('69', 433, 4, 5, 773242) Just as I was about to send with Prahlad all the accompanying matter having finished it all, I got your gun shot; but it has misfired.
('69', 433, 4, 6, 773377) I had a hearty laugh when I read your message.
('69', 433, 4, 7, 773424) Nowadays we don’t have any occasions to laugh.
('69', 433, 4, 8, 773471) I had no idea that my Note 2 contained any criticism of you.
('69', 433, 4, 9, 773532) Even when Mirabehn drew my attention to it I told her, “What can Mahadev do?” Cancel my Note and send in yours.
('69', 433, 4, 10, 773644) Why should I have to insist on anything?
('69', 433, 4, 11, 773685) For my part I can manage even if nothing is issued.
('69', 433, 4, 12, 773737) A similar mistake has occurred in the current number too, which I am not at all going to correct.
('69', 433, 4, 13, 773835) I have in me a far greater strength to let such things pass than you might imagine.
('69', 433, 4, 14, 773919) However, you are after all a poet and that too with a sensitive skin; so you are easily upset.
('69', 433, 4, 15, 774014) Where can I have the remedy for this?
('69', 433, 4, 16, 774052) It would have been enough, had you only asked, ‘How if we draft the Note like this?’ Why did you have to make an issue of it?
('69', 433, 4, 17, 774178) But that is that.
('69', 433, 4, 18, 774196) “Old habits die hard.” It is useless to plead on Lilavati’s behalf.
('69', 433, 4, 19, 774264) Her coming up here has crowned her faults.
('69', 433, 4, 20, 774307) However, why didn’t she promptly take charge of him 3 when he fell ill?
('69', 433, 4, 21, 774379) The fact is she is crushed under the weight of sympathy she gets.
('69', 433, 4, 22, 774445) Look here, don’t you take offence again.
('69', 433, 4, 23, 774486) If I haven’t said the right thing you should correct me but never feel hurt.
('69', 433, 5, 24, 774563) Blessings from BAPU [PS.]
('69', 433, 6, 25, 774589) I am sending McArrison’s speech, which may be included as it is after deleting the first paragraph.
('69', 433, 7, 26, 774689) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 11492

('69', 434, 1, 2, 775001) 576. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI
('69', 434, 2, 3, 775030) SEGAON, WARDHA, October 6, 1936
('69', 434, 3, 4, 775062) MAHADEV, I am sending herewith the letters that I wrote last night.
('69', 434, 3, 5, 775130) Even today Nanavati’s fever has not gone and he is noticeably weak.
('69', 434, 3, 6, 775198) Balwantsinha has normal temperature.
('69', 434, 3, 7, 775235) Mirabehn has suffered an attack again and her illness seems to go deeper.
('69', 434, 3, 8, 775309) She has some kind of a sore on her nipple.
('69', 434, 3, 9, 775352) She is bed ridden.
('69', 434, 3, 10, 775371) The last blow dealt by Lilavati has hurt me very much.
('69', 434, 3, 11, 775426) I never thought that she would forget anyone lying ill before her eyes.
('69', 434, 3, 12, 775498) My impression has been that you encourage her.
('69', 434, 3, 13, 775545) Why didn’t you yourself put her in charge of Prabhu Dayal?
('69', 434, 3, 14, 775604) Kanu had been keeping a vigil throughout the night.
('69', 434, 3, 15, 775656) Bhansali happened to visit at 3 in the morning and he then relieved Kanu.
('69', 434, 3, 16, 775730) This much Kanu told me when I wrote to him and inquired.
('69', 434, 3, 17, 775787) He also said that she wasted a good deal of your time talking.
('69', 434, 3, 18, 775850) But I felt she had a number of complaints.
('69', 434, 3, 19, 775893) You should learn them from her as I don’t have the time and am, moreover, as good as dumb.
('69', 434, 3, 20, 775984) She will not benefit from undeserved pity.
('69', 434, 3, 21, 776027) Her trouble lies deep within her.
('69', 434, 3, 22, 776061) She herself says that she has never submitted herself to any rules.
('69', 434, 3, 23, 776129) Again my stock of envelopes is exhausted.
('69', 434, 3, 24, 776171) Why not send me eight packets of them?
('69', 434, 3, 25, 776210) I have had to send a few letters without envelopes.
('69', 434, 3, 26, 776262) I need no postcards.

('69', 440, 6, 10, 783764) 587. TASK BEFORE HARIJAN SEVAKS
('69', 440, 7, 11, 783796) Ever since the inauguration of the Harijan Sevak Sangh, the central organization has been feeding, very properly, the provincial branches.
('69', 440, 7, 12, 783935) But the time has certainly arrived for the branches to stand on their own and be self sustained, even though it may be at the sacrifice of part of their programme.
('69', 440, 7, 13, 784099) The work in each province, and for that matter in each district or taluka, should be an unequivocal demonstration of active savarna support.
('69', 440, 7, 14, 784240) For the chief mission of the Sangh is to touch the savarna heart and change it.
('69', 440, 7, 15, 784320) Supposing the central organization had collected from two or three reformers a crore of rupees, and with it established branches all over India to cover it with schools and hostels for Harijan boys and girls, it would not have hastened the day of the doom of untouchability.
('69', 440, 7, 16, 784595) For the savarna heart would remain as stony as ever.
('69', 440, 7, 17, 784648) Supposing conversely that without the cost of a single pice, by some stroke of good fortune the savarna heart was changed and untouchability became a thing of the past, the whole object of the Sangh would be fulfilled.
('69', 440, 7, 18, 784867) For in that case every public school, place of worship and other institutions would be open to Harijans precisely on the same terms as to caste Hindus.
('69', 440, 7, 19, 785019) That day may be far off or much nearer than many people expect.
('69', 440, 7, 20, 785083) Anyway that is the goal of the Harijan Sevak Sangh and never the opening of separate schools, wells, temples and the like for Harijans and consequent perpetuation of untouchability.
('69', 440, 7, 21, 785265) At present these things are
('69', 441, 0, 1, 785293) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 441, 1, 2, 785335) undoubtedly done, but they are done only as a means to THE end.
('69', 441, 1, 3, 785399) They have become necessary because the savarna heart is slow to change.
('69', 441, 1, 4, 785471) The growing number of reformers must not sit still and make protestations of removal of untouchability from themselves.
('69', 441, 1, 5, 785591) They must demonstrate that change by their visible conduct.
('69', 441, 1, 6, 785651) The spending of their purse for the Harijan cause is a tangible proof of the change and therefore an essential part of the programme.
('69', 441, 1, 7, 785785) But immediately it becomes a corner confined to a few individuals who salve their conscience by liberal donations, it ceases to be a token in the manner indicated by me.
('69', 441, 1, 8, 785955) Hence it becomes a matter of duty for the Central Board to invite the attention of the branches to this fundamental part of the programme and for the branches to appreciate it and prepare the way to becoming wholly self reliant.
('69', 441, 1, 9, 786184) Indeed the burden has been progressively thrown on provincial boards of financing their own ins titutions.
('69', 441, 1, 10, 786291) But the time has come for definite and decisive action in the direction.
('69', 441, 1, 11, 786364) This change to full self reliance will never come unless all the workers realize that this is essentially a religious movement.
('69', 441, 1, 12, 786492) We are a nation spending lavishly for causes which the masses believe to be religious.
('69', 441, 1, 13, 786579) One has only to go to the places of pilgrimage to have an ocular demonstration of the fact.
('69', 441, 1, 14, 786671) A study of the history of religious endowments will reveal the tragic story of fortunes being entrusted to them by credulous millions without ever caring to know how they were spent.
('69', 441, 1, 15, 786854) It is enough for people to believe that they pay their mite to a cause which in their opinion is religious.
('69', 441, 1, 16, 786962) Harijan workers have a cause that is wholly religious in the best sense of the term.
('69', 441, 1, 17, 787047) If they have a living faith in it, if they do not move mountains they will at least get from their surroundings enough for the institutions in their charge.
('69', 441, 2, 18, 787204) Harijan, 10 10 1936
('69', 441, 3, 19, 787224) 588. A CORRECTION
('69', 441, 4, 20, 787242) I know that Harijan contains almost always printer’s errors.
('69', 441, 4, 21, 787303) It would be tedious, if not even pedantic, to issue corrections every week.
('69', 441, 4, 22, 787379) In the difficult circumstances under which Harijan is being issued, the problem before me is to cease publication or to continue it in spite of mistakes recurring with unfailing regularity.
('69', 441, 4, 23, 787569) I have chosen the latter course whilst a sufficient number of subscribers tolerate the errors.
('69', 442, 0, 1, 787664) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 443
('69', 442, 1, 2, 787707) But the issue of 26th September contains two howlers in the article headed ‘The Law of Our Being’ which need correction: Last para, II.
('69', 442, 1, 3, 787843) 2 4. INCORRECT: “The writes seems to poohpooh the idea of honour derived from individual and national gain.” CORRECT: “The writer seems to poohpooh the idea of honour devoid of individual and national gain.” Last para, II.
('69', 442, 1, 4, 788066) 6 7. INCORRECT: “There is no question for one of self destruction, voluntary or otherwise.” CORRECT: “There is no question for me of self destruction, voluntary or otherwise.” The errors seem to have originated in Wardha, the typist having misread the manuscript sent from Segaon.

('69', 447, 4, 10, 796115) 597. TALK WITH STUDENTS OF MARWADI VIDYALAYA 1
('69', 447, 5, 11, 796162) October 12, 1936
('69', 447, 6, 12, 796179) Gandhiji asked the students to be worthy of the Principal, Sjt.
('69', 447, 6, 13, 796243) Aryanayakam, who at the invitation of Jamnalalji had agreed to take charge of the institution.
('69', 447, 6, 14, 796338) He had a distinguished career at Cambridge and London and later on at Santiniketan, and he has come to Wardha with his wife who is a great Sanskrit scholar and a distinguished graduate of the Banaras University.
('69', 447, 6, 15, 796550) She has been placed in charge of the Mahila Vidyalaya, 1 also a creation of Jamnalalji.
('69', 447, 6, 16, 796638) Gandhiji asked the boys to be not only worthy of the Principal, but of Jamnalalji...
('69', 447, 6, 17, 796723) [He said:] He had long ago broken the bonds of sect and community and creed, and though the institution owed its existence to donations from Marwadis only—that is what gave it its name—Jamnalalji would not be satisfied until it was thrown open to boys of all castes and creeds.
('69', 447, 6, 18, 797001) He has no interest until he had found his way to destroy its exclusive character, to throw it open as much to the Harijans as to any other section of Hindus, as much to the Mussalmans as to the Hindus.
('69', 447, 6, 19, 797203) He has no room in his heart for untouchability, and he had none at all for any feeling that Hinduism is in any way superior to any other religion.
('69', 447, 6, 20, 797350) He has helped Muslim institutions no less than he has done Hindu ones, and he has several Muslim friends whom he treats as blood brothers.
('69', 447, 6, 21, 797489) I would ask you students, Hindus and Muslims, to take a leaf from Jamnalalji’s book and to have the same regard for one another’s religion that Jamnalalji has, and to treat one another as
('69', 447, 7, 22, 797677) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('69', 447, 7, 23, 797727) The Principal and the students came to see Gandhiji on his birthday which according to the Vikram calendar fell on October 12.
('69', 448, 0, 1, 797854) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 449
('69', 448, 1, 2, 797897) blood brothers.
('69', 448, 1, 3, 797913) And let me tell you one thing which you may not know, and perhaps many do not know.
('69', 448, 1, 4, 797997) This passion for removal of untouchability and freedom from communal feeling as well as equal regard for all religions, Jamnalalji does not at all owe to me.
('69', 448, 1, 5, 798155) It is not possible for anyone to transfer his conviction to another.
('69', 448, 1, 6, 798224) All one can do is to help another to manifest the conviction which is already in him.
('69', 448, 1, 7, 798310) But in respect of Jamnalalji, I could not take the credit for having even helped him to arrive at or to manifest those convictions in his life.
('69', 448, 1, 8, 798454) He had the convictions in him long before he met me and he had lived up to them.
('69', 448, 1, 9, 798535) It was these inner convictions of his that brought him and me together and made possible the close co operation in which we have been able to work together for so many years.
('69', 448, 1, 10, 798710) You children have to be worthy of a man like him.

('69', 452, 4, 12, 804535) 606. AHIMSA CONUNDRUMS
('69', 452, 5, 13, 804558) A college professor and two representatives of a class of fifty students write: 1
('69', 452, 6, 14, 804640) As you are no doubt aware, the Intermediate Prose Text Book, Pearce and Aryatna’s Models of Comparative Prose, used in most Intermediate Colleges in India this year, contains a selection about five pages long from your book The Story of My Experiments with Truth.
('69', 452, 6, 15, 804904) The selection is entitled “Ahimsa”, and contains your discussion of this most challenging principle and its application to our lives.
('69', 452, 7, 16, 805038) The fifty students in my prose class, and I, their instructor, have been spending several class periods studying and discussing the above essay....
('69', 452, 8, 17, 805186) At one point, however, both the students and I, their instructor, have been unable clearly to understand the precise nature of your views.
('69', 452, 8, 18, 805325) I refer to your statement about the conduct of a votary of ahimsa in case of war, particularly the following passage 2: “When two nations are fighting, the duty of a votary of ahimsa is to stop the war.
('69', 452, 8, 19, 805528) He who is not equal to that duty, he who has no power of resisting war, he who is not qualified to resist war, may take part in war, and yet whole heartedly try to free himself, his nation, and the world from War.” A little further on (discussing three methods of recourse in case of the European War, for yourself): “...
('69', 452, 8, 20, 805850) or I could participate in the war
('69', 452, 9, 21, 805884) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('69', 452, 9, 22, 805921) 2 Vide “ An Autobiography”, sub title “ Miniature Satyagraha”
('69', 453, 0, 1, 805983) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 453, 1, 2, 806025) on the side of the Empire and thereby acquire the capacity and fitness for resisting the violence of war.
('69', 453, 1, 3, 806131) I lacked this capacity and fitness, so I thought there was nothing for it but for me to serve in the War.”
('69', 453, 2, 4, 806238) We should be deeply and humbly grateful if you would expand and clarify this subject and your past and present views upon it...
('69', 453, 2, 5, 806366) I do not know that I need have suppressed the name of the college or the names of the signatories.
('69', 453, 2, 6, 806465) The learned professor has sent me a stamped envelope for answer.
('69', 453, 2, 7, 806530) This presumes a personal reply.
('69', 453, 2, 8, 806562) But I have only limited time at my disposal especially when I am nursing two precious patients.
('69', 453, 2, 9, 806658) I would not miss my weekly talk with the readers of Harijan.
('69', 453, 2, 10, 806719) I am, therefore, with apologies to my correspondents, combining two purposes to save my time.
('69', 453, 2, 11, 806813) The question raised in the letter is of very great importance and has always caused me the greatest difficulty, not much in deciding upon the action to be taken at a given moment but in justifying my conduct in terms of ahimsa.
('69', 453, 2, 12, 807041) For the same action may outwardly be taken by the believer and the unbeliever.
('69', 453, 2, 13, 807120) At these times the motive alone decides its quality.
('69', 453, 2, 14, 807173) At the time of writing I have neither the text book nor the original in Gujarati of which the text is a translation.
('69', 453, 2, 15, 807290) But I have a recollection of what I wrote.
('69', 453, 2, 16, 807333) What is more, so far as I am aware, my views on ahimsa, as I held them, remain the same today.
('69', 453, 2, 17, 807428) The general proposition that I laid down in the quotation was derived from my conduct during the European War.
('69', 453, 2, 18, 807539) I had thrown myself whole heartedly into it at the peril of my life—not because of the risks attendant upon serving at such times, but because at the time I was attending drills and camps I was suffering from pleurisy and general weakness as I had hardly regained the strength I had lost during an exhausting fourteen days’ fast I had undertaken two or three months or before the War.
('69', 453, 2, 19, 807924) I believed then the British Empire to be on the whole a system beneficial to humanity.
('69', 453, 2, 20, 808011) I had dreamt of one day converting it to methods of peace instead of war for the sake even of its own existence though in another form.
('69', 453, 2, 21, 808147) But I was fully conscious of my limitations.
('69', 453, 2, 22, 808192) I was an insignificant atom ineffective for resistance to its general policy.
('69', 453, 2, 23, 808270) Whether I joined the War or not, I was helplessly party to it, inasmuch as I ate the food protected by the British fleet.
('69', 453, 2, 24, 808392) I was enjoying personal liberty too under its protection.
('69', 453, 2, 25, 808450) If, therefore, I helped the War somehow or other, I felt that for me as a votary of ahimsa, it was better to take a direct part in it so as to enable me the
('69', 454, 0, 1, 808607) VOL. 69: 16 MAY, 1936 19 OCTOBER, 1936 455
('69', 454, 1, 2, 808650) sooner to end War.
('69', 454, 1, 3, 808669) It is quite possible that all this was argument of the weak and that if I felt that war was an evil, I should have gone away from it even if it meant starvation or a rebel’s death.
('69', 454, 1, 4, 808850) Anyway I did not think so then, nor do I now.
('69', 454, 1, 5, 808896) It is wholly beside the argument what my attitude would now be, seeing that I no longer believe in the Empire as on the whole a beneficent power.
('69', 454, 1, 6, 809042) To illustrate my answer, let me take another argument from my own life.
('69', 454, 1, 7, 809114) Even when I was a little urchin my heart and intellect rebelled against untouchability.
('69', 454, 1, 8, 809202) But being then an insignificant member of the family I acquiesced in their conduct towards Harijans which I should not do now.
('69', 454, 1, 9, 809329) Needless to say, I could not then have argued out my conduct.
('69', 454, 1, 10, 809391) My personal belief did not appear to me to be inconsistent with my living in the family.
('69', 454, 1, 11, 809480) Indeed life is made of such compromises.
('69', 454, 1, 12, 809521) Ahimsa, simply because it is purest, unselfish love, often demands such compromises.
('69', 454, 1, 13, 809606) The conditions are imperative.
('69', 454, 1, 14, 809637) There should be no self in one’s action, no fear, no untruth, and it must be in furtherance of the cause of ahimsa.
('69', 454, 1, 15, 809753) The compromise must be natural to oneself, not imposed from without.
('69', 454, 1, 16, 809822) I should not at all wonder if my answer has given no satisfaction to the professor and his pupils.
('69', 454, 1, 17, 809921) I must be pardoned for the constant reference to my own actions.
('69', 454, 1, 18, 809986) The reason is obvious.
('69', 454, 1, 19, 810009) I am not a well read man in any sense of the term.
('69', 454, 1, 20, 810060) All I know of ahimsa is in the first instance derived from my own experiences and experiments carried on in broad daylight in a humble scientific spirit and in the fear of God which is Truth.
('69', 454, 1, 21, 810252) Harijan, 17 10 1936

('69', 457, 4, 7, 814052) 612. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('69', 457, 5, 8, 814094) October 19,1936 CHI.
('69', 457, 5, 9, 814115) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I liked the letters from you both.
('69', 457, 5, 10, 814171) Manilal, it was your dharma to have pointed out my shortcoming which you did, nor was it indecorous.
('69', 457, 5, 11, 814272) Filial piety consists in respect for parents in spite of one’s knowledge of their shortcomings.
('69', 457, 5, 12, 814368) In that test none of you fail, barring Harilal.
('69', 457, 5, 13, 814416) But the fault is not entirely Harilal’s.
('69', 457, 5, 14, 814457) For how could we hold him responsible for what he does or says under the influence of drink?
('69', 457, 5, 15, 814550) I shall not write a long reply as I am surrounded by patients.
('69', 457, 5, 16, 814613) Mirabehn as well as Nanavati are better today.
('69', 457, 5, 17, 814660) I do not repent for the kind of education I gave you brothers.
('69', 457, 5, 18, 814723) I should have been glad if I could have done more along the same lines.
('69', 457, 5, 19, 814795) I offered you at the altar of my sacrifice, not unmindful of your well being but knowing it fully well.
('69', 457, 5, 20, 814899) Nor do I believe the result has been unhappy.
('69', 457, 5, 21, 814945) There was a special purpose in sending Sorabji 1. He achieved it too; we could have seen it had he lived.
('69', 457, 5, 22, 815051) As for Chhaganlal 2, he was sent to prepare himself for a specific task.
('69', 457, 5, 23, 815124) It miscarried because he was threatened with tuberculosis and left England abruptly.
('69', 457, 5, 24, 815209) How do you forget about Ritch 3 and Polak 4?
('69', 457, 5, 25, 815254) There was a purpose in sending them and there was one also in not sending you brothers.
('69', 457, 5, 26, 815342) By the time you had reached the age of discretion my infatuation with Western education had worn away.
('69', 457, 5, 27, 815445) It was not that I did not provide you such education for want of money.
('69', 457, 5, 28, 815517) The Doctor’s 5 purse was always at my disposal.
('69', 457, 5, 29, 815565) When Ritch was sent I too was in a position to meet the cost.
('69', 457, 5, 30, 815627) However, I purposely moulded you in the school of experience and drafted you for public
('69', 457, 6, 31, 815715) 1 Vide “Letter to Harilal Gandhi”, 16 10 1912 2 Chhaganlal Gandhi 3 L.W. Ritch; vide “Speech at Farewell to L. W. Ritch”, 9 3 1905 4 H.S.L. Polak 5 Dr. Pranjivan Jagjivan Mehta

('69', 458, 1, 2, 815936) service.
('69', 458, 1, 3, 815945) I understand how you might regret the want in view of the present times, but that does not change my thinking.
('69', 458, 1, 4, 816056) Don’t you know that I have done the same with the boys and girls that came to be placed in my charge here too?
('69', 458, 1, 5, 816167) I am not worried that Radha, Keshu, Shankar, Bal, Jayanti, Kanti, etc.
('69', 458, 1, 6, 816238) rebelled against it.
('69', 458, 1, 7, 816259) I see in it the force of the current stream and not any defect in my thinking.
('69', 458, 1, 8, 816338) The best of workers here have no Western education, and men like Mahadev who have it are with me not because of it but because of their other qualities.
('69', 458, 1, 9, 816491) I do of course make use of Mahadev’s education by the way, but that is of no great significance.
('69', 458, 1, 10, 816588) It may be my efficiency.
('69', 458, 1, 11, 816613) Mahadev will himself admit that Maganlal was more valuable than he.
('69', 458, 1, 12, 816681) How many educated men do you think there are in my army?
('69', 458, 1, 13, 816738) To what position would I have been reduced had I depended on them?
('69', 458, 1, 14, 816805) Don’t you know that I had a hand in sending Joseph, both the Godfreys and Bernard?
('69', 458, 1, 15, 816888) Where are they?
('69', 458, 1, 16, 816904) What have they achieved?
('69', 458, 1, 17, 816929) I also know the art of producing barristers and doctors, but it has borne no fruit.
('69', 458, 1, 18, 817013) I think you brothers were spared the wild goose chase.
('69', 458, 1, 19, 817068) Why can you not see my non violence in the exceptions I made in the cases of West 1 and Sam 2?
('69', 458, 1, 20, 817163) Had I not been generous to them, how could I have accommodated them and others like them?
('69', 458, 1, 21, 817253) You know that I encouraged Kitchin 3 to eat meat when he was ill and, as a result, he gave it up altogether.
('69', 458, 1, 22, 817362) In the Boer War I myself served wine to the stonebreakers in my corps and served bidis to others.
('69', 458, 1, 23, 817460) Discretion is very necessary in doing all such things.
('69', 458, 1, 24, 817515) Generosity to others is as necessary as strictness with oneself.
('69', 458, 1, 25, 817580) I have dilated far more than I had intended.
('69', 458, 1, 26, 817625) You need not send anything to Kanti as Devdas has undertaken to pay all his expenses.
('69', 458, 2, 27, 817711) Blessings from BAPU
('69', 458, 3, 28, 817731) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 4858

('69', 459, 1, 2, 817904) 613. LETTER TO BALVANTRAI K. THAKORE
('69', 459, 2, 3, 817941) SEGAON, WARDHA, October 19, 1936
('69', 459, 3, 4, 817974) BHAISHRI BALVANTRAI1
('69', 459, 4, 5, 817995) I am at present busy nursing patients.
('69', 459, 4, 6, 818034) I finished your letter little by little yesterday evening.
('69', 459, 4, 7, 818093) I have no idea what I would be able to do in Ahmedabad.
('69', 459, 4, 8, 818149) I regard myself quite unfit to preside over the Conference.
('69', 459, 4, 9, 818209) Being a Mahatma, perhaps, I am supposed to know all things.
('69', 459, 4, 10, 818269) Would you send your suggestions in the form of an amendment?
('69', 459, 4, 11, 818330) I should be glad to meet you, but how could there be such an occasion?
('69', 459, 4, 12, 818401) After all I am not visiting Bombay.
('69', 459, 4, 13, 818437) I Shall be wandering into Ahmedabad.
('69', 459, 4, 14, 818474) I expect you are in good health.
('69', 459, 5, 15, 818507) Vandemataram from MOHANDAS [PS.] Your letter shall remain confidential.
('69', 459, 5, 16, 818579) I have destroyed it.

('69', 459, 7, 18, 818644) 614. LETTER TO BENARSIDAS CHATURVEDI
('69', 459, 8, 19, 818681) October 19, 1936
('69', 459, 9, 20, 818698) BHAI BENARSIDAS,
('69', 459, 10, 21, 818715) Prabhu Dayal gave me the news of your brother’s death.
('69', 459, 10, 22, 818770) You are a man of knowledge and therefore hardly need to be consoled.
('69', 459, 10, 23, 818839) We all have to go the same way as Ramnarayan, the only difference being in time.
('69', 459, 10, 24, 818920) Why then should we grieve over it?
('69', 459, 10, 25, 818955) But with the passing away of our loved ones, our responsibility increases and yours has grown heavily.
('69', 459, 10, 26, 819058) God alone is our true help at such times.
('69', 459, 10, 27, 819100) He alone can guide you.
('69', 459, 11, 28, 819124) Blessings from BAPU

('69', 460, 1, 2, 819277) 615. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI
('69', 460, 2, 3, 819306) October 19, 1936
('69', 460, 3, 4, 819323) MAHADEV,
('69', 460, 4, 5, 819332) I can say that I have done a fair amount of writing today.
('69', 460, 4, 6, 819391) Baba has done a great thing.
('69', 460, 4, 7, 819420) Mira’s temperature today has been 98 o and it has not risen so far.
('69', 460, 4, 8, 819488) She however continues to be restless.
('69', 460, 4, 9, 819526) There is no release of saliva in her mouth.

('69', 460, 4, 11, 819639) There is something else too.
('69', 460, 4, 12, 819668) I want no oranges or lemons.

('69', 461, 0, 1, 820142) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('69', 461, 1, 2, 820184) APPENDICES
('69', 461, 2, 3, 820195) APPENDIX I
('69', 461, 3, 4, 820206) LETTER FROM JAWAHARLAL NEHRU 1
('69', 461, 4, 5, 820237) May 25, 1936
('69', 461, 5, 6, 820250) About women and W. C. I began by saying that I had received some protests for their non inclusion.
('69', 461, 5, 7, 820349) I would have welcomed even stronger protests for I wanted our women to be more aggressive and to insist on their rights, both political and social.
('69', 461, 5, 8, 820497) I invited them to organize themselves to press for their rights which they were not likely to get if they waited for the goodwill of their menfolk.
('69', 461, 5, 9, 820645) About the W. C. I said that it was formed under peculiar circumstances when I had to play an unusual part.
('69', 461, 5, 10, 820752) The hayadar (self respecting) president would probably have resigned and I being behaya (shameless) stuck on even though the majority of the Congress had decided against me on some vital issues.
('69', 461, 5, 11, 820947) This peculiar position was reflected in the formation of the W. C., which certainly could not be under the circumstances of my choice although technically I was responsible for it.
('69', 461, 5, 12, 821128) When various viewpoints have to be represented, the lesser ones go to the wall.
('69', 461, 5, 13, 821208) You are perfectly right in saying that I was responsible for the exclusion of women.
('69', 461, 5, 14, 821293) But yet this is not the whole matter.
('69', 461, 5, 15, 821331) I would have liked to have a woman in the Working Committee but as the matters developed and a number of other names appeared and stayed, there was little choice left.
('69', 461, 5, 16, 821499) Ultimately I felt that it mattered little to me who was in the W. C. and who was not.
('69', 461, 5, 17, 821585) The Committee as it took shape was not my child, I could hardly recognize it and to some inclusions, as you know, I reacted strongly.
('69', 461, 5, 18, 821719) Yet ultimately I submitted but inevitably with the thought that I was surrendering to others and almost against my own better judgment.
('69', 461, 5, 19, 821855) At the very first meeting, almost without provocations, the inherent conflicts appeared.
('69', 461, 5, 20, 821944) The whole purpose of a president nominating a homogeneous committee was thus frustrated.
('69', 461, 6, 21, 822033) File No.
('69', 461, 6, 22, 822042) 32/12/36, Home, Political.
('69', 461, 6, 23, 822069) Courtesy: National Archives of India
('69', 461, 7, 24, 822106) 1 Vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 27 9 1935

('69', 462, 1, 2, 822196) APPENDIX II
('69', 462, 2, 3, 822208) LETTER FROM VALLABHBHAI PATEL TO RAJENDRA PRASAD 1
('69', 462, 3, 4, 822259) May 29, 1936
('69', 462, 4, 5, 822272) I have received your letter...
('69', 462, 4, 6, 822303) of 24th with Kripalani’s letter to you enclosed with it.
('69', 462, 5, 7, 822360) His 2 Bombay speeches have disturbed me much.
('69', 462, 5, 8, 822406) I am not worried so much about khaddar.
('69', 462, 5, 9, 822446) It will recoil on him if he goes on in this fashion.
('69', 462, 5, 10, 822499) But I cannot stand the attitude of injured innocence he has assumed regarding the nomination of members in the W. C., particularly his statement regarding omission of a woman.
('69', 462, 5, 11, 822675) Rajaji feels equally strongly.
('69', 462, 6, 12, 822706) Bapu had written to him on these points and the extracts of his reply and the last letter of Bapu to him on the subject of the W. C. nominations are enclosed herewith for your information.
('69', 462, 6, 13, 822895) Re: khadi—he says the report is not correct and he had issued a correct version of his speech next day though.
('69', 462, 6, 14, 823006) I have not seen it reported anywhere.
('69', 462, 6, 15, 823044) His reply about the W. C. is bad enough and I don’t think I can swallow it.
('69', 462, 6, 16, 823120) It is a humiliating position in which I for one would not agree to stay at any cost.
('69', 462, 6, 17, 823205) He was expected to act honourably with his colleagues but he cannot do so or if he feels that we are a drag on him we must clear the way for him.
('69', 462, 7, 18, 823351) I am going to Bangalore tomorrow where I am staying till the 12th and then we disperse for our respective places.
('69', 462, 7, 19, 823465) Hope you are doing well.
('69', 462, 8, 20, 823490) File No.
